Dialogue:
Person1: No.
Person2: Well you're probably right about that. It certainly can't help Sister Agnes to have this investigation continued for any length of time.
Person1: Why do you call it an investigation? I never have.
Person2: Your mother was a resident of Saint Catherines home before you moved her.
Person1: What does this have to do with..?

Person1: You, sister...
Person2: Look at the trouble you've caused. Now you know what Giang Hu life is really like.  If you think of me as your sister, let me give you some sisterly advice.  You can run from marriage, but not your parents.
Person1: They forced me to marry!
Person2: Go back to them first.  Then you can decide about Lo.
Person1: You know about Lo?
Person2: He really loves you.  Come back to Peking with me.  We'll find a solution.
Person1: Where is he now?
Person2: Li Mu Bai has made arrangements. He sent him to Wudan Mountain.
Person1: You're working together to set me up!  I'm leaving!
Person2: How dare you accuse us?  I always knew you had stolen the sword! I've done nothing but protect you and your family.  And you're repaid me with nothing but contempt.  Li Mu Bai himself spared you, and all you do is insult him.  We wanted some peace and you've ruined it all! You're no sister of mine!
Person1: What do I care?  You were never a real friend anyway.  But I wonder, how long could you last as my enemy?

Person1: What time are visiting hours?
Person2: I've made arrangements with Dr. Gynde for 10:30. But Jeffrey, you'll have to walk over; I need the car this morning.
Person1: Well. Okay.
Person2: Jeffrey, when you see your father.
Person1: Yeah?
Person2: He doesn't know you're out of school. He thinks it's a vacation for you.
Person1: What?
Person2: It would be too much for him. So please let him think as he does, that you're home just to see him.
Person1: Thanks a lot, Mom.
Person2: .Jeffrey!. Nobody wanted you to leave school and go to work in the store. maybe going back to school will be an option one day. I hope so.

Person1: C'mon, you two... Jacques, we have to get ready for the ceremony tonight.  We have a new world champion.
Person2: I'm a little tired, I don't know if...
Person1: Get in the car!

Person1: Please don't cry. Please, honey.
Person2: What are you sorry for?
Person1: I don't know. For the food business. I guess. I just thought, you know, we'd sneak a Big Mac on Mommy, like we used to.
Person2: I want to go home.
Person1: You can't.

Person1: I want you to come home with me right now, Jody.
Person2: Who is she?
Person1: She's nobody you should be concerned with.
Person2: Whoever tried to kill me was made up to look exactly like this picture of Lisa Sherman, clothes and all. I think that concerns me.
Person1: Don't make me order you.

Person1: You dropped a glass.
Person2: I...
Person1: A cheap wine glass from the caterers.  You started crying.  I tried to comfort you...
Person2: In the living room...
Person1: You shoved me away and ran out to the patio.  I took you home.
Person2: But why?  I can't understand how I could just completely--
Person1: It was maybe a week after the accident. We were moving.  It was a hard time.
Person2: But I don't remember.
Person1: Sweetheart, it was over a year ago.
Person2: What's wrong with me?

Person1: Where are we?
Person2: Where are we? You know where we are. It's called the beach. It's where life first crawled up out of the sea. I come here sometimes... when I feel like crawling back in.
Person1: You don't have to do this.
Person2: Do what, show you a good time?
Person1: I'm not good company. I should be alone.
Person2: I don't think so, but if that's what you want...

Person1: Not that much appreciation. I thought we were gonna tone down that flabby ass.
Person2: Hey, I'm so sorry I'm not the stud that you are.

Person1: What are you listening to, chicken ass?
Person2: Ah, leave him alone.  He's doing no harm.
Person1: With a face like that?  I don't want you looking at me.  You hear?

Person1: Look, I'm just on this boat, okay? I'm an engineer.  Whatever this is, it's not for me to be involved, okay?
Person2: I don't remember Zurich.

Person1: I know why most of you are here. We're not stupid. But before you get to sell what we teach you over at United Airlines, you gotta give the Navy six years of your life, Sweet Pea. Lot of things can happen in six year. Another war could come up in six years. If you're too peaceful a person to dump napalm on an enemy village where there might be women and children, I'm gonna find that out. Understand?
Person2: Yes, sir!

Person1: I'm married, George.  Me.  I can't believe it.  Can you believe I'm married, George?
Person2: You're a lucky man, Diego.
Person1: I love you, my brother, do you know that?
Person2: I love you too, man.

Person1: You realize, Sal, that we're gonna get outta the country, so if you wanna talk to somebody, do it now ... You gotta Mother or a Father? Friends?  If we gotta be outside the country, where do you wanna go?  Any country. Just name a country.
Person2: Wyoming.
Person1: Wyoming ... That's not out of the country -- that's in the United States ... Look, I'll be back.

Person1: Oh you know, for a minute I thought it was --
Person2: Paul? Yeah. You think --

Person1: It's just that, you know, I was thinking about how, in class, you're always telling us 'that writers make choices -- at least the good ones. And, don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the book isn't really great -- I mean, really great -- but at times it's, well, very detailed, you know, with the genealogies of everyone's horses and all the dental records and so on -- and I don't know, maybe I'm wrong, but it sort of reads, in places, like, well, actually, like...  ...you didn't make any choices at all. And I was wondering if it might not be different if, maybe, when you wrote, you weren't always... under the influence.
Person2: Uh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but, as shocking as this may sound, I'm not the first writer to sip a little weed. And furthermore, it might interest you to know that one book I wrote, as you say, 'under the influence,' happened to win a little something called the PEN award which, by the way, I accepted 'under the influence.'

Person1: What do you want from me, Jack?  Name it.  You want money?
Person2: You gonna write me a check?
Person1: We'll go to my bank.  I'll make a withdrawal.

Person1: How am I a hypocrite?
Person2: Oh please Annette. You spend all your time preaching about waiting for love. Well here it is. Right in front of you, but you're going to turn your back on it. I'm sorry that we're not at the age where we can get married. If we were, I'd propose, but that's not going to happen. So I guess we're just in a tough situation. I'll move on, but you... you're going to have to live with yourself knowing you've turned your back on love. And that makes you a hypocrite.

Person1: Do you know how to count?
Person2: Of course I do?  Bring them up!
Person1: Jeanne... that is not ten thousand reinforcements -- that is one hundred very loyal but very tired soldiers.
Person2: But... where is Dunois... where are the men the king promised me?
Person1: He never sent them... Don't you understand?  He doesn't want this war anymore... he has his crown now, that's all he ever wanted...
Person2: But my voices... they promised me...
Person1: To hell with your voices -- it's time to face facts!  We have nothing to do here... none of us... not even you.  You should go home, Jeanne.

Person1: Luke, you probably don't remember me, Roscoe Fitts, I'm the grocer here in town.
Person2: Good to meet you.  Again.
Person1: Like Ernie said, we're all glad to have you back.
Person2: Thanks.
Person1: And I hear you and Harry are planning on re-opening the Bijou.
Person2: We're gonna try.  Place needs a lot of work.
Person1: I can only imagine.  You know, I spoke with your Dad last year about maybe taking the Bijou off his hands.  I don't think he gave it very much thought.
Person2: Well, he loves the place.  It's his home.
Person1: Luke, I'm hopping you can help him see the reality of the situation. I'll come to the point.  I want to buy the property, and I'm prepared to offer six-thousand dollars for it.  And that's just for the property, mind you.  If you want, I'll leave it to you and your father to dismantle and liquidate the building for whatever salvage value it has, and you keep those proceeds.  I just want the land.
Person2: That's... well, that's very generous, but if you've already got a store...?
Person1: The days of the storefront grocery are numbered.  I plan on putting up a free-standing supermarket.
Person2: A super market.  Huh.
Person1: You think it over.  No reason to risk financial ruin for the sake of a crumbling old building.

Person1: My father's company imports and exports. Archaeology is part of the business. We happen to get along just fine, smartass. Look, why don't you bust somebody else's balls for a change.
Person2: I thought you meant...
Person1: You thought I meant...too tough to apologize, huh? You must have been a very lonely girl.

Person1: I found out you've been undermining my proposals to the board.
Person2: I just gave them a different perspective, that's all.
Person1: You don't want to go down this road with me. I've always played fair with you.
Person2: I didn't see it as undermining. I just voiced my concerns.
Person1: Next time, voice them to me first. Let's keep our disagreements in-house.

Person1: I'm sorry about getting on your case earlier.  I just see you getting sucked in deeper and deeper, and I -- anyway.  I'm sorry.
Person2: S'okay.  I know you still love me.

Person1: I've seen lots of people.  It's not a big thing for me.
Person2: Hand me a towel.  I'm getting out.
Person1: I'm coming in.
Person2: I don't want you to!
Person1: We're not gonna do anything.
Person2: Why are you so stupid?
Person1: Why are you so uptight?
Person2: I don't even...what do you mean?  I don't even know what that means.
Person1: It means I'm gonna shampoo my hair and stay out of your way.
Person2: Hand me a towel.  Hand me a towel.

Person1: Jabez Stone -- did you or did you not sign this document?
Person2: Yes, I did -- but you tricked me into signing it! You told me my soul was nothing ... that I could forget all about a soul, in exchange for money. That was a lie, a lie, a lie.
Person1: That is highly irrelevant to this case, Your Honor.

Person1: It is not beautiful.
Person2: You read my thoughts, Mr. Holland.
Person1: It's easy enough to read the thoughts of a newcomer. Everything seems beautiful because you don't understand.  Those flying fish -- they are not leaping for joy. They're jumping in terror.  Bigger fish want to eat them. That luminous water -- it takes its gleam from millions of tiny dead bodies. It's the glitter of putrescence.  There's no beauty here -- it's death and decay.
Person2: You can't really believe that.

Person1: I hate having my picture taken.
Person2: You're crazy. The camera loves you, Vanessa.

Person1: What are you doing?
Person2: He has no heartbeat!
Person1: You're hurting him!!
Person2: I'm massaging his heart. I saw it done once.
Person1: ARE YOU CRAZY?!! STOP IT!!!
Person2: LISTEN TO ME! IF I DON'T DO THIS, HE'S DEAD!

Person1: It's just an innocent question.  Besides I just wanted to clarify your intentions.
Person2: Whaddya mean?
Person1: Well I just wanted to make sure you know, fully and completely, that you're never gonna get any from me, at least in this lifetime.

Person1: Now listen up, Ruben.  You never, never, never mess with somebody inside the case!
Person2: Excuse me?  Excuse me?!  What do you...
Person1: You damn well better start working on that impulse control.  A woman who is implicated in this case? Someone who's practically a piece of evidence?
Person2: It's against your rules that I try to help a witness who's scared shitless?  Who's...
Person1: The woman's unstable.  You could wind up with a harassment charge. Anything.  You're like some horny little teenager.

Person1: Please be a little more careful how you talk, Mr. Mitchell.
Person2: How careful should I be?
Person1: I don't like being referred to as babe, or addressed as baby. I don't like your possessive attitude, nor your hints of secret knowledge. In fact, to be very frank, Mr. Mitchell, I don't think I like you.
Person2: Maybe you're going to have to like me.

Person1: I've analyzed the data, and I think we should switch our marketing strategy to target a younger demographic.
Person2: Oh, Lucas, always with a new theory. You think you’re so smart.
Person1: It's not about thinking I'm smart, Nina. It's about adapting to the market.
Person2: Maybe we should get more opinions before making any drastic changes.
Person1: That's fair. Let's discuss it in the next team meeting.

Person1: Just souvenirs.  Towels and stuff.
Person2: You1re leaving, too?
Person1: I never wanted to hurt anybody.  In fact... I even thought I was helping.

Person1: What's going on?
Person2: Your capacity for self-delusion is remarkable, Dr. Singer.

Person1: And this hand... it... it slashed Doctor Layton's throat... and the Deputy. Then it grabbed Danny by the head...  And it pulled his head right down into his chest... I couldn't... Hayes lays a hand his shoulder.
Person2: Take it easy, Ruby...
Person1: Did you find a scalpel? Did you find a murder weapon?

Person1: We're making too much of this.
Person2: No, we're not.
Person1: I'm not a lonely spooky writer like you. Nursing a hundred grudges. I'm a man who loves life.
Person2: We're talking about something deeper than grudges. How do we respond to personal attack?

Person1: You looked just like your father... The first time the shark came to Amity....
Person2: I don't want to talk about that.
Person1: It's a terrible thing to know some- thing no one else wants to believe.
Person2: I'm tired of hearing about it. There's no shark.  Sean wasn't killed by the same shark.. Dad didn't die because of it...It's all wrong... Some fantasy you've concocted...You keep bringing it up.

Person1: So how are you doing, dad?
Person2: Great. I've just started a new company. Solid financing. It's good.  I love you Jacko, you know that
Person1: Yes, I know that.
Person2: Don't let yourself down.
Person1: I won't.  Goodbye, dad.

Person1: I helped you not to think about Wally. You were so upset--you couldn't stand worrying about him, about his being killed and not coming back-- but when you were with me, you could stop worrying... well, for a while, anyway. This is how I helped you, right?
Person2: Please... that's enough. I loved you, too--you know I did.
Person1: "...did." Well, okay.
Person2: Please don't...
Person1: And now that Wally's coming back, and because he'll certainly need you...
Person2: You say that as though it's some awful thing!  I never stopped loving Wally!

Person1: Why don't I just wait three weeks and tell her I was cleaning out my wallet and found her number...
Person2: ...then ask where you met her...
Person1: Yeah, I'll tell her I don't remember and then I'll ask what she looks like.  Then I'll ask if we messed around. How's that, Tee? Is that "the money"?

Person1: They didn't teach it at Memorial Hospital.  I had my suspicions, though, about the Directress of Training.
Person2: Very well.  That means that you have met all Mr. Holland's requirements.  Now, as to salary -- it's quite good -- two hundred dollars a month.
Person1: That is good.  But I'd like to know more about the case.
Person2: I'm afraid I'm not able to tell you much. Only that the patient is a young woman -- the wife of a Mr. Paul Holland with whom we do considerable business.
Person1: That will mean another interview, won't it?
Person2: No, this is quite final.  You see, Mr. Holland is a sugar planter.  He lives in St. Sebastian Island in the West Indies.
Person1: The West Indies?
Person2: A year's contract -- a trip with all expenses paid -- that's not so bad, you know.
Person1: But it's so far away...
Person2: That's rather nice, isn't it?

Person1: Last time might as well've been the first.  I remember all the times, don't I.  Watching her grow up --  in increments.
Person2: She told me you were a ghost in her life. Daddy the friendly ghost.  Coming back to haunt her.
Person1: Well, she twigged by the time she was eight or nine that daddy wasn't in the Royal Marines or doing scientific research in the jungles of Borneo or playing Iago in a worldwide tour of OTHELLO.
Person2: Still, you could never ... do what she wanted.

Person1: So, you are William's wild young neighbor?  Or should I say, 'brother'; William claims you as a member of his family.  I have heard so many unflattering tales about you, and I understand, that except for you, this 'family' is quite cultivated.
Person2: George, I'm sorry.
Person1: Oh, but you must not mind my talking about you!  In fact, William says my main job here at Belvoir is to civilize you; to make an honest English gentleman out of you.
Person2: That's not what I said!  Now, Sally, you're embarrassing me!  Watch out for her, George; she talks refinement, but she has a barbarous soul!

Person1: But you gave me a rose ...
Person2: And tomorrow I'll give one to somebody else.  Get dressed.  Get out.
Person1: You shit.  Who do you think you are?
Person2: I'm JP Monroe, you stupid little bitch. Now get out of my life.
Person1: You ... I can't believe you, you bastard!  You get me in here ...
Person2: Right.  Like you were hog-tied or something.

Person1: I don't write the questions.  I just review them.
Person2: What's all this for?
Person1: We want a sense of your overall capabilities, limitations, turn-ons, turn-offs...
Person2: No, I mean, what is it FOR?  What are you selling?
Person1: Oh... it's a game.
Person2: A game?
Person1: Tailored specifically to each participant.  Think of it as a great vacation, except you don't go to it, it comes to you.
Person2: What kind of vacation?
Person1: It's different every time.
Person2: Humor me with specifics.
Person1: We provide whatever's lacking.
Person2: And if nothing's lacking?
Person1: May I make two suggestions... ?
Person2: Do you really expect me to participate without knowing a single thing?
Person1: First, admit to yourself that it sounds intriguing.  Second, you don't have to decide today.  Take the silly tests, fill out the forms.  One day, the game begins.  You either love it or hate it.  Decide then.  We're like an experimental Book-of-the-Month- Club; drop out at any time with no further obligation.  That was my sales pitch.

Person1: Vanderbilt's not that far from U of M.
Person2: Yeah right.
Person1: What?  We both have cars.
Person2: Yeah but, no offense, you're talking about a post-high school, long- distance relationship, and you and Kevin haven't even done it yet.
Person1: That's not why we're going out.
Person2: What the hell are you expecting him to drive to Vanderbilt for?  Milk and cookies?
Person1: Jessica!  He'll drive there for me, and I'll drive to Ann Arbor for him. We're going to have sex when he's ready and I'm ready.  It's got to be completely perfect.  I want the right place, the right time, the right moment.
Person2: Vicky, it's not a space shuttle launch, it's sex.  So did you do the physics write-up?
Person1: Please.

Person1: He's not really my friend.  I just do a job for him now and then.
Person2: Tyrell could help us, Sebastian.
Person1: He could?
Person2: His company made us.
Person1: I'd be happy to mention it to him.
Person2: Be better if I could talk to him in person.  But he's not an easy man to get to.
Person1: No.
Person2: When do you deliver your project?
Person1: This afternoon.

Person1: Wow... .
Person2: What do you weigh these days, slugger?
Person1: ...eight-seven, eighty-eight. What's it to you?
Person2: Gee, when you tipped one seventy-five you were beautiful. You should've been another Billy Conn. That skunk I got to manage you brought you along too fast.
Person1: It wasn't him!  It was you, Charley. You and Johnny. Like the night the two of youse come in the dressing room and says, "Kid, this ain't your night we're going for the price on Wilson." It ain't my night. I'd of taken Wilson apart that night! I was ready remember the early rounds throwing them combinations. So what happens This bum Wilson he gets the title shot outdoors in the ballpark!  and what do I get a couple of bucks and a one-way ticket to Palookaville.  It was you, Charley. You was my brother. You should of looked out for me. Instead of making me take them dives for the short-end money.
Person2: I always had a bet down for you. You saw some money.
Person1: See! You don't understand!
Person2: I tried to keep you in good with Johnny.
Person1: You don't understand! I could've been a contender. I could've had class and been somebody. Real class. Instead of a bum, let's face it, which is what I am. It was you, Charley.

Person1: You're out of your mind, you know that!? You're messed up!?
Person2: Just drive.

Person1: Lex...Lex, how could you do that to Otis?
Person2: What else is ballast for?
Person2: How would you like to take a little vacation? I mean you've earned it, you know? You deserve it.
Person1: There is some good in you, Lex, after all.
Person2: You'll have to pack quickly.
Person1: A bikini! I'll need to buy a new bikini, Lex.  C'mon. After being cooped up in that prison, haven't you thought about me in a bikini . . ...once maybe ?
Person2: A parka.
Person1: You thought about me in a parka. That's sick, Lex. Really.
Person2: North!

Person1: You have to help me.  Please, Weaver. Think of all the things I've done for you!
Person2: I can't think of any.
Person1: Well I'm gonna start doing things for you...
Person2: Will you introduce me to some worker girls?
Person1: You bet!  They'll really go for a sensitive guy like you!
Person2: Maybe I'll get lucky.  You know, Z, I wouldn't do this for anyone but you...

Person1: Great. That was our last option. What am I going to do with you?
Person2: Nothing. Thanks for bringing me this far.
Person1: Where are you going? You'll freeze out there. You don't even have a coat.
Person2: I'll manage.
Person1: No, you won't. You'll die of cold out there and then I'll have to feel guilty. And I've already got more guilt than I know what to do with. Do you want something to drink?
Person2: No, I'm ok.

Person1: What about Elliot Harmsway? Or is this just another one of your stunts?
Person2: No! He's crazy - he's insane. He hates everybody. He's got these plans -  You've got to help me, James. I'm sorry. I'm sorry for everything. I know I was wrong - but you've got to protect me. I know you still love -

Person1: Good for you. Why shouldnt you protect whats yours.
Person2: I dont think youre hearing me.
Person1: Oh, Im hearing you, Alan. Thats not the problem. The problem is that what you think is yours, is really mine.  And I dont care how low on the totem pole I start, I will get it back...  So do yourself a favor and dont get too attached to that view because sometime soon, maybe very soon, you and your French country antiques, your chintz sofa, and your little play pen are gonna be moving out of that office.

Person1: Captain... We're waiting. What's the delay?
Person2: All is well, sir. You have the coordinates to beam up Genesis...
Person1: First things first, Captain. Kill Admiral Kirk.

Person1: There's this poem by Rilke, I don't remember the whole thing, but it's about that.  About waiting for that person, and wondering if you'll ever find them.  And the last line of it goes, "Who knows?  Perhaps the same bird echoed through both of us, yesterday--
Person2: --separate, in the evening..."
Person1: Yes.

Person1: Why, you don't want us to bring him over?
Person2: No, it's that when do you have time to be parents to him? You guys don't pick him up until nine, ten at night. You are into yourselves, as the saying goes. Spend some time trying to be parents. Take him to the mountains, fishing. You ought to let him get to know nature.
Person1: Well, you are his grandfather. He is supposed to spend some time with you. You're supposed to show him those woodsy things and this and that.
Person2: Junior spends time with his child.
Person1: Oh here we go with that.

Person1: Father!
Person2: Neil, you are going to quit this ridiculous play immediately.
Person1: Father, I--

Person1: Yes?
Person2: Is that the Ransom file? Thanks. Don't wear that outfit again.
Person1: Ummm...what? I didn't hear you.
Person2: I said "Do not wear that outfit again." Wear a dress. A skirt or something.

Person1: What are you doing out there? Are you crazy?
Person2: There's been a bad accident.
Person1: In English, Enrique. We're in the United States--
Person2: I have some friends who have had a accident--
Person1: You have somebody else out there?
Person2: We was by the river? And I hear my friend callin' for help, and I look and she has falling in the water--
Person1: Don't tell me lies, Enrique. Que paso?
Person2: We was crossin' the river--

Person1: You kiddin? Who else would hack through South Bronx or Harlem at night?
Person2: You want to work uptown nights?
Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: How's your driving record?
Person1: Clean. Real clean.  As clean as my conscience.
Person2: Listen, son, you gonna get smart, you can leave right now.
Person1: Sorry, sir. I didn't mean that.
Person2: Physical? Criminal?
Person1: Also clean.
Person2: Age?
Person1: Twenty-six.
Person2: Education?
Person1: Some. Here and there.
Person2: Military record?
Person1: Honorable discharge. May 1971.
Person2: You moonlightin?
Person1: No, I want long shifts.
Person2: We hire a lot of moonlighters here.
Person1: So I hear.
Person2: Hell, we ain't that much fussy anyway. There's always opening on one fleet or another.  Fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk, and leave your phone number. You gotta phone?
Person1: No.
Person2: Well then check back tomorrow.
Person1: Yes, Sir.

Person1: Something wrong?
Person2: Are you having an affair?
Person1: Goodness, where'd that come from? I have a late lunch by myself, and now I'm involved with somebody?
Person2: Well, are you?
Person1: No, I'm not. Frankly, I'm offended at the accusation.
Person2: If I'm right, I want to know. I don't want you to lie. I'd be very upset, but not as upset as if I'd found out you'd been lying.
Person1: There's nothing to know, Ann.
Person2: I can't tell you how upset I would be if you were lying.
Person1: Ann, you are completely paranoid. Not ten minutes ago I wanted to make love for the first time in weeks, and you act like I'm dipped in shit. You know, I think there are a lot of women that would be glad to have a young, straight male making a pretty good living beside them in bed with a hard on.
Person2: My sister, for one. Is that who it is?
Person1: For God's sake, Ann, I am not in a relationship with your sister. I don't find her that attractive, for one.
Person2: Is that supposed to comfort me?
Person1: I was just saying, you know? I didn't get paranoid when you didn't want to make love. I could have easily assumed that you didn't want to because you were having an affair.
Person2: But I'm not.
Person1: I'm not either!!
Person2: Why don't I believe you?
Person1: Look, this conversation is utterly ridiculous. Maybe when you have some evidence, we should talk, but don't give me conjecture and intuition.
Person2: Always the lawyer.
Person1: Goddam right. I mean, can you imagine: "Your honor, I'm positive this man is guilty. I can't place him at the scene or establish a motive, but I have this really strong feeling."
Person2: You've made your point.
Person1: I'm sorry. It's just... I'm under a lot of pressure with this Kirkland thing, it's my first big case as junior partner, and I work all day, I come home, I look forward to seeing you, and... it hurts that you accuse me like that.

Person1: Why did you go behind my back and discuss my project with the manager?
Person2: I felt there were some issues that needed to be addressed.
Person1: You should have come to me first. Now I look bad in front of the whole team.
Person2: I’m really just trying to help you. I thought bringing it up with the manager would expedite a solution.
Person1: In the future, please talk to me directly. We can handle things together.

Person1: Yeah?  Like what?  Limos?
Person2: I told you I don't like to talk about it.
Person1: Well, this big stake's got to be big by now.  When you leaving?
Person2: See, I've got bills.  My mother's been dying of the same disease since I was a kid.
Person1: What, no insurance?
Person2: Doesn't cover everything.
Person1: Good excuse.  How many others you got?

Person1: And I couldn't follow her.  God knows I tried.  One doesn't often get a second chance. I want to stop being haunted. You're my second chances, Judy.
Person2: Take me away...
Person1: You look like Madeleine, now. Go up the stairs.
Person2: No!
Person1: Go up the stairs, Judy.  I'll follow.

Person1: Don't tell me you really are in love?
Person2: Yeah and I got the bruises to prove it. So what?
Person1: Nothing, it's just that's when things usually start to go wrong.

Person1: You must think I'm some kind of fool.
Person2: It looks delicious.
Person1: You hear me talkin' to you.  The only time you come up here when something is wrong.
Person2: C'mon, Mommy, don't start with that I'm an ungrateful son stuff.
Person1: I said no such thing.  All I said is that something must be wrong.

Person1: Dad, maybe I shouldn't go with all that's happening to you.
Person2: You're going.
Person1: But listen, if I had a friend in the same position, I would tell her to delay a year.
Person2: You're going.
Person1: It doesn't feel right to me.  I, I don't even have the right luggage yet.
Person2: Bon voyage.
Person1: You're not listening to me.
Person2: Diane!  Alright, let's stop this right now.  Let's not put our energy into something ridiculous.  This isn't even smart thinking.
Person1: Dad, why are you acting this way?  Is this because of the other morning?

Person1: I don't want to hit you in the stomach!
Person2: You're not gonna hurt me. Just hit me in the stomach.
Person1: Look, Marty, I'm just not a fighter...

Person1: Cole and Munoz?  I been on this case for two years.
Person2: That's the point, isn't it?
Person1: Yeah, I get it.  Time to play let's dick the old guys, huh, Harp?
Person2: Supervising Special Agent, Harp. Now I want you to go work the drop car, okay, Angelo?  Okay?

Person1: No secrets, goddammit!  You don't hold back from me.  Whatever is going on, you're gonna tell me now!
Person2: No.  I cannot involve you.  This is not your concern.
Person1: The hell it isn't, when somebody wires up enough C-4 explosive to my car to turn me into pink mist!  That Slag was on something, and not sour milk, either?  Am I right?  TELL ME!  What is it?
Person2: ... It is called ss'jabroka'.  To us it is a potent narcotic.
Person1: How potent?
Person2: Like your cocaine, I suppose.  The "high" lasts several hours.  We would receive small amounts of it... as a reward for our labor.
Person1: We?  You've taken it?
Person2: We all did.
Person1: Where did he get it?  Was there any of it on the ship?
Person2: No... I am sure not.  That is why I am so concerned... someone must now be producing it here.  But none of my people know how to make it.  The process was carefully guarded.
Person1: Jesus, this is major.  Why didn't you tell me sooner? Why'd you hold out on me?
Person2: Your people don't know about this part of out past.  And they can't know -- It would threaten our entire existence here.

Person1: I love this.  We're onto something really big.  I can smell it, Ray.  We're going to make some headlines with this one.
Person2: Hey, hey, hey, stresshound!  Are you nuts? If anybody found out about this we'd be in serious trouble.  The judge couldn't have been clearer - no ghostbusting.
Person1: Relax.  We're going to keep this whole thing nice and quiet, low key, no profile.

Person1: Hello, Spooky.
Person2: I don't want to hurt you, Catwoman. Yet.  After tomorrow, you can do anything you want, but please, just stay out of sight for the next 24 hours. I won't stand by and watch my leader get all emotional over an animal like you. I warn you, don't tempt Captain God when he is angry. Let is complete our mission in peace.
Person1: Whatever you say...Sis.

Person1: More endearments.
Person2: I like you, DIl
Person1: Love me.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Tell me you love me.
Person2: Whatever you say, Dil.
Person1: Then say it.
Person2: Love you, Dil.
Person1: You do?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: What would you do for me?
Person2: Anything.

Person1: --- and I have heard you from the beginning... from it's very first beat.
Person2: I love Michael...
Person1: Then help me--- for his sake...

Person1: Well, honey, I don't guess I give a shit. I ain't here half the time anyway. If you want a retard livin' in the garage, I don't guess I care. I've got a good tool box and socket set out there I don't want stol'd. I guess I could take it home with me.
Person2: He's real honest. He wouldn't steal nothin'.
Person1: Now son, I wadn't talkin' to you, was I?  Was I?
Person2: No sir.
Person1: No sir's right. I'm talkin' to your mama. This is your mama's decision, not yours. I'm lettin' it go on because she asked me, not you.  Now is this the kind of retard that drools and rubs shit in his hair and all that, 'cause I have trouble eatin' around that kind of thing. Just like I am about antique furniture and midgets. I can't so much as drink a glass of water around a midget or a piece of antique furniture. Same thing with a droolin' retard.

Person1: Wait -- what're you doing?
Person2: I'm going down.
Person1: Down? Down there?! Are you crazy!
Person2: I'm not leaving without those stones.
Person1: You're gonna get killed chasing after your damn fortune and glory!
Person2: Maybe... someday.  Not today.

Person1: I don't know where you get that idea -- the Board agreed --
Person2: The Board didn't know you're a mole who burrowed inside so you could bury us all.
Person1: Is this Mr. Black's fantasy?  Another one of his whoppers?  Aren't you sick of this asshole lurking around? No one knows who he is, but one thing everyone does know, he somehow got your ear and has been pouring poison into it ever since.

Person1: What'd I tell you? Huh, Vinny? What'd I tell you when you came to me for money? Didn't I ask you not to do it? Did I not say that?  What'd I say to him?
Person2: You said don't do it, boss.
Person1: That's right. I said don't do it. Did you listen to me? No. You wanted the money. So, I lent you twenty large. Now it's been three weeks and you ain't paid a dime. What do you think that makes me look like on the street? I don't do something to you and everyone will think they can skate.

Person1: Look, we have to get these...
Person2: I can't afford stuff like this right now.
Person1: I'm sick of waiting - we need to start getting stuff if we're ever going to move.  Aren't these the greatest towels?
Person2: Why do you care about this kind of stuff?
Person1: Don't you want nice stuff?
Person2: I can't imagine spending money on towels.
Person1: You don't have to. I'll pay for all the stuff right now and you can pay me back when you finally get a job.
Person2: You're insane.
Person1: Do you still want to go to that thing tonight?
Person2: What thing?
Person1: That guy's band is playing tonight... Alien Autopsy.
Person2: Oh yeah... maybe... Seymour's going on his big date tonight and I kind of want to be around when he calls, so I can hear how bad it went.
Person1: God, I'm so sick of Seymour.

Person1: Let him out of here, Lieutenant.
Person2: But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.
Person1: And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?
Person2: Now, Hildy --
Person1: Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?
Person2: I can't.
Person1: All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!
Person2: Now, Hildy, don't be hasty! I can't let him out.
Person1: You can let him out on bail, can't you?
Person2: Five hundred dollars.
Person1: You'll take fifty and like it!
Person2: Well, all right. But I'm liable to get into a jam.

Person1: Let me just ask you a serious question first.
Person2: What?
Person1: Aren't you worried you could die a virgin?
Person2: Yeah. I'm extremely worried about that. It's right up there with global warming.
Person1: On our way home, a drunken driver could hit us head on and send us flying through the windshield. Terminate us instantly. We'd never experience what it means to make love.
Person2: If sheep don't count.
Person1: That wasn't me ...
Person2: I know. I'm kidding you. Chill out.
Person1: Well I'm trying to be real here and you're mocking me.
Person2: I'm sorry, but you're not going to die a virgin Rod.

Person1: HARRY! I found the treasure!
Person2: Go away, assface.
Person1: Did you hear what I said? The treasure! Like on your map!
Person2: Yeah, right. Why don't you show it to your "girlfriend"?
Person1: JESSICA and I are through. I couldn't stand being with her knowing you liked her. It wasn't worth our friendship. Oh, and she also has a boyfriend.
Person2: Do you hear something, Captain Rob?
Person1: Captain Rob came back?
Person2: Yeah, he does sound like a rat fink.
Person1: Hey, there's no reason to use that kind of language!
Person2: Good one, Captain Rob. He does look like a you-know-what.
Person1: Oh, telling inside jokes now, are we? That's it. You're out of the cool crowd. Next time Turk's passing out wedgies, you ain't gettin' one.

Person1: You know.  If we hook up, tomorrow I'll just be some girl you go telling all your friends about.
Person2: No way.

Person1: There's only one person in the world to decide what I'm going to do - and that's me.  And if you think - if any of you think -
Person2: You decided what you were going to do, Charles - some time ago.  You can't always have it your own way, regardless of anything else that may have happened.  Come on, Charles.
Person1: Go on!  Get out!  I can fight this thing all alone!

Person1: But -- if you're a User -- then everything you've done has been part of a plan ...
Person2: You wish. Man, I haven't had a second to think since I got down here. I mean in here. Out here. Whatever.
Person1: Then...
Person2: Look, you guys know how it is. You just keep doin' what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, and you hope to hell your User knows what's goin' on.
Person1: Well -- that's how it is for programs, yes, but --
Person2: I hate to disappoint you, pal, most-the time, that's how it is for Users, too.
Person1: Stranger and stranger...

Person1: I'm sorry, ma'am, there are no pets allowed in the library...
Person2: But I'm blind.
Person1: It's seeing-eye dogs, ma'am. If I let the cat stay, will you go out with me?
Person2: What if I say I'll go out with you, so you can have all these great daydreams, but then never actually talk to you again?
Person1: Okay, deal.
Person2: "I'll go out with you." Now go get me these old newspapers...

Person1: Remember when you promised you'd help me with the project and then bailed?
Person2: Oh, that? Let’s forgive and forget. We should focus on the present.
Person1: It's hard to forget when I had to pull an all-nighter because of that.
Person2: Always holding onto the past, aren't you?
Person1: It's about accountability and trust.
Person2: And it's about not holding grudges. We should move on.

Person1: I don't know you.
Person2: Ahhh, but I know you.
Person1: How?
Person2: We met in court.
Person1: We never met in court or anyplace else.
Person2: That's true. I'll rephrase it. I saw you in court.
Person1: When?
Person2: Do you remember one of your practical jokes that resulted in the smashing of a plate glass window?
Person1: I didn't break that window!
Person2: No, but your little prank did. The judge should have put you behind bars!
Person1: What are you? A policeman?
Person2: I simply believe in the law, Miss Daniels, and I'm not too keen on practical jokers.
Person1: What do you call your lovebird story if not a practical...
Person2: Ahhh, but I really do want those birds.
Person1: You knew I didn't work here. You deliberately...
Person2: Right. I recognized you when I came in. I thought you might like to know what it felt like to be on the other end of a gag. What do you think of that, Miss Daniels?
Person1: I think you're a louse.
Person2: I am.  Good day.  Madam.
Person1: And I'm glad you didn't get your lovebirds!
Person2: I'll find something else.  See you in court some day.

Person1: See, I can't do it. I came out of the desert.
Person2: You came out of the hospital. You were tied down and hallucinating. You got some bad chemicals in your head, Noel. There's some medicine at the hospital that will fix that.
Person1: No, no medicine!

Person1: Now...now, I'm sorry...don't - don't....please.  It's just... I was happy.  Why get me involved? You told SEN that you weren't satisfied with me.
Person2: What?...Oh, no, THX.  That's not true.  Not satisfied?  THX, I need you so much.

Person1: It was dead.
Person2: It was alive wasn't it?
Person1: I don't remember.

Person1: I didn't mean to hurt you.
Person2: Shhhhhh. Now I have your disease.
Person1: You what?
Person2: You put your disease in me. Your semen. It's hot and full of disease.
Person1: There's no disease, I can tell you.
Person2: Men are crazy. Then they put their craziness into me. Then it makes me crazy. Then they aren't so crazy for awhile. Then they put their craziness in me again.  It's burning me, but I love you. I do, I do. Did you know that? Did you know that I love you?
Person1: I'm glad you do.
Person2: There's so much I want to tell you. I'm in so much darkness though with things moving. There is darkness sucking me. It's kissing me and darkness is entering me. In every hole. It's opening me to a death.
Person1: Dorothy. No!
Person2: If I die, then they'll be free. It's getting late, isn't it? I can tell, it's a cold feeling when it's late. It's warm then it gets cold. Jeffrey. I feel it getting cold.
Person1: You called me Jeffrey.
Person2: I did. Are you?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Why are you here?  HMMMMMMMM!!!! OK.
Person1: No. Not really.  But also because I really want you to be alright.

Person1: I tell you - this is the only way to travel.
Person2: You better put on the lights. I can't see what I'm doing.
Person1: No - no lights.  We don't want anyone to know we're having a party.
Person2: I may spill something.
Person1: So spill it.  Spills, thrills, laughs, games - this may even turn out to be a surprise party.
Person2: What's the surprise?
Person1: Uh-uh.  Not yet.
Person2: When?
Person1: We better have a drink first.
Person2: Here.  This'll put hair on your chest.
Person1: No fair guessing.

Person1: You know this guy, don't you?
Person2: I've never seen him before in my life. I'm just trying to help you out.
Person1: By stealing my car?
Person2: I would've come back for you.
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: Yeah.

Person1: That's no batlight, it's a birdcall.
Person2: Her name is Pamela Isley.  I saw her talking to Gordon.  She must have stolen his keys, altered the signal-
Person1: And she did it all for me.  For love.
Person2: She's infected us with some kind of pheromone extract-
Person1: Is that it, Bruce?  I'm under some magic spell?
Person2: She wants to kill you.
Person1: You'd say anything to keep me away from her.  To keep her for yourself.
Person2: You once said to me that being part of a team means trusting your partner.  That sometimes counting on someone else is the only way to win.  DO you remember?

Person1: So, you still picking apart cockroaches?
Person2: No, I'm into earthworms now. You wouldn't be interested. They're real "boring" creatures. Very reliable, dependable, no surprises...
Person1: You're still mad at me, aren't you?
Person2: You just left me without a phone call, a letter, nothing. All this time. Yeah, I guess I'm still a little mad.
Person1: That was eight years ago. Some people change, you know.
Person2: Most people don't.
Person1: I'm sorry you feel that way.

Person1: You didn't get any, did you?  You're a homo.
Person2: Just stop, okay? Make something up, and that's what happened. Whatever you want. Write my confession, and I'll sign it. Just stop pushing me all the time! I can't take it! You're an infant! This is all a big party for you, but not for me! This is serious. And you -- Just... leave me alone, okay? You're messing me up.
Person1: Wow. Okay. Calm down. Sorry.

Person1: Are you afraid of his reaction? Of his finding you silly for thinking of such things?
Person2: No. I don't know. I haven't told him about the garbage thing because I'm pissed off at him right now. He's letting some old college buddy stay at our house for a couple of days, and he didn't even ask me about it. I mean, I would've said yes, I just wish he would've asked.
Person1: What upsets you about that?
Person2: I guess I'm upset because I can't really justify being upset, I mean, it's his house, really, he pays the mortgage.
Person1: But he asked you to quit your job, and you do have housework.
Person2: Yeah, I know.
Person1: This unexpected visit notwithstanding, how are things with John?
Person2: Fine, I guess. Except right now I'm going through this where I don't want him to touch me.

Person1: Dont do that...
Person2: Look, youre making this into something its not. This isnt a referendum on our lives, Kate. Its a step forward...  Dont you see?  Im talking about us finally having a life other people envy.

Person1: When are you coming home?
Person2: As soon as I can walk.
Person1: Something wrong with your legs?
Person2: No -- it's my stomach.
Person1: Your stomach?
Person2: They had to pump it out.
Person1: Miss Kubelik, I don't think you ought to call anybody -- not till that chewing gum is out of your head.

Person1: Youre right. I was so desperate to make everyone believe I was happy that I spent six grand on a lie. And after all that? The only one who ended up falling for it was me.
Person2: Go ahead, Kat. Hate me. You were running out of steam on the whole Jeffrey thing. Maybe now youll be able to hold onto this just long enough to ruin your next relationship.

Person1: Okay.   Okay.    I believe you.
Person2: You killed her!
Person1: No. You killed her. Manager remembers you going into her room. Your fingerprints were found all over the place.
Person2: Bullshit! She was alive when we left her with you.
Person1: You're in trouble, Sami. You know it.   That's why you're here.
Person2: Look, I just want out of this nightmare. I don't know these guys. A few days ago I'm in Paris picking pockets and now I'm America's most wanted.
Person1: Where are the tapes?
Person2: I can get them -- but what do I get if I do?
Person1: A pass.
Person2: A pass? How you gonna give me a pass? A witness can put me at the crime scene.
Person1: Witness' can be convinced they made a mistake. Without the murder weapon the D.A. won't have enough to prosecute you.
Person2: They don't have a murder weapon?
Person1: No. I have it. The lamp? The one with your fingerprints and her blood on it?  Remember?

Person1: What are you, crazy?
Person2: I just thought we should talk about it.  Between ourselves.
Person1: What's there to talk about?  She can sing. That puts her at the head of the class. That makes her the only one in the class.
Person2: I don't know ... She had gum on her lip, for Christ sake. I don't think she's right for the act.
Person1: You're getting cold feet about this.
Person2: I was just thinking what Ma would think.
Person1: Ma? Ma?  Was Ma there the last time we played the Ambassador?  Oh, that's right, she was on bass. How could I forget.

Person1: Well, wait now.  I still have to ask Darryl if I can go.
Person2: You mean you haven't asked him yet? For Christ sake, Thelma, is he your husband or your father?  It's just two days.  For God's sake, Thelma. Don't be a child.  Just tell him you're goin' with me, for cryin' out loud.  Tell him I'm havin' a nervous breakdown.

Person1: Are you crazy, Ray?
Person2: You heard Kelly say "Sam."  That was Lombardo on the phone.  And you saw the girls...
Person1: Ray.  The conversation on this tape is totally unintelligible.  What we have here, is you on the Van Ryan property, without a proper warrant, shooting a porn flick...
Person2: I don't believe I'm hearing this.  A month ago you were pulling these two apart at the courthouse.  They were acting.  They were all acting, from the beginning.  And we bought it, hook, line and sinker... And now they're home free with six million of Sandra Van Ryan's money.

Person1: Listen to me.  You have to consider the possibility that God doesn't like you, he never wanted you.  In all probability, He hates you.  This is not the worst thing that can happen...
Person2: It isn't... ?
Person1: We don't need him...
Person2: We don't... ?

Person1: Hiya Allan.
Person2: Dude, I finally got the venue I wanted.  I'm Performing my dance quintet--you know, my cycle--at Crane Jackson's Fountain Street Theatre on Tuesday night, and I'd love it if you came and gave me notes.

Person1: This is your problem, right here. This girl's driving you insane, Ethan. Let me help you.
Person2: I don't want your help.
Person1: Come back to my house. My car's outside.

Person1: So...you never did tell me...what made you come out to the worker bar that night?
Person2: Just looking for fun, adventure, trouble, I guess.
Person1: Well, "trouble" is my middle name. Actually, my  middle name is .985, but I don't tell people.  Hey, Bala, I...I actually have something of yours...you left it at the bar that night.

Person1: It's pretty embarrassing. I really don't know what to tell Mr. Robinson. It's awkward and strained for me every time he suggests that you call up Elaine.
Person2: Next time he suggests it, I'll tell him I have no intention of ever calling her up in my life.

Person1: Hello?
Person2: Hey. What are you doing? How are you?
Person1: I'm fine. Who is this?
Person2: Georgia.
Person1: Hi....what....what's up....?
Person2: It's ok that I'm calling, right, I mean? It's ok.
Person1: Yeah. No. It's ok. What's goin' on?
Person2: I just wanted to call and talk to you, thank you for last night, try and get you before you went to work and say, "hey."
Person1: I'm going to work.
Person2: Uhhh...I am sooo tired...I stayed up too late last night, what about you, when did you go to sleep?
Person1: Not very late.
Person2: You're going to work now?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Can I ask you a question?
Person1: Uh-huh.
Person2: Remember last night I was talking to you and I was telling you about my apartment, my rent -- ?  Do you remember?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: This is really weird and really embarrassing for me but....uh....  I was wondering if you could help me out with a little bit of money.
Person1: Me?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: I can't really. Yeah, no. I mean. I can't afford it.
Person2: You don't even know how much it is.
Person1: I know but I....how much is it?
Person2: Like seven-fifty. Seven hundred fifty?
Person1: Yes, no, yes. I can't. I can't afford that. I'm sorry. Sorry.
Person2: Really? Please?
Person1: You have trouble, financial trouble?
Person2: Yeah. It's so hard these days and I really need it.
Person1: Yes I can't....I don't make enough money to be able to do that.
Person2: I thought you had your own business. You said you were gonna diversify and all that stuff....

Person1: What's going to happen to Stensland?  He'll give himself cirrhosis over this.  He's one year from his pension.
Person2: It would've happened years ago if you hadn't carried him.  Why the loyalty, Wendell?
Person1: He helped me out once.  That's all.
Person2: Your partner's through. Department scapegoat on the Chief's orders.  He's been billed, he'll be indicted and he'll swing.
Person1: Him and me both.  Damn Exley.
Person2: Don't underestimate his skills. As a politician he exceeds even myself.  But the department needs smart men like Exley and... direct men like yourself
Person1: What do you want?
Person2: Wendell, I want you to come to work for me.
Person1: Doing what?  Mowing your lawn?

Person1: You'll never have another chance to hit me again.  I never knew till this minute -
Person2: Susan, it seems to me -
Person1: Don't tell me you're sorry.
Person2: I'm not sorry.
Person1: I'm going to leave you.
Person2: No, you're not.
Person1: Yes.

Person1: Why?
Person2: Don't it matter none he's makin' ya out a fool? -- I'd break his lips.
Person1: It don't matter.
Person2: He's takin' cheap shots.
Person1: It don't bother me none.
Person2: Yo, Rock -- now ya'll be lookin' for people to help, right?
Person1: Help what?
Person2: Y'know, to help keep ya livin' clean.
Person1: I'll do okay.
Person2: Ya gotta have a guy help ya exercise, mebbe somebody to be standin' by with a towel or run errands, y'know.
Person1: Hey, who cared about me yesterday, huh? Nobody -- I think I'm gonna train myself.
Person2: Without havin' good people around, ya won't have such a good chance.

Person1: Come now, Sam.  This is a gathering of old friends.  I know how difficult this must be for you -- a man of your upbringing and integrity -- but now that I'm in charge I felt it was only fair that you finally know the truth.  After all, you're the only one around here who's still in the dark, as it were.  This isn't the way I wanted to tell you, but you've really given me no other choice.
Person2: This is madness, Wynn.
Person1: Your madness is another man's greatness.  This is the way things have always been.  You've just been too blinded by your own reality to see.  But having you on the outside has been convenient for us in many ways.  You always did come through -- our loyal watch dog. Finding him. Bringing him back to us once he'd finished his work.  Although after you had that nasty stroke the last time, I had to go after him myself.  And what a terrible time we had getting him out of that jail cell.
Person2: It was you.
Person1: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar.
Person2: Why did you take Jamie?
Person1: She has the gift -- the blood of Thorn running through her veins.  Michael's mother had it, too.  So for six years I incubated her, prepared her for this night.  Michael has served his purpose.  And soon we will have a new progeny.
Person2: Jamie's baby ...
Person1: There you go trying to make sense again.  It's a curse.  Handed down through countless generations. As ageless as this celebration which you call Halloween.
Person2: Samhain.
Person1: And I'm its deliverer.  Its calling card, if you will.  I follow it.  Protect it. Act as its guardian.  In a sense, Sam, so do you.

Person1: The police came to me for help.  What could I do?
Person2: You could have been honest with me for starters.  We work together.  I have to be able to trust you.
Person1: I admit I handled it badly.  Sanderson wasn't going to talk to me... but you're young, attractive--
Person2: --the same type as the girl who got killed.  Jesus, Alan, the guy could be a psychopath.

Person1: Tell us, Jeanne... why did you jump from the tower at Beaurevoir?
Person2: I had been sold to the English.  I'd rather die than fall into their hands.
Person1: Did your voice tell you to jump?
Person2: No...
Person1: So when you jumped, you wanted to kill yourself?
Person2: No...!
Person1: How can you deny it when you just said "I'd rather die than fall into the hands of the English"...?
Person2: That's now what I meant...
Person1: Do you not know that suicide is a very grievous sin?  No one is allowed to destroy the life that God created!
Person2: I know, but that's not the way things happened...
Person1: You mean it was not of your own free will that you were on the ledge?
Person2: Yes, but...
Person1: And you didn't jump of your free will?
Person2: No!
Person1: Oh?  Perhaps someone pushed you then?

Person1: Chopin prelude.  Stodgy, but nice.  Here's the deal.  I didn't want you involved in this.  Still breathing? But now that you are, we have to make the best of it, Max.  Improvise.  Life is that way.  Adapt to your environment.  Survive.  Darwin.  "Shit happens."  The I Ching.  Whatever. Roll with it.
Person2: I Ching?  You threw a man out a window!
Person1: I didn't throw him, he fell.
Person2: What'd he do to you?
Person1: Nothing.  I only met him the one time.
Person2: How can you kill him like that?
Person1: I should only kill people after I get to know 'em?  Six billion people on the planet, you're getting bent out of shape 'cause of one fat guy?
Person2: Who was he?
Person1: What do you care?  Ever hear of Rwanda?
Person2: Rwanda-Burundi.  Central Africa.
Person1: Tens of thousands killed before sundown.  Nobody's killed that fast since Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  Did you bat an eye, Max?  Join Amnesty International?  No.  I off one Angeleno, you throw a hissy fit...

Person1: Go fuck yourself...

Person1: Why do you feel that Truman's never come close to discovering the true nature of his world?
Person2: We accept the reality of the world with which we're presented.  As the show expanded, naturally we were forced to manufacture ways to keep Truman in Seahaven - demonstrating that every venture is accompanied by a risk.

Person1: Hey, Ram ... what were you ... you know, before?
Person2: Oh, I was an actuarial program... worked at a big insurance company. It really gives you a great feeling, helping folks plan for their future needs -- and of course, if you look at the payments as an annuity, over the years, the cost is really

Person1: It's fun!  It's high.
Person2: Or the sexual habits of locusts?
Person1: That was very interesting research George was doing!
Person2: What kind of Dead Head gets a temporary tattoo?
Person1: I already explained about that.
Person2: And where you ever really going to run the leper colony in Molokai?
Person1: Brian told you that?
Person2: Or maybe you just wanted to wear the headdress.
Person1: Every one of those times I was being supportive.  Something you won't understand.
Person2: Supportive?  You weren't being supportive.  You were being scared. Just like now.  You are the most lost woman I have ever laid eyes on.
Person1: Lost!
Person2: That's right.  You're so lost you don't even know how you like your eggs.
Person1: What!?
Person2: With the priest, you liked them scrambled.  With the Dead Head, fried. With the bug guy, poached.  Now it's egg whites only, thank you very much.
Person1: That's called changing your mind.
Person2: No, that's called not having a mind of your own.  What are you doing, Maggie? You really want to let that man drag you up Annapuma on your honeymoon?  You don't want to climb Annapuma.
Person1: Yes I do!
Person2: No you don't.  You want a man who will lead you down the beach with his head over your eyes just so you can discover the feel of the sand under your feet. You want a guy who will take you into a cave with a thousand candles just to read you a poem.  You want a man to wake you up at dawn because he's burning to talk to you and he can't wait another minute to find out what you'll say.  Am I right?

Person1: Lauren Murphy is now a wanted felon in the state of Washington. Forgery, Embezzlement, two drug convictions, plus she jumped parole. When she's arrested, she will not have a trial, she will not pass go, she will go directly to jail. Then I change this file back to the original, and your mom disappears.
Person2: That's bullshit.
Person1: What can I tell you. Computers never lie, kid. Your mom will be arrested at work, she'll be handcuffed, and later, strip searched.
Person2: You lay a finger on her and I'll kill you.
Person1: Kid, don't threaten me. There are worse things than death and, uh, I can do all of them!

Person1: Yes.  That's true.  Actually, at this point, I just want A job.  Wait. What do you mean... yet?
Person2: It means I know you think you got a beat on things.  But trust me, you don't.  You don't even have an inkling of a hint of a clue as to what's really going on in the world.    And if you want to find out even a little, you'll shut up and come with me. And if you don't, fine.  Go with them. Cause I'm not interested in breaking in another little hot-shot only to have him wig or die on me just when I'm starting to count on him.  So forgive me if you don't exactly hear me ringing little bells and whistling welcome aboard, but this isn't the Love Boat.  And I'm not Captain Stubing.  Now I'm sorry.  But this has been one long, bad day.

Person1: Look, old man, you stay out of this. We spend a fortune on you, more than we can possibly afford, and all you do is criticize, morning to night. And then you think you can -
Person2: Stanzi!
Person1: No, it's right he should hear. I'm sick to death of it. We can't do anything right for you, can we?

Person1: Do you mind if I smoke, Mr. Garrison?
Person2: How could I?  Dave, as you know, President Kennedy was assassinated on Friday.  A man named Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested as a suspect and then was murdered yesterday by a man named Jack Ruby.  We've heard reports that Oswald spent the summer in New Orleans and we've been advised you knew Oswald pretty well.
Person1: That's not true.  I never met anybody named Oswald.  Anybody who told you that has to be crazy.
Person2: But you are aware, he served in your Civil Air Patrol unit when he was a teenager.
Person1: No... if he did, I don't remember him.  There were lots of kids in and out... y'know.
Person2: I'm sure you've seen this.  Perhaps you knew this man under another name?
Person1: No, I never saw him before in my life.
Person2: Well that must've been mistaken information we got.  Thanks for straightening it out for us.  There is one other matter that's come up, Dave.  We were told you took a trip to Texas shortly after the assassination of Friday.
Person1: Yeah, now that's true.  I drove to Houston.
Person2: What was so appealing about Houston?
Person1: I hadn't been there ice skating in many years, and I had a couple of young friends with me, and we decided we wanted to go ice skating.
Person2: Dave, may I ask why the urge to go ice skating in Texas happened to strike you during one of the most violent thunderstorms in recent memory?
Person1: Oh, it was just a spur of the moment thing...  the storm wasn't that bad.
Person2: I see.  And where did you drive?
Person1: We went straight to Houston, and then Saturday night we drove to Galveston and stayed over there.
Person2: Why Galveston?
Person1: No particular reason.  Just to go somewhere.
Person2: And then Sunday?
Person1: In the morning we went goose hunting. Then headed home, but I dropped the boys off to see some relatives and I stayed in Hammond.
Person2: Did you bag any geese on this trip?
Person1: I believe the boys got a couple.
Person2: But the boys told us they didn't get any.
Person1: Oh yes, well, come to think of it, they're right.  We got to where the geese were and there were thousands of them.  But you couldn't approach them.  They were a wise bunch of birds.
Person2: Your young friends also told us you had no weapons in the car.  Dave, isn't it a bit difficult to hunt for geese without a shotgun?
Person1: Yes, now I remember, Mr. Garrison. I'm sorry, I got confused.  We got out there near the geese and it was only then we realized we'd forgotten our shotguns.  Stupid, right?  So of course we didn't get any geese.
Person2: I see.  Dave thank you for your time.  I'm sorry it has to end inconveniently for you, but I'm going to have you detained for further questioning by the FBI.
Person1: Why?  What's wrong?
Person2: Dave, I find your story simply not believable.

Person1: These new people never identified themselves.  They musta been watching the whole thing 'cause they knew everything Mary and me had been doing that day.  I guess I wasn't too hard to find - wearing that red raincoat.
Person2: How many shots you say you heard?
Person1: Four to six.
Person2: That's impossible.  You heard echoes ...echoes.  We have three bullets and three shots which came from the Book Depository and that's all we're willing to say.
Person1: ...which is strange 'cause this is less than 20 minutes after the assassination.
Person1: No, I saw a guy shooting from over there.  He was behind that fence. What are you going to do about it?
Person2: We have that taken care of.  You only heard three shots and you are not to talk to anyone about this. No one, you hear?
Person1: I was scared.  It was all kinda queer, but it sure felt like two and two was coming up three... and then they took Mary's five snapshots from me, sent them to Washington, and when they returned them weeks later, two of them had the backgrounds mutilated... The only one we saved was in Mary's camera.  I didn't want to go to Washington when the Warren Commission subpoenaed me... so the lawyer come down here and interviewed me at Parkland Hospital.

Person1: Shit, John!  What the hell were you doing out there?!
Person2: Nothing.
Person1: You're kidding with that answer, right?
Person2: I just went for a walk.  It's no big deal.
Person1: Wrong.  There are rules in this house and you're going to follow them whether you like it or not.
Person2: Or what?  You're gonna shoot me?
Person1: It's an option.
Person2: Well, maybe if you'd let me live in the dorms, I wouldn't have to sneak out to spend time with my friends.
Person1: Oh, so now it's my fault?
Person2: Just forget it...

Person1: I believe the marketing strategy you proposed is outdated. We should pivot to a more digital approach.

Person1: You know I don't need another person in this family making me feel like an idiot...your ex-wife's doing a bang up job and I have to face it every Tuesday and Thursday and every other goddamn weekend and I just don't know how the hell you were married to her for so goddamn long!  Jesus what did you see in her?  I don't get it -- I just don't get it.

Person1: Ann, in life one has to be aware of hidden agendas.  Did it occur to you that Graham may have his own reasons for not wanting you to be in therapy?
Person2: What do you mean? I don't understand.
Person1: It's possible that Graham has hidden motives for disliking therapy and/or therapists. Perhaps he has problems of his own that he is unwilling to deal with, and he would like to see other people, you for instance, wallow in their situation just as he does. Do you think that's possible?
Person2: I guess.
Person1: You understand that you are free to leave therapy at any time?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: That you are under no obligation to me?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Do you want to leave therapy?
Person2: Not really.
Person1: Do you feel there is more progress to be made?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: I'm glad you feel that way, because I feel that way, too.
Person2: But you don't have hidden motives for feeling that way, right?

Person1: Nothing.
Person2: Too late for what, Sheila?

Person1: I want you to help me take my revenge.
Person2: Michael, anything.  What is it I can do for you?
Person1: I want you to settle these troubles with the Rosato Brothers.
Person2: I was just going to contact you, Michael; we just had a 'sit-down' - in fact, I just come from there.
Person1: I want you to settle on their terms.
Person2: Mike, I don't understand.  Don't ask me to do that.
Person1: Trust me; do as I ask.
Person2: It would be the beginning of the end for my family.  How can I keep all my other territories in like if I let two wise-guys stand up and demand this and that, and then give it to them?
Person1: Frankie...do you respect me?  Do I have your loyalty?
Person2: Always... But sometimes I don't understand.  I know I'll never have your kind of brains, in big deals. But Mike, this is a street thing. And Hyman Roth in Miami is behind the Rosato Brothers.
Person1: I know.
Person2: Then why do you want me to lay down to them?
Person1: Frankie, Roth tried to have me killed.  I'm sure it was him, but I don't know yet why.
Person2: Jesus Christ, Michael, then let's hit 'em now, while we still got the muscle.
Person1: This was my father's old study. When I was a kid, we had to be quiet when we played near here. When I was older, I learned many things from him here.  I was happy that this house never went to strangers; first Clemenza took it over, and then you.  My father taught me, in this room, never to act until you know everything that's behind things.  Never.  If Hyman Roth sees that I interceded with you in the Rosato Brothers' favor, he'll think his relationship with me is still sound.  I'm going somewhere to meet him tomorrow.  We have friends in some very important business that we're making.  Do this for me; you make the peace with the Rosato Brothers on their terms.  Let the word out that I forced you; you're not happy wit hit, but acquiesced, just because of me.  It will get back to Hyman Roth.  Do this, Frankie.  You can trust me.
Person2: Sure, Mike.  I'll go along.
Person1: Good.

Like, say, both countries agreeing to a million dollar reward and international protection for anyone who gives evidence of cheating to the inspectors. You can't hide those things without a lot of people knowing about it.  And if I were going to try and hide a few, I wouldn't want to depend on the fact that some poor slob isn't going to run and blab for a million bucks.  We're as smart as they are, and if they cheat, or even hold back information, we'd pull right out.

Person1: ... So me and Sounder, ran right by the men that was the prisoners, and crawled under the fence! That's when I cut my hand on the glass. It hurt like mad! But I kept runnin', and then I didn't feel no more hurtin' till I stopped runnin'!  Why was that, Miss Johnson?

Person1: I miss him.  You know, sometimes I wake up in the morning, and I think 'I have to make Frank's breakfast,' and I... I get up and there's a... a very good reason for getting out of bed until... until, of course, I remember.  I miss talking to him.  Cathy's a child, you know, and Mitch...  ...Mitch has his own life.  I'm glad he stayed here today. I feel safer with him here.
Person2: Would you like to rest now, Mrs. Brenner.
Person1: No.  No... don't go yet.  I feel as if I... I don't understand you. And I want so much to understand.
Person2: Why, Mrs. Brenner?
Person1: Because my son is...  My son seems to be fond of you.  And I...  I'm not quite sure how I feel about it. I really don't know if I... like you or not.
Person2: Is that so important, Mrs. Brenner? You liking me?
Person1: Yes, I think so. My son is important to me. I want to like any girl he chooses.
Person2: And if you don't?
Person1: Then I don't suppose it'll matter much to anyone but me.
Person2: I think it might also matter to Mitch.
Person1: Mitch has always done exactly what he wanted to do.  I'm not complaining. That's the mark of a man.  But...  You see, I... I wouldn't want to be... be left alone. I don't think I could bear being left alone.  I... forgive me. This business with the birds has me upset.  I... I don't know what I'd do if Mitch weren't here.
Person2: Why don't you try to sleep now, Mrs. Brenner.
Person1: I wish I were stronger.  Do you think she's all right? Do you think she's safe at the school?
Person2: Would you like me to go for her?
Person1: I couldn't ask you to.
Person2: I don't mind, really.
Person1: Would you? I'd feel so much better.
Person2: I'll just clear up here, and then dress.

Person1: Zachory ! My boy, how goes the carnage down on 44 ?
Person2: Not that well sir. I believe we have a few too many soft hearts in the building. Did we aquire a bank from Chicago or a charity ?
Person1: Relax, son. They'll learn in time that you don't mess with First Bank. This is the real deal and we aim to keep it strong. My Daddy always told me that Only The Strong Survive.
Person2: I thought that was Darwin, sir. Or perhaps Nietzsche ?
Person1: Perhaps it was. I was in boarding school for so many years, it's hard to remember. Do you have the tape of the latest exploits from my favorite hobby ?
Person2: Yes sir, I do. Last night's, fresh from the Park.
Person1: I have to say, that I am glad you are such an amazing kiss ass.
Person2: Thank you , sir. Sir, may I ask you a question ?
Person1: Of course.
Person2: While I am not morally against these little, shall we say "hobbies", as long as I am on the payroll, but why not something like a yacht club ?
Person1: Zach, how old are you, son ?
Person2: I am thirty two.
Person1: And how much do we pay you annually ?
Person2: I make roughly four hundred thousand a year.
Person1: Zach my boy, I can spend your yearly salary in a blink. I have had that kind of money all of my life. If I wanted to, I could fly to Paris for the afternoon.  My father formed this company over seventy years ago. When my brother became mentally challenged, it was put in my charge. Now running a bank of this size is very stressful. I need to relax on what little down time I have. A yacht club will not quite make my blood pressure decline. Understand ?
Person2: Yes sir.
Person1: I have entrusted you with a great many things. In your tenure with this company you have seen and heard things that could upset the very economic world in which we live. I think this kind of loyalty should be rewarded.
Person2: Thank you, sir.

Person1: Okay, Karl, the reason I brought you here was to talk to you about something that is on my mind.  I guess I'll put it right out on the table. Where do I start. Linda and Frank are very important to me. They're like family. My own family was never like family. They're horrible people. As a matter of fact I prayed every night for years that my father would die. I finally realized through a lot of therapy that I was wasting my energy on hating him. Now I just don't care.  You see, you and I are a lot alike, strange as that may seem. I mean not physically or even mentally really, just well, maybe emotionally or actually the hand we've been dealt in life. We're different. People see us as being different anyway. You're -- well you have your affliction or whatever and I, well mine's not as easy to see. I'm just going to say it. I'm gay.  Does that surprise you?  That I'm gay. You know what being gay is, don't you?
Person2: I reckon not.
Person1: Homosexual. I like men. Sexually.
Person2: Not funny, ha, ha, funny queer.
Person1: Well that's a very offensive way to put it. You shouldn't say that. You were taught that, weren't you?
Person2: I've heard it said that way.
Person1: Anyway, it's hard to live gay, that's the right way to say it, in a small town like this. I've wanted to leave many times, but my love for Linda and Frank and another certain person that we won't go into have kept me from it. Anyway, I'm rambling. If you're going to live in the Wheatly garage you need to know that it won't be easy. Doyle is a monster. Not just a closed minded redneck, but a monster. A dangerous person. I've told Linda that one day that man is going to really hurt her or that boy. Maybe even kill one of them. I see it in his eyes. I'm very in tune, maybe even psychic. Doyle will make your life hell. You're a perfect target. When I first saw you I was afraid of you. Not really afraid, I guess, just taken aback. But also, I felt a real sensitive feeling from you. And for some reason, Frank has adopted you. Much like a stray animal. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it like that. In a good way. Anyway, I just want you to know what you're in for. I have a good feeling about you. You're good for Frank. Maybe it's that he can have an adult friend on a child's level. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it in a bad way.  There's one more thing. It's none of my business why you were in the state hospital. Everyone has something in their past, maybe you tried suicide, maybe you did something -- terrible. But what I see before me is a gentle, simple man. All I want you to promise me is that you're capable of being around Linda and Frank. You know. You would never hurt them under any circumstances, would you?
Person2: I wouldn't never hurt them.
Person1: That's what I thought. I hope I haven't offended you in any way. You seem like a thinker. You seem to always be in deep thought. Tell me something. What are you thinking right now?

Person1: It's all your fault! It was all arranged until he spoke to you! Why can't you leave us alone?
Person2: Do you mean to tell me you want to leave Shangri-La?
Person1: I'll die if I have to stay here another minute! I've waited a long time for this chance to go, and you're not going to stop me now. If I have to, I'll go alone. It was I who bribed the porters. If it weren't for me, you'd never get out!
Person2: I thought the porters had instructions from the High Lama not to take anyone.
Person1: The High Lama? Who pays any attention to him? The porters laugh at the High Lama. All they want to know is how much gold he will give them. Well, I gave them more gold. I've been stealing it for a year. I'd do anything to get out of this place. To get away from that High Lama - the one who calls himself Father Perrault! Why, he's been insane for years!
Person2: Father Perrault is dead.
Person1: He's dead? That's fine. You won't see me shedding any tears over him!  Oh George, you must take me with you!
Person2: Aren't you afraid to leave? You don't want to look like an old woman, do you?
Person1: Old woman? Chang told you that, didn't he?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: I thought so!  He tells everyone I'm old. He wants them to stay away from me. He can't stand it when anyone comes near. He's punished me for every minute I've spent with George. If it weren't for him, I would have been out of here long ago, but he always stops me. Six months ago, I tried to escape and he locked me in a dark room. I nearly went crazy.  Look at me, Mr. Conway, do I look like an old woman? Is this the skin of an old woman? Look into my eyes and see if these are the eyes of an old woman?

Person1: To our assignment.
Person2: What is it you need me to do?

Person2: I don't know.  I have to think...

Person1: You didn't visit him in prison.
Person2: He didn't want me to.
Person1: Why not?
Person2: I don't know.  He was different after he was sentenced, looking at thirty years.  Said it depressed him every time the younger cons called him an old timer.
Person1: But you spoke to him on the phone.
Person2: He'd call every once in a while.
Person1: He called the day he escaped.
Person2: He did?  I don't remember.  Did he say about me?  In the trunk?
Person1: He said he wished the two of you could start over, live a normal life.
Person2: Huh.  Problem is, Jack's idea of a normal life is robbing banks.  It's all he's ever done.
Person1: Did you know that when you married him?
Person2: He said he was a card player.  I could live with that.  I never knew he robbed banks till he got busted with that car that caught fire -- if you can imagine something like that happening, comes out of the bank and the car's on fire. I did go see him in jail to tell him I was filing for divorce.  He said, "Okay."  Jack's so easy going.  He was fun, but never what you'd call a real husband.
