Person1: Melodrama coming from you seems about as natural as an oral bowel movement.
Person2: What do you want me to say? Yes, I suppose some of the things you're saying may be true. But that's the way things are; it's not going to change.
Person1: Make them change.
Person2: I can't, all right! Jesus, would you leave me alone? I can't make changes like that in my life. If I could, I would-but I don't have the ability to risk comfortable situations on the big money and the fabulous prizes.
Person1: Who're you kidding? You can so.
Person2: Jesus H. Christ, I can't!
Person1: So you'll continue being miserable all the time, just because you don't have the guts to face change?
Person2: My mother told me once that when I as three, my potty lid was closed, and instead of lifting it, I chose to shit my pants.
Person1: Lovely story.
Person2: Point is-I'm not the kind of person that disrupts things in order to shit comfortably.

Person1: You seem... disturbed.
Person2: I... No. You do this for money?
Person1: Mais certainment... A great deal of money. Naturally I do not do it myself. I myself do not possess the nerve.  But I am always... how do you say... looking out for those who do... It is a thing quite rare. Champagne perhaps? Tch, tch. Don't say no. When a man says no to champagne, he says no to life and that no man must ever do.  Where did you play?
Person2: Up north.
Person1: Ah yes. Of course... So few survive.  La creme de la creme... How did you obtain release?
Person2: Playing.
Person1: Playing?
Person2: We... Three bullets.
Person1: And then you...

Person1: It's all kind of lost in the... in the dense mists of time now... It wasn't that I really liked Marco more.  In fact I thought you were more, shall we say, attractive than him.  It was just that he knew he was good-looking and you didn't, and that made a difference somehow.  You used to act as if I was weird for wanting to spend time with you, and that got kind of beat, if you know what I mean.  Your self-image started to rub off on me and I ended up thinking that I was strange.  And I knew that you were kind and thoughtful... you made me laugh, and I dug the way you got consumed by things you loved... and Marco seemed a bit more, I don't know, glamorous? More sure of himself?  Less hard work, because I felt like I was dragging you around, sort of.  A little sunnier.  Sparkier.  I don't know.  You know what people are like at that age.  They make very superficial judgements.  Do you think that's superficial?  He was a clown, if it's any consolation.
Person2: Did you tell that to Marco when he did his what-does-it-all-mean thing with you?
Person1: Oh God, no.  I didn't want to hurt his feelings.

Person1: Grab a seat there, boy. Want some dinner? Grab yourself an egg roll. We got everything here from a diddle-eyed-Joe to a damned-if-I-know.
Person2: No thanks.
Person1: No thanks? What does that mean? Means you ate before you came down here? All full. Is that it? Naw, I don't think so. I think you're too scared to be eatin'. Now, see we're sittin' down here, ready to negotiate, and you've already given up your shit. I'm still a mystery to you. But I know exactly where your ass is comin' from. See, if I asked you if you wanted some dinner and you grabbed an egg roll and started to chow down, I'd say to myself, "This person's acting like he hasn't got a care in the world. Who knows? Maybe he doesn't. Maybe this person's so confident, he doesn't have to worry about anything, he just sits down, eats my Chinese food, watches my TV." See? You haven't even sat down yet. On that TV there, since you've been in the room, is a woman in a revealing outfit, and you haven't even glanced. You've just been staring at me. Now, I know I'm interesting, but I'm not as interesting as that TV show.

Person1: I remember us having made some kind of deal, Randall. I don't remember this deal having some kind of time-limit. I look at you - here - in my town - and I'm confused...
Person2: A little family emergency --
Person1: I hope it's not your dear sweet mother...
Person2: No...
Person1: Or your baby brother. What was his name?
Person2: Kip.
Person1: Yes, Kip. Short for Kipling. Named for the English writer of stories about India ... He bites into his pear ... Memphis says nothing, waits ...

Person1: I'm gonna quit.
Person2: What?!?
Person1: Each show is worse than the next.
Person2: Are you nuts?!  40 million people watch you every week!
Person1: So?  What do they know?
Person2: Absolutely nothing!  That's the beauty!  It's credibility.  You make them love you... and then later, on your special, you'll screw with their heads!

Person1: Daddy, I want to discuss the prom with you. It's tomorrow night --
Person2: The prom?  Kat has a date?
Person1: No, but
Person2: It's that hot rod Joey, right? That ' s who you want me to bend my rules for?
Person1: He's not a "hot rod".  Whatever that is.
Person2: You're not going unless your sister goes.  End of story.
Person1: Fine.  I see that I'm a prisoner in my own house.  I'm not a daughter. I'm a possession!

Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Just giving credit where credit is due.
Person1: You have no one to blame but yourself.
Person2: Blame the victim.
Person1: Victim my ass!  You stole my security key and used it to break into my lab to do who knows what kind of damage!  Maybe this is the end of the story and you finally got what you deserved!
Person2: This is what I deserve for trying to protect the world from a madman and his mercenary physicists?
Person1: You're not protecting the world, you're obstructing progress!
Person2: I don't consider uncontrollable toxic waste progress!
Person1: And I'm sure you thought Columbus was going to sail off the edge of the world!
Person2: But lo and behold he found another world that progress could annihilate!
Person1: Come on, I don't see you living in a cave!
Person2: And I don't see you sunbathing at Chernobyl!

Person1: Don't help me.
Person2: He's a liar and a cheat and a scoundrel.  He's taken money from little old ladies.  He's talked people into doing things they never would have dreamed of.  Especially me.  But who has he really hurt?

Person1: Hasn't anyone ever taught you that fighting violence with violence solves nothing.
Person2: It's a lot more fun than fighting violence with pamphlets. That voicebox of yours is a hoot. Say "I'm wearing no underwear"--it'll be funny..  You do know you're evil, don't you?
Person1: A superhero's job is to protect society.  Don't blame me if society is a horrible, corrupt joke.
Person2: "A superhero's job is to protect.." Sorry, I can't take you seriously...I overheard you say that tomorrow the Cult of Good will be dead--I should be so lucky--what did that mean?
Person1: My, those little ears pick up a lot. The Cult of Good will die heroically preventing a world-class heist. Since we will be the ones performing the heist, our deaths will obviously be fake. But have no fear. There will be many other deaths tomorrow...and those will be quite real. I'm afraid these questions of yours put you in a position not unlike a long-tailed tabby in room full of rocking chairs.
Person2: Oh please, sir, one more. Are you the reporter or the architect?
Person1: Yes. I am the reporter or the architect.  You've been through so much..It looks like you've used up all nine of your lives...
Person2: I still have one left...
Person1: You think so?...Selina?
Person2: You've seen me...

Person1: Yeah, they's good all right.
Person2: You got any money?
Person1: They give me fifty dollars when they turned me loose. I spent up some of it on ridin' the bus and eatin' french-fried potaters.
Person2: Well, I'm gonna pay you today for this comin' week, so you'll have some walkin' around money. When you get off this evenin' you better go buy some toothpaste and cleanin' up supplies to have back there. Some hard candy and some magazines. Somethin' to keep you busy at night.
Person1: All right then.
Person2: I'll let you off while it's still daylight.

Person1: Don't flee from yourself.  If you have a quality, let it define you.  Cultivate it.  It is you.  By helping me, you will help yourse...
Person2: What!?  What are you talking about?  Why should I help you?
Person1: Because you want to.  You've always wanted to.  Look at your pictures.  Look at your sculptures.  Look at those tawdry representations and then ... Imagine.  Imagine a world of the body as canvas.  The body as clay.  Your will and mine as the brush and the knife. Oh, I have such sights to show you.

Person1: I returned the money, I made it right. I said I was sorry! What more do you want from me?
Person2: It's not about the money, Alex. It's about trust.

Person2: You made me doubt everyone around me. It's deeper than just an apology.
Person1: I know, but we can rebuild, can't we?
Person2: Time will tell, Alex. It's not that easy.

Person1: Yes, of course you are.  Well, Otho had an intuition.  Call it a hunch -- that it was going to be a fabled monstrosity of a house.  And it certainly is.  Charles, you're lucky the Yuppies are buying condos, so you can afford what I'm going to have to do to this place. We are talking from the ground ups'ville!
Person2: That's fine, Otho.  Just keep me out of it.  I am here to relax and clip coupons.  And goddamnit, I mean to do it.

Person1: They had it at the store, Paul, there was a whole batch of them there. As soon as I saw it, I slammed my money down. I got the first copy.
Person2: Then the roads are open...
Person1: The one to town is, but that's about it. I called the hospital and talked to the head orthopedic surgeon. I told him who you were and what had happened. He said as long as there's no infection, you're not in any danger, and as soon as the road to the hospital is open, they'll send an ambulance for you.
Person2: The phones are working?
Person1: Well, mine's still out. But the ones in town were working just fine. I called that agent of yours.  Oh, Paul, I peeked at the very beginning.  What a wonderful first page--just to read the name Misery Chastain...
Person2: My daughter must be going nuts.
Person1: ...it's like a visit from my oldest, dearest friend.
Person2: I was supposed to be home for her birthday three days ago.
Person1: Your agent said she would tell her you were okay. But I'm afraid you'll have to wait until tomorrow if you want to speak to her yourself.

Person1: It's important for you to know who your father was, isn't it?

Person1: There you are. Take some cake, why don't you?
Person2: No, thank you.
Person1: One little piece of cake won't hurt you. Go ahead, take one. It's full of fruit...citron, cherries and ginger. It'll make you dream. Yes, wonderful dreams.

Person1: Yeah, just her in the shower.  Nothing happened.  Look, I'm sure you probably think I'm a fool and I messed up, but...
Person2: No, I don't think you were a fool, I just think you were unwise about it. I mean, to say the least, you should know better. You don't know her well enough. She's got the potential to really hurt you even if she suggests that you made a pass at her, it's over. You can deny it all you want, but it will not make one bit of difference. You're in trouble.
Person1: I told you, you know, I thought I was doing the right thing, you know, I think she's innocent.
Person2: Well, it's not up to you to decide whether she's innocent or not.  Don't you understand, that's why you're a professional.
Person1: But, I mean, didn't you ever go out on a limb for somebody?  I mean, you shoulda heard her there.  Tellin' her whole story...I believed her.
Person2: How you go out on a limb for somebody is by giving her a number of an Immigration lawyer.  Here, here's a number of an Immigration lawyer.  That's how you help her. But you can't get involved in her like that.  You're gonna jeopardize your career, your life and you're gonna jeopardize my case.  And lemme give you another piece of advice.  Maybe you don't watch TV but I'll let you in on a little secret - the whole world watches television.  And when you get out there, they know your face.  And the little fame, the little itty bitty fame that I get in this city makes it a lot easier for my job.  And I get more done because of it.

Person1: Tell me.
Person2: Your mother mates out of season.

Person1: You said you had an insurance policy out on your wife.  Fifty-thousand dollars.

Person2: I think this heat's getting to you the way you're rambling on.

Person2: You're talking like a mad man.

Person2: What about your attitude...Where's your job...eh?  You talk and talk and I go to work...what do you do?

Person2: Ok, now that that's over with...what are you gonna make me for breakfast?

Person1: If the Mayor wants me, he knows where I am.

Person2: Howard Shenken, the Sheriff's uncle on his mother's side --

Person1: Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me.
Person2: I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God.

Person2: You're the one who started it.

Person2: You asked me to model.  Remember?
Person1: Of course I remember.  Do you think I'm so senile --

Person1: Sure, like this low-grade shit here, some girl in a fight with her boyfriend... it's a test-pattern. Nothing happens.  I'm snorin'.
Person2: Hey, you're always saying, 'Bring me real life.  Bring me street life. And, like, one man's mundane and desperate existence is another man's Technicolor.'

Person1: You're not crazy, by the way.

Person1: You didn't jump in.
Person2: That's my memory.  And it seemed absolutely real.
Person1: Seemed, not was.
Person2: It's in my family, you know.  My grandmother died in an institution...

Person1: Sandro, I don't want you to come with me, I don't want to see you... How can I make it clear to you?...Why did you come?
Person2: I don't know why. I just couldn't help it.
Person1: But sooner or later we've got to end this relationship. And it's better to do it right now.
Person2: I have no desire to sacrifice myself... It's idiotic to sacrifice oneself... Why?... For whom? If Anna were here I might understand your scruples. But she's not...
Person1: Oh, Sandro...
Person2: I'm sorry. I didn't want to sound cynical. But isn't it better to look things squarely in the eye?
Person1: For me they are exactly as they were when we met three days ago -- just three days ago... don't you realize? And you and Anna... No, I guess they aren't like that any more. My God, is it possible to forget in such a short time, for things to change so quickly?
Person2: It takes even less.
Person1: But it's so sad. So terribly sad. I'm not used to it, I'm not ready for it... You know... I have never been so upset in my life. Sandro, why don't you help me?
Person2: I think the only way to help ourselves, Claudia, is for us to be together.
Person1: No, I'm sure it won't. Move over there. Let's make believe nothing happened. And when we get to the next station, get off.
Person2: And what about you?
Person1: Me... I... I... Please leave me alone.

Person1: We're looking for him. In your opinion, why did Frank kidnap Dorothy's son and husband?
Person2: He became obsessed with her. She hated him. He had to have her. He kidnapped them to control her. to make her do things. Then she wanted to commit suicide so he started cutting off ears as a warning to her to stay alive. I'm not kidding. Frank loved blue. blue velvet. He had to have Dorothy cause her whole life was blue.
Person1: You seemed to see some very interesting things on your little escapade with Dorothy Vallens.
Person2: Yeah. I guess I did.  What's going to happen to me?
Person1: We're going to leave that up to Detective Williams. I'll tell you though. you're okay. you shot a real son of a bitch.
Person2: Yeah. I sure know that. Yeah, but how many more are out there?

Person1: I understand Black culture.  I grew up around black people all my life. If the truth be told I probably know "niggers" better than you, Monsieur Delacroix.  Please don't get offended by my use of the quote-unquote N word.  I got a black wife and three bi-racial children, so I feel I have a right to use that word.  I don't give a damn what Spike says, Tarantino is right.  Nigger is just a word.  If Dirty Ole Bastard can use it every other word so can I.
Person2: I would prefer you not use that word in my presence.
Person1: NIGGER.  NIGGER.  NIGGER.  NIGGER.

Person1: Do you remember if you were driving a car?  Maybe you went over the bridge.  No guard rail there, it's easy to do.  It's happened before.
Person2: It's possible.  I just don't remember.

Person2: I... no, I... I just can't...
Person1: It's okay, son.  We just need to call you something.  That's all.

Person1: If you ask me... I'll say, "yes."
Person2: There are lots of reason... I had a thought that if you had sex with Simon it might...

Person2: It's one idea...

Person2: I don't know why I brought you -- that idea occurred to me is all... It came out first... Hey, you kiss him -- me... He says he loves you. You two hit it off. But you don't want to... fine... Forget what I said about sex with Simon. It was a mistake.
Person1: I'll never forget you said it.

Person1: I didn't say nobody, I said you.
Person2: Sweet Dick, I didn't mean it like that.
Person1: Yes you did.

Person1: If looks could kill, I'm dead...
Person2: No, I don't care about you -- you're fantastic.  My whole interest, if it's not too late, is in Susie...and how to undo what you've done to her...
Person1: And what have I done to her, besides not buy her a new fur coat lately?  Sidney, you were right -- the boy's a dilly.
Person2: Why?  Because I don't like the way you toy with human lives? - Your contempt and malice?  Because I won't be the accomplice of your sick ego - and the way it's crippled Susie...?  You think of yourself - you and your column - you see yourself as a national glory...but to me, and thousands of others like me, you and your slimy scandal, your phony patriotics - to me, Mr. Hunsecker, you are a national disgrace!
Person1: Son, I don't fancy shooting mosquitoes with elephant guns.  So suppose you just shuffle along and call it a day...

Person1: You read that wrong. She doesn't marry Humperdinck, she marries Westley. I'm just sure of it. After all that Westley did for her, if she does not marry him, it wouldn't be fair.
Person2: Well, who says life is fair? Where is that written? Life isn't always fair.

Person1: Yes.

Not like it is with Susan, the way your eyes light up when she comes in the room and the way she always gets a laugh out of you, as opposed to me when I walk in a room and that look comes over your face, "What does she want now?"

Person1: She was very groovy. She was so in love with your Dad. If there was one other cat in this world that could have loved your Mum and treated her as well as you Dad did, it was me. But, unfortunately for yours truly, that train has sailed.

Person1: Yes, when I was younger I had thoughts about public office... But I found, Chauncey - that I was able to contribute more as a private citizen... of course, my wealth provided me with considerable influence, but I've tried, believe me, not to misuse that power... It's extremely important, Chauncey, when one is in a position of eminence, that he does not allow himself to become blinded to the needs of the country... The temptations are strong, and I've been labeled a 'kingmaker' by many, but I have tried to stay open to voices of the people... I have tried to remain honest to myself...
Person2: I see, Ben.
Person1: ... Maybe one day you shall find yourself in a similar position, Chauncey... Maybe one day...

Person2: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to lose something you love. To see it slip away, and know it's never coming back.

Person1: What do you mean you and my father decided? Who the hell are you to plan my life? Let's get married and live happily ever after. Bullshit. I got knocked up. I had to marry you. I never had a choice.

Person1: You betrayed me, Charlie. You were never there for me or the children. And now you come and tell me, "Peggy, you're scared." Of course I'm scared. If you knew what I knew you'd be scared shitless.

Person1: I might be crazy, but I'm not crazy enough to marry you twice. There's a lot of things I can't change. I can't even think about them. I tried. But I couldn't even help Rosalie.  I don't want to be bitter. I'm a naturally optimistic person. But you took advantage of that.

Person1: ... He said he had shot his Grandfather with a gun, and then he died in the garden.  And he asked me... he asked me, Tom, if that meant now his father would shoot him out of... revenge.  How does a four year old boy learn the word... 'revenge'?
Person2: Kay... Kay...
Person1: What kind of a family is this... are we human beings?  He knows his Father killed his Uncle Carlo.  He heard Connie.
Person2: You don't know that's true.  But Kay, just for the sake of an argument, let's assume it is, I'm not saying it is, remember, but... What if I gave you what might be some justification for what he did... or rather some possible justification for what he possibly did.
Person1: That's the first time I've seen the lawyer side of you, Tom.  It's not your best side.
Person2: Okay, just hear me out.  What if Carlo had been paid to help get Sonny killed?  What if his beating of Connie that time was a deliberate plot to get Sonny out into the open? Then what?  And what if the Don, a great man, couldn't bring himself to do what he had to do, avenge his son's death by killing his daughter's husband?  What if that, finally, was too much for him, and he made Michael his successor, knowing that Michael would take that load off his shoulders, would take that guilt?
Person1: He's not the same as when I met him.
Person2: If he were, he'd be dead by now. You'd be a widow.  You'd have no problem.
Person1: What the hell does that mean?  Come on, Tom, speak out straight once in your life.  I know Michael can't, but you're not Sicilian, you can tell a woman the truth; you can treat her like an equal, a fellow human being.

Person1: I don't want to argue with you. Let's just eat in peace.

Person1: No matter how I keep turning it around in my mind -- it doesn't seem like the right thing.
Person2: For who?
Person1: For anyone. They'll never be able to live through the talk. Richard will never be able to. He doesn't deserve that. He hasn't hurt anyone in his life.
Person2: Then he can move! People move!
Person1: His family's lived for almost a hundred years. Richard doesn't know how to live anywhere else. And the kids...
Person2: The kids are grown! They don't need you anymore. You told me that. They hardly talk to you.
Person1: No, they don't say much. But Carolyn's 16. She's just about to find out about all this for herself -- she's going to fall in love, she's going to try and figure out how to build a life with someone. If I leave what does that say to her?
Person2: What about us? What about me?
Person1: You've got to know deep down that the minute we leave here. It'll all change.
Person2: Yeah. It could get better.
Person1: No matter how much distance we put between us and this house, I bring with it with me. And I'll feel it every minute we're together. And I'll blame loving you for how much it hurts. And then even these four days won't be anything more than something sordid and... a mistake.
Person2: Francesca, listen to me. You think what's happened to us happens to just anybody? What we feel for each other? How much we feel? We're not even two separate people anymore. Some people search their whole lives for it and wind up alone -- most people don't even think it exists and you're going to tell me that giving it up is the right thing to do? That staying here alone in a marriage, alone in a town you hate, in a house you don't feel apart of anymore -- you're telling me that's the right thing to do!?
Person1: We are the choices we've made, Robert.
Person2: TO HELL WITH YOU!

Person1: Remember, pay attention to how she talks about Foley, her tone.  Do it right, she'll tell you things she wouldn't tell Burdon.  Tell her you think he's a nice guy.  No, first tell her about being in the trunk with him, in the dark for half an hour, and see how she takes it.  If she's in on it, what does she get for all the aggravation; cops breathing on her?  I bet nothing.  So she still likes him enough to stick her neck out.  You think that's possible?  What kind of guy is he?

I just want to graduate from high school, go to Europe, marry Charlie Sheen and die.  It may not sound too exciting to a sconehead like you, but I think it's swell.  And then you come along...  and... and then I'm a member of the hairy mole club, so you throw things at me!

Person1: So then what, Mr. Wandering Jack?

Person2: Yeah; it was great money... I could make a dollar a day, sometimes. But only in summer. When it got cold, I decided to go to Paris and see what the real artists were doing.

Person1: Mummy and I, we were more like lovers, really, or sisters.  Then a couple of years after Daddy died, and not long after I left Oxford, she started seeing various men and I was furious.  I really was upset. I stopped going home.  I never phoned.  I went round telling everyone how awful her books were. And she hardly seemed to notice, and that made me angrier.  Then I got a job I was interested in, and I started to see lots of men, and I suppose I grew up a little and began to understand.  So I wrote her a long letter, almost seven pages, saying how sorry I was, and how I was worried that we were drifting apart.  And do you know, she wrote me a poem, a really beautiful poem about mothers and daughters.
Person2: How nice.
Person1: It makes me weepy just to remember it.  So we were fine again, and then she got married to Matthew who's a womaniser and a bit of a yob, but quite nice really, makes TV commercials.  What about yours.

I was sorry and I'm sorry every time your food was cold and that you had to wait two seconds for a coffee filler...

Person2: In about fifteen minutes.

Person1: Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport.  ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world...  Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired...
Person2: I don't understand.
Person1: Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture...
Person2: Follow him? Mr. Gekko I...  It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?
Person1: Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that?  I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business...

Person1: Why? Why? Why? Why add to your misery by confessing to murder? You didn't kill him.
Person2: I did.
Person1: No, you didn't!
Person2: I poisoned his life.
Person1: But not his body.
Person2: What difference does that make?

Person2: No, Father. From now on no one will be able to speak of Mozart without thinking of me. Whenever they say Mozart with love, they'll have to say Salieri with loathing. And that's my immortality - at last! Our names will  be tied together for eternity - his in fame and mine in infamy. At least it's better than the total oblivion he'd planned for me, your merciful God!
Person1: Oh my son, my poor son!
Person2: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You serve a wicked God. He killed Mozart, not I. Took him, snatched him away, without pity. He destroyed His beloved rather than let a mediocrity like me get the smallest share in his glory. He doesn't care. Understand that. God cares nothing for the man He denies and nothing either for the man He uses. He broke Mozart in half when He'd finished with him, and threw him away. Like an old, worn out flute.

Person1: We've been given a gift here, honey.  A real live little girl. She likes us a lot.  She needs us. Maybe that's why we died so young, to keep us from getting so... attached to things.  The house, antiques, your model.  Look at us. We didn't have room for anyone.

Person1: Edie, for years we pushed quarters into a cookie jar, to keep you up there with the Sisters, and to keep you from things like I just seen out the window. My own daughter arm-in-arm with Terry Malloy. You know who Terry Malloy is?

Person1: Who is he! Edie, you're so softhearted and soft-headed you wouldn't recognize the devil if he had you by the throat. You know who this Terry Malloy is? The kid brother of Charlie the Gent, Johnny Friendly's right hand, a butcher in a camel hair coat.
Person2: Are you trying to tell me Terry is too?
Person1: I'm not trying to tell you he's Little Lord Fauntleroy.
Person2: He tries to act tough, but there's a look in his eyes that... .
Person1: A look in his eyes! Hold your hats, brother, here we go again. You think he's one of those cases you're always draggin' in and feelin' sorry for. Like the litter of kittens you hadthe only one she wants to keep has six toes and it's cockeyed to boot. Look at him. The bum! And the crush you had on that little Abyssinian... .
Person2: He wasn't Abyssinian, Pop, Assyrian... .
Person1: Six-toed cats. Assyrians. Abyssinians. It's the same difference. Well don't think this Terry Malloy is any six-toed cockeyed Assyrian. He's a bum. Charley and Johnny Friendly owned him when he was a fighter and when they ring the bell he still goes into action.
Person2: He wanted to see me again.
Person1: You think we kept you out in Tarrytown just to have you go walkin' with a corner saloon hoodlum like Terry Malloy? Now get back to Tarrytown, before I put a strap to you.
Person2: And learn about charity and justice and all the other things people would rather talk about than practice? Pop goes up to her and holds out his two arms, his right one closer to Edie; he trembles with emotion.
Person1: See this arm? It's two inches longer 'n the other one. That's years of workin' and sweatin', liftin' and swingin' a hook. And every time I heisted a box or a coffee bag I says to myselfthis is for Edie, so she can be a teacher or somethin' decent. I promised your mother. You better not let her down.

Person1: Yeah, I had a small problem with members of our side murdering civil-...
Person1: ...-ians.  But I assure you, Leo...
Person1: ...I lost all my squeamishness at Leav- ...
Person1: ...-enworth.  I'll have no compunction at all about using this.

Person1: Or I may be wrong.  The breeze could be gusting south.  That'd be Billings...
Person1: ...maybe even Salt Lake, not to mention Casper...
Person1: ...Destry, Fair Oaks....
Person2: Knowing you, Brynner, you've got buyers waiting to buy! You're not gonna use that...
Person2: ...here!

Person1: I'll do it.

Person1: So what's with this place? You have a swan fetish? Is this something you'd like to talk about?
Person2: I was thinking about what you said to me the other day, about my painting. I stayed up half the night thinking about it and then something occured to me and I fell into a deep peaceful sleep and haven't thought about you since. You know what occurred to me?
Person1: No.
Person2: You're just a boy. You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about.
Person1: Why thank you.
Person2: You've never been out of Boston.
Person1: No.
Person2: So if I asked you about art you could give me the skinny on every art book ever written...Michelangelo? You know a lot about him I bet. Life's work, criticisms, political aspirations. But you couldn't tell me what it smells like in the Sistine Chapel. You've never stood there and looked up at that beautiful ceiling. And if I asked you about women I'm sure you could give me a syllabus of your personal favorites, and maybe you've been laid a few times too. But you couldn't tell me how it feels to wake up next to a woman and be truly happy. If I asked you about war you could refer me to a bevy of fictional and non-fictional material, but you've never been in one. You've never held your best friend's head in your lap and watched him draw his last breath, looking to you for help. And if I asked you about love I'd get a sonnet, but you've never looked at a woman and been truly vulnerable. Known that someone could kill you with a look. That someone could rescue you from grief. That God had put an angel on Earth just for you. And you wouldn't know how it felt to be her angel. To have the love be there for her forever. Through anything, through cancer. You wouldn't know about sleeping sitting up in a hospital room for two months holding her hand and not leaving because the doctors could see in your eyes that the term "visiting hours" didn't apply to you. And you wouldn't know about real loss, because that only occurs when you lose something you love more than yourself, and you've never dared to love anything that much. I look at you and I don't see an intelligent confident man, I don't see a peer, and I don't see my equal. I see a boy. Nobody could possibly understand you, right Will? Yet you presume to know so much about me because of a painting you saw. You must know everything about me. You're an orphan, right?

It's designed to encourage airline travel and obviously designed to encourage buying Healthy Choice products. They make frozen meals, deli meats, pasta sauce, breads, soups and ice creams, this sort of thing.....

Person1: ....I'm sorry....I lost my thoughts, what I was saying....

Person1: -- the promotion says: buy any 10 Healthy Choice products and get 500 miles of airline travel or 1,000 for purchases made with a special coupon. So in the supermarket, you notice their products, first you notice they have a Teriyaki Chicken Dinner at $1.79 - that's a pretty good deal....but then I noticed they had soup at 89 cents a can.....and you start to do the math and you start to notice that it's a really amazing deal because I stumbled across the pudding at 25 cents a cup. Now the crucial thing is the bar codes on the label. That's those little bar codes, you know? The universal product codes?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: That's what's used to redeem the mileage, so in noticing the pudding, each cup had an individual bar code -- in other words, two dollars and fifty cents for ten cups of pudding is 500 miles. Add in the coupon: it's one thousand. You see?

Person1: You see?
Person2: Yeah, no, I see --

Person1: Leon?  Whatsa matter?  They give you a shot down the hospital or what?
Person2: Oh, God, they shot me with like unreal!
Person1: Well, you got to get hold of yourself.  You got to talk to him, tell him to give himself up.

Person1: If he won't listen to you, who will he listen to?
Person2: He won't listen to anybody.  He's been very crazy all summer.  Since June he's been trying to kill me.
Person1: You try calling the police?
Person2: What good is that?  They couldn't stop him.  And it'd just make him mad.  They don't know him.
Person1: Somebody's got to stop him, Leon.
Person2: He was under great strain. You don't understand, he's a very mixed up person.
Person1: He's makin' threats in there.
Person2: He's scared.  It's crazy.  I never met anyone like him.  His wife, he's a wonderful father to his children.  His mother - you should see her - his mother and father together are like a bad car wreck - he lets it all slide off his back, he sees them, he pays their rent. Unbelievable.  I wanted to get married ... He didn't really want it ... he's married already!  But he did it.  I don't know why.  I thought it would help me, but it didn't.  I was just as confused and unhappy was before; I did terrible things.
Person1: What kind of things, Leon?
Person2: Ten days I spent in Atlantic City - Sonny was frantic - he knew I was drinking; he didn't know where I was ... who I was with.  I couldn't explain why I did the things I did. So I went to this psychiatrist who explained to me I was a woman in a man's body.  So Sonny right away wanted to get me money for a sex change operation. But where was he to get that?  2500 dollars!  My God, he's in hock up to his ears already.
Person1: He needed money?  For the operation for you?
Person2: It made him crazy - so much demand, he'd fly into this rages.  And I got more depressed than ever; I saw I'd never get the operation.  So I tried to take my life - I swallowed about a half pound of pills ... blues, reds, yellows, downers, uppers, screamers ... you name it. But I just threw them up and wound up in the hospital.  Sonny comes there and looks at me and just says: "Wow!"  So when I hear he's in the bank, I almost go crazy because I know he's doin' it for me.
Person1: Well, don't you figure you owe to him to get him out of there?
Person2: I can't talk to him.
Person1: You're in it up to your ass, Leon. You're an accessory.  You talk him out of there and they might be a little more understanding of your case.
Person2: I'm afraid.
Person1: How is he gonna hurt you on the telephone?
Person2: I don't know what to say to him.  I can't.
Person1: You think it over, Leon.

Person2: Mm.
Person1: Well, you want to swing by the Chinks, watch me eat, we'll talk?
Person2: I think I'd better stay here for a while.

Person1: Why did you leave the dishes in the sink again? I thought we agreed to clean up after ourselves.
Person2: Oh, so now you're tracking every little thing I do?
Person1: I just want some help around here.
Person2: I see you want to start a fight. Maybe we should discuss this when we're both calm.

Person1: I don't understand.
Person2: Oh, come on, Buffy.  You know what's going on.  It's not working out at all.  I've got to move on.  I mean, I've got needs, too.  I told you about all this.
Person1: No, you didn't.  When?
Person2: Didn't you get my message?
Person1: You broke up with my machine?
Person2: You weren't home.  Like always.
Person1: You left me a message?
Person2: I'm out of here.  Jenny.

Person1: Emma, did you ever find out about the surprise party I planned for you?
Person2: Surprise party? That doesn't ring any bells. Are you sure it happened?
Person1: Positive. I invited your friends and organized it last Saturday.
Person2: I'm really drawing a blank here, Alex. Are you sure it wasn't someone else?
Person1: Well, now that you mention it, maybe there was a mix-up.
Person2: Oh, I thought you knew; I never intended to hide anything.
Person1: I must have misunderstood.

Person1: That isn't true.  It was about your father.  Where is he?
Person2: He's all right.  Isn't that enough?
Person1: No.
Person2: You just want money -- and you haven't any right to any more.  He made a big settlement on you.
Person1: That's gone long ago.  I've got to see him.  Where is he?
Person2: I won't have you hounding him any more for money.

Person1: Uh, I come here personally to kind of smooth over a fracas about a certain matter. See, uh, maybe you didn't know it, but, uh, Don Ward is a very well-liked man in this town. He's got lots of friends here. Now, his family and their money go back many, many years. Now, friends vote... family and money votes. That's important to me... and you. And if you'll think about our little problem along them lines...  and you forgive me for sayin' it, maybe he did not deserve to be fired.
Person2: I'm sorry, but he knew about our gettin' hit on three big machines in a row and he did nothing about it. That means either he was in on it or, forgive me for saying this, he was too dumb to see what was going on. Either way, I cannot have a man like that workin' here.
Person1: Before we point the dirty end of the stick at 'ol Don, uh, we better be sure we can prove them charges.
Person2: Believe me, if I could prove it, he would be under arrest.
Person1: Are, uh -  - are we certain that you want the Gamin' Control Board eyeballin' your record and your gangster pals like Nicky Santoro?
Person2: I think you're way out of line talkin' to me like that. What you're sayin' is libelous, and you're in no position to challenge my expertise. I went way out of my way to be very helpful and courteous to that kid. He's weak, he's incompetent. He jeopardizes the whole place. There's not much more I can do for him.
Person1: You have got me there. Old Don is as useless as tits on a boar.  But, he is my brother-in-law, and I would look on it as a personal favor if you'd think some more on hirin' him back.
Person2: I can't do that. And I appreciate the fact that he's your brother-in- law, and I do want to help you and I like to do favors, and I know who you are, but I cannot do that.
Person1: Well, could there be any position... further down the trough?
Person2: I'm sorry, I can't do anything. He's too incompetent. And the bottom line is, he cannot be trusted.

Person1: You wanted by the law or somethin'?
Person2: Naw, it's okay.
Person1: You're crazy carryin' that kinda money in this neighborhood.  No wonder you got hit.
Person2: Thanks.  I'm obliged to ya, but I gotta get goin'.
Person1: You ain't goin' nowhere on that leg.
Person2: I gotta!  Look, I run some slots down in West Bend for a mob here. I got a little behind on my payoffs so they figure I been holdin' out on 'em.  They gave me to 4:00 to come up with the cash.  I don't get it there I'm dead.
Person1: It don't look good, gramps, it's ten of now.
Person2: I got a hundred bucks for you and your friend if you deliver the money for me.
Person1: I dunno.  That little mug that got ya is mad enough at me already -- what if he's out there waitin' around a corner with some friends.
Person2: He won't know you're carryin' it. C'mon, you gotta help me out.
Person1: Sorry, pal.  I'll fix you up, call you a doc, but I ain't gonna walk into a bunch of knives for ya.
Person2: How bout you?  I'll give you the whole hundred!
Person1: What makes you think you can trust him?  He didn't do shit.

Person1: Annette, how long have we known each other?
Person2: Forever.
Person1: Now it's my job to look out for you. You're like a kid sister to me. Do I look like some kind of gossip queen?

Person1: You mean we get `Dave' to nominate you as Vice President.
Person2: I was a senator, you know.
Person1: Oh, I know. And then when our poor President gets another stroke - - of course much more serious this time - - the newly appointed V.P. becomes the Pres...
Person2: What about containment, Alan?

Person1: Masseria's confused. He can't figure whether you're workin' for Maranzano, or gettin' ready to kill the bastard. So he's spreadin' the word that you're goin' after Profaci because it happened on his turf. I figure Masseria's gonna try to rub out Profaci, and pin it on us. Then Maranzano will have to kill ya.
Person2: You got men on Profaci's place?
Person1: We got our boys paintin' the house next door. Around the clock. We're gonna keep old man Profaci alive if it takes twenty coats.

Person1: Check your mail tomorrow.  I sent you a letter, a letter.
Person2: Your letter came yesterday.
Person1: It did?
Person2: Uh-huh.  It was wonderful.
Person1: Why didn't you tell me?
Person2: It was wonderful.
Person1: I've never sent a letter like that, you know?  I mean, I felt like I wanted to tell you something, but I didn't put it in the letter, and I didn't say it, but I want to say it now, I'm not sure if I should say it, you know, 'cause people always say it and don't mean it, but I think that I mean it, so, um, I just wanted to tell you...
Person2: No, we don't have to say it.
Person1: How do you know what I'm going to say?
Person2: I don't know what you're going to say, but I think that...
Person1: I was just going to tell you that I love you.  I said it.
Person2: I know.  Lloyd, let's not start putting things on this level.
Person1: What?  This is a good level, isn't it?
Person2: How can I look at you and say this?
Person1: Say what?

Person1: And here's one from nice Mr. Zeiss. He says that...
Person2: Why are these all opened?
Person1: Well, they needed immediate answers, Frances. It's good manners and good sense. You shouldn't be bothering yourself with these right now.
Person2: Then why did you bring them?
Person1: It's your fan mail, little sister.
Person2: You kill me, Mama.
Person1: What?
Person2: Go on...

Person1: You're going to drive me crazy!
Person2: Let's see... where was I?  Oh, yes.  He went to find the man. That man was desperate!  He knew that he was caught dead to rights -- and with prison staring him in the face, he took the only way out. He killed Wynant.  It's terrible to tell you this way but your father's dead, Dorothy.

Person1: I hate to turn on this light, you Daddy's awake downstairs, but I have to take the chance.  Buddy, please don't tell on me.
Person2: I said I wouldn't.
Person1: Buddy, I have to ask you, as bad as I've been please have pity on me and don't ruin me by telling them what I did. I know it was bad, it was bad and dumb. But mostly it was dumb, I didn't mean you no harm, I'd never want to hurt a hair on your head and that's the truth. I love you. But they'd think I did, they'd think I was awful, they'd despise me and hate me...

Person1: You are drunk.  You know, it's been a long time and I'd love to catch up, but I really got to -

Person2: It's...it's a long story.  Can we meet somewhere?
Person1: Jesus, man...
Person2: Please...

Person1: A million things could have caused those problems.  Poor diet, bad genes, irresponsible lifestyle.  Our offer is final and more than fair.

Person1: 250,000 is all I'm authorized to offer.

Person1: Get out of this room and get back to work.
Person2: I don't have to listen to you anymore.
Person1: I am in charge now. Get back to work or I'll fire you.
Person2: Let me ask you Mr. Manager, do you notice a smell of cockroaches? If I were to leave this room, I'm sure I could find this smell. I know people who could cleanse it. But maybe it doesn't bother you? Why is that? Are used to this smell? Not me, I need a clean room to escape it.

Person1: What is it, mother?
Person2: I wish to discuss your brother.
Person1: He is dead!  By God's choice!  There is nothing to discuss.
Person2: First they told me he had died at birth.  Then your father admitted he was alive, but well cared for, in secret.  But the message that told of his death said he had been a prisoner.
Person1: I am King, Mother!  And I do not wish to discuss this with you.
Person2: He was my blood -- and I demand to know what happened to him.
Person1: Why would you ask now?  You never asked before!
Person2: Because I have dreamed of him.  Not as the baby they took away, but as a man.
Person1: You have prayed too much.  Your mind is weak.

Person1: Help me with this one, I'm really screwed up.
Person2: Bring it left. Bring it left, You're high.
Person1: This is crazy!
Person2: What is?
Person1: Wait! Hell!..Something's wrong!
Person2: What?  What is it?
Person1: Were upside down!
Person2: You're crazy. We're level.
Person1: Can't you feel it? I'm hanging in my straps!
Person2: You're not. We're level. Look at the instruments, we're okay!
Person1: They must be broken. I'm hanging in my straps! We're inverted!
Person2: We're not! Trust me! We're okay.

Person1: They're like beasts. Wild.
Person2: Maybe they're angry because they're grown in meccano-breeders.
Person1: Instead of what? Nine months inside a woman. We're all raised the same but most of us don't become cubs in Cathedral.
Person2: Some people say children need human mothering.
Person1: Insane. Nurseries are better than any mother could be.
Person2: I'm only telling you what I've heard...  Haven't you ever wondered what your seed-mother was Like...?

Person2: I have.

Person2: I don't remember exactly... except I was a Green.  What would you like to relive, Logan?
Person1: Let's see -- how long has it been?

Person1: I did something stupid. I had a courier job -- picking up a package from the airport. It turned out to be money -- so I kind of borrowed it to pay my rent and now these dudes are after me.
Person2: So pay them back and apologize.
Person1: These guys aren't the kind that'll take an apology. They're the kind that'll break my thumbs.
Person2: You think that story's gonna make me loan you money?
Person1: It's the truth. If you'd just loaned me the money last time this never would have happened.
Person2: Somehow this winds up being my fault? You always blame me.
Person1: Come on, I'm your biggest supporter.
Person2: My bra is my biggest supporter.
Person1: I just need a place to lay low for a few days. Come on, I know you hate me but you can't wanna see me at the bottom of the East River?

Person1: Saved me?  You don't even know me. You used me, Caesar, just like I used you.  All part of the business.
Person2: You betrayed me!
Person1: You murdered Gino!
Person2: I had to.  You made me.
Person1: Nonsense, you killed him. Not me. You did it because you couldn't stand the thought of Johnnie deceiving you.

Person2: Dizzy wouldn't want our tears. She'd want us to remember her... with a vengeance. So go out and kill a bug for Dizzy. Kill as many as you can. You are her revenge, and every bug you kill honors her death.

Person1: Son. About Rasputin --
Person2: Don't worry. I'll get him soon enough --

Person1: Well, I won't be around forever, you know?

Person1: You have just made the worst mistake of your lives! You have chosen to join my Army! This Army is my mother, my father, and my little virgin sister and I will not allow anyone or anything that is not up to my standards near her pretty little virgin cooze, do you understand me -- give me a sir, yes, sir!
Person2: Sir, yes, sir!
Person1: Those who I deem unworthy to pass through this camp will quit, and those who refuse to quit I will kill. You ever hear of a training accident -- give me a sir, yes, sir!
Person2: Sir, yes, sir!
Person1: In my time I have killed sixteen men for the good of my country, sixteen men whose entrance into this Army I could not condone, as it would weaken the fabric of this nation's defense! This base suffers an average of three training accidents a year, unfortunate incidents that I will not hesitate to repeat if you cross me, understand -- give me a sir, yes, sir!
Person2: Sir, yes, sir!
Person1: So forget what you've seen on Sixty Minutes about the kinder, gentler military -- you will either succeed, quit, or die by my hand!

Person1: You hate your father.
Person2: If he tricked me into loving him, is what I meant.
Person1: You'd hate him for the trick.
Person2: Not if what he left me was real.

Person1: I told her she was going to meet her father.
Person2: You what?
Person1: It was the only way, Auggie. Otherwise, she wasn't going to let me see her.
Person2: I think you'd better stop the car and let me out.

Person2: Yeah, like what?
Person1: That I wasn't bullshitting you, sweetheart. At least you'll know I've been telling the truth.
Person2: Look, I'm not saying you don't have a daughter. It's just that she's not my daughter.
Person1: Wait till you see her, Auggie.
Person2: And what's that supposed to mean?
Person1: She looks just like you.
Person2: Cut it out. Just cut it out, okay? It's starting to get on my nerves.
Person1: When I told her I was going to bring her father, she kind of melted. It's the first time Felicity's talked nice to me since she left home. She's dying to meet you, Auggie.

Person1: I can't afford this stuff right now.
Person2: Oh, come on.  You've had a hard year, you're cooped up with the kid all the time.  Let go; live a little.

Person1: I'm a girl, I'm a girl, I'm a girl -
Person2: What did you say?
Person1: I'm a very sick girl.
Person2: Maybe I'd better go before I catch something.
Person1: I'm not that sick.
Person2: I have a very low resistance.
Person1: Look, Sugar, if you feel you're coming down with something, the best thing is a shot of whiskey.
Person2: You got some?
Person1: I know where to get some.  Don't move.

Person1: Wholesome.
Person2: Unwelcome.
Person1: Unwelcome?  I guess someone still has her panties in a twist.
Person2: Don't for one minute think that you had any effect whatsoever on my panties.
Person1: So what did I have an effect on ?
Person2: Other than my upchuck reflex? Nothing.

Person1: Damn, Max.  I'm impressed.  Really.  I would have bet good money you wouldn't walk out of there.
Person2: Makes two of us.

Person1: Who are you?
Person2: That's not the way we play the game.
Person1: I don't play games.

Person1: We pick up Schumann.  Sneak him back inside the Beltway. And we plan his homecoming.  Zt's gone be Neil Armstrong, Dr. Livingston, and Lindy...They're gonna forget, they're gonna forget, they're gonna forget that there is an election...The Pres's gonna have to say, one of his speeches, "Don't forget to Vote..."
Person2: I got it in the inaugural.  "Thank you for voting for me, but, as importantly, Thank you for voting..."
Person1: Getting off on the inaugural?  Gonna go...
Person2: Might, if I was asked...

Person1: Don't take it personally.
Person2: You have no right, no right to take the worst thing that's ever happened to me and make it into some kind of game.
Person1: Stop acting like you're someone special. You're just like the rest of us.
Person2: I'm not the one who's masquerading as a doctor. I'm not the one who's, who's...

Person1: Legate Narcissus Meridas, general of the Spanish Felix Legions!  I'm proud to have you in my school!  Now, show them what you can do!
Person2: I'm not a gladiator.  I refuse to fight.
Person1: Then, you'll die...  Just, know this

Person1: Otis!!!!
Person2: Otis!!!!
Person1: Otis, good boy, come here.  Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god.
Person2: This is a nightmare.  We should have kept him upstairs.
Person1: It was done.  When Sophia put the kids to bed, America brought Otis in the room and closed the door.  It was done.
Person2: Well someone clearly let him out before Monica opened the gate.
Person1: Oh, forget you, and forget Monica while you're at it.  But I guess that's what I interrupted.
Person2: Jesus, Sally.  You are a medical miracle. The only person who's ever taken ecstacy and become angrier.
Person1: Yeah, let's talk about that.  You seem to be rather an expert.  I don't remember in the last five months of counselling your ever mentioning ecstacy or going to rage parties.
Person2: Rave parties?!  That's so typical - you would think it was called rage.  Perfect!
Person1: What else don't I know about, Joe?  Let's get really clear here.
Person2: Sally, so I took a few pills.  I went out dancing.  I tried to forget how upset I was about splitting up with you.  I haven't lied to you.  I told you about the people I've slept with.  I just didn't mention the few occasions I took drugs because you're so judgmental I knew I'd never hear the end of it, and you have so little faith and so little trust in me.  Sally, we're back, I love you.  Trust that.  Please let's not do this.
Person1: Otis!  Come!  Good boy!  Come!
Person2: Otis!
Person1: I'm not sure we understand that word in the same way.
Person2: Love?
Person1: You walked out on a five year marriage.
Person2: That hasn't the first thing to do with love.  It's whether we can live together... like this!  All the time.
Person1: It's not like this all the time.
Person2: DO I want anyone else?  No.  Do I want to be with you for the rest of my natural life?  I'm trying.
Person1: And how hard it hit?
Person2: Just stop right there, Sally.  We've been through this.
Person1: You've been through it.  That's how you love people.  When it's easy for you, when it's convenient for you.
Person2: Sally, first of all, you're talking bullshit.  And second...
Person1: You want to talk about bullshit?  Lucy called you three times this week.  She's a mess, Joe.  Your sister is a mess.  She needs you.  I talk to her more than you do.
Person2: That is not true.
Person1: It is true.  You know how you love, Joe? You dedicate a book to someone.
Person2: Every novel I've had published in every language I've dedicated to Lucy.
Person1: Right.  And when was the last time you spoke to her?

Person1: Jon, I do not want to hear it.
Person2: I'm sorry.  Look -- there's a gas storm on the Valles Marineris . . .
Person1: Oh God.  I'm no more than a bug on a windshield to you.
Person2: You're the only human being I care for.
Person1: Then do me a favor.  If the world's going to end, it shouldn't matter a bit.  I want you to cure me.
Person2: I won't do that.
Person1: You have the power to do it.  I want you to do it.  Please.
Person2: I explained this.  I can't.  That's not the way it happens.
Person1: Jon.  If you ever loved me -- if there's anything human left in you -- then do it.

Person1: ...wouldn't let you settle it, huh?
Person2: Hell, you know how Skinny is. Says he's gonna shoot 'em... an I says, "Skinny, you can't do that," an' he says, "Well, then get Little Bill down here an' let's settle this" an' I says, "Bill's sleepin', Skinny," an'...

Person1: Get up out of the chair, Richard.
Person2: What's with you people? Why do ya have to mess with my head all the time? I came through, man.
Person1: Get up out of the chair, and walk toward the backdoor, Richard.
Person2: I get thrown in solitary until I don't know my own darn name, and then you people tell me I can beat nine years if I help you. I helped you!
Person1: Get up!

Person1: I'm sorry. After careful consideration, I regretfully have to decline.
Person2: C'mon, man, I'm just asking for one Superbowl ring.
Person1: In exchange for eternal damnation of your soul? You're too nice of a guy for me to want to do that to you, Mr. Marino.
Person2: You did it for Namath.
Person1: Yeah, but Joe was coming here anyways. Just go back to Earth and enjoy your records and the Hall of Fame and the beautiful family and all that.
Person2: This is bullshit, man.  I'm gonna win the Superbowl this year, with or without you!
Person1: Now you're talking.

Person1: Hey, Eve!
Person2: Have you ever heard the saying, "He hasn't got enough sense to come in out of the rain?"
Person1: Yep.  You know, my father -- who is a scientist -- says that everything is a miracle. Everything. Until recently I wasn 't sure what he meant by that.
Person2: Yeah? No kidding. Listen, you still want to go girl hunting tonight?
Person1: I certainly do!
Person2: Okay. But you know, this business of finding you a wife -- it's kind of ridiculous, don't you think?
Person1: No it's not!
Person2: Yes it is. A girlfriend maybe. But a wife? I mean...
Person1: Then just help me find a girlfriend! That's all I ask. I'll give you every single card I've got left!
Person2: Hey, screw you! Okay? You think I'm just somebody you can buy off! Listen, let me tell you something--
Person1: Would you do it just because you're my friend? My very best friend.
Person2: Well...yeah. Okay.

Person1: Have you any idea what the message is?
Person2: If it's so important, why don't you just tell me?
Person1: I couldn't tell you that.  It would ruin the game.  Not that you're playing it very well.
Person2: You like to brag, don't you?

Person1: What is it? What's in there?
Person2: The Soul of the House. Everything that's corrupt about it... My father trapped it in there just before he died. You see, he purchased the house to restore it... We were going to live here... Nothing can live here. I was just a kid... The first time I saw it, I thought it was beautiful... It was just a dark mist turning into the corner of the room... then it started to move... then death started to happen... First the workers.. six in all... then my father...

Person1: No!  You're one of them.  Of course, it makes perfect sense!
Person2: No, it doesn't!  Those keys were put there.  I didn't even know...
Person1: You're behind this, aren't you?  You and your sick friends.  Well, make it stop!
Person2: Listen to yourself.   Why would I do anything like what you're describing?
Person1: Because you hate me.  Because you had to be here, when mom died.  Because you had to do it alone.  Well, don't you think if I'd known... I'd've been here too.  I'd have been here...
Person2: Stop this.  It's not true...
Person1: I'm sorry, Christ, I'm sorry!  How many more times do I have to say I'm sorry before you forgive me... ?
Person2: Stop it!

Person1: You awake?
Person2: You could call it that.  My eyes are open.
Person1: Me too.  I feel awake.
Person2: Good.
Person1: Wide awake.  I don't remember ever feelin' this awake.  Everything looks different.  You know what I mean.  I know you know what I mean. Everything looks new.  Do you feel like that?  Like you've got something to look forward to?

Person1: Oh! The evening before, I see...
Person2: Yes, Dr. Furtwngler was absolutely clear about this: politics and art must be kept separate.
Person1: Politics and art must be kept separate. I'll remember that. But let me see if you can help me with something I just don't understand. I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about him. What's his secret?

Person1: Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book,  The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K.
Person2: This is absolute nonsense!
Person1: Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime?  Jealousy?
Person2: Of course there was a conspiracy against me, a campaign - even abroad.

Person1: How much do you owe me, Curly?
Person2: Oh, gee, Mr. Gittes we're going out tomorrow. I know you been real good about it but my cousin Auggie's sick.
Person1: Forget it. How would you like to pay me off by taking a couple of passengers to Ensenada... you'd have to leave tonight.
Person2: I don't know...
Person1: I might be able to squeeze an extra seventy-five bucks out of it for you. Maybe an even hundred.
Person2: Plus what I owe you?
Person1: I'll throw that in too.
Person2: Okay, you got yourself a boat.

Person1: Are you seeing somebody else, Nathan? I just have to know.
Person2: Of course not.
Person1: It would just be helpful to know.
Person2: No.
Person1: Because, you know, you seem so distant. And you work late every night. And we hardly ever have sex, and when we do, it's... I don't know. It feels different.
Person2: I'm just preoccupied.
Person1: Do you like my new look?

Saunders--whether you ever mean anything to him or not--

Person1: "That boy"--Mami, say his name for chrissakes!

Person1: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.
Person2: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.
Person1: Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?
Person2: I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on the gallows.
Person1: Really?
Person2: Really, I haven't a bit of character. None at all.
Person1: No?
Person2: When I was a little boy I was taught to ride and be a gentleman -- at school, it was a monastery, I learned to pray and lie -- and ---
Person1: And?
Person2: And then, in the war, to kill and hide. That's all.
Person1: And what do you do -- now?
Person2: I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large like a happy pig, devouring anything of life that pleases me, I really belong in jail
Person1: Oh! What a picture -- and what else?
Person2: I'm also a criminal and a hotel thief.
Person1: That's a silly joke.
Person2: Please look at me. You must believe me -- you must believe that I love you -- that I have never known what love is -- until last night.
Person1: What is the matter?

Person1: He gets huge advances on his novels. He's going back to that.  You know how he hates it here.
Person2: There's still time to undo this.
Person1: We'll be fine.
Person2: Did you invite them?
Person1: The Roses?  And of course they said yes.
Person2: That was the plan.  And you're thrilled to have them.
Person1: Whatever you say.
Person2: Did you tell Joe to behave?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Did he promise?
Person1: Scout's honor.
Person2: Before I forget.  Put it on the bookshelf.

Person1: Mr Rothstein, sir, let me put her on suspension.
Person2: Never mind the 'sir'. Never mind the 'sir'.
Person1: Well, sir, I was just...
Person2: Why is she eight pounds over?
Person1: ...trying to offer you the respect that your...
Person2: I...
Person1: ...position...
Person2: 'Mr Rothstein' is good enough.
Person1: Mr Rothstein... well, sometimes, when you reach that pressure point, when you put that pressure point on them, you know, it shows...
Person2: She could at least lose half a pound or a quarter.  Listen...
Person1: ...and she doesn't always -
Person2: ...all you do is give me answers. Just - just give me the right answer.
Person1: But, sir. Well, I don't know why. I guess, maybe, because she's frightened that if she doesn't lose the weight she may even get fired.
Person2: That's right. She will get fired. In fact, I want you to send her back to Paris.
Person1: It's always been our policy -
Person2: No. Just stop everything.

Person1: I'm supposed to be leaving on a fellowship that I worked for my entire life.  I don't even care.  I met this boy over the summer, and I, I can't see him because of this, I can't talk to him, I can't talk to my father about... I wore these clothes, I thought, I thought that if I looked right and if I acted right then someone would talk to me.  But I look awful and I feel awful, could you, could you please talk to me?  Be a little decent.
Person2: We believe that your father operates in a large pool of cash that comes from phoney billings, phoney patients.  We've been investigating him for five years.  We believe that when they die, he takes their money.
Person1: Pardon me?
Person2: Look, why don't you check it out for yourself?  See if your father fits the profile.
Person1: What's the profile?
Person2: Well, take a look around the house.  Is everything nice, but not too nice?  Are there lots of, uh, rugs, pieces of art, stereo equipment, uh, furniture, a lot of things bought with cash?  Does he give a lot of gifts?  Do the major items in your house cover around the nine thousand-dollar range?
Person1: You're trying to get me to say something, that's why you're telling me all of this.
Person2: Don't let your father's business infect your life.
Person1: How can you, how can you say that?
Person2: Because he's guilty.
Person1: No, no he's not.
Person2: We have records.  We have proof.  I'm sorry to be the one to have to tell you this, but it's going to get worse.  Now, if I were you, I would take that fellowship.

Person1: Hungry?
Person2: Just some coffee.
Person1: I'm not surprised. After all that humble pie...
Person2: Nothing of the kind. Karen and I had a nice talk.
Person1: Heart to heart? Woman to woman? Including a casual reference to the part of "Cora" - and your hopes of playing it.
Person2: I discussed it very openly. I told her that I had spoken to Lloyd - and that he was interested.
Person1: She mentioned, of course, that Margo expects to play the part?
Person2: Oddly enough - she didn't say a word about Margo. Just that she'll be happy to do what she can to see that I play the part.

Person1: Every day that goes by, I'm losing money. Every worker that is shot, costs me money - I have to get somebody else, I have to train them -
Person2: We're going to be making so much money, none of this is going to matter -
Person1: It's bad business.
Person2: Some of the boys went crazy, what're you going to do?  You're right, it's bad business, but it's over with, it's done.  Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make an example.  But that's good business.

Person1: We're recruiting.
Person2: Who's recruiting?
Person1: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...
Person2: Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!
Person1: Someone's got to do it, Henryk.
Person2: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...
Person1: Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?
Person2: Yes, please.
Person1: I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work...

Person1: Where do you think you're going?
Person2: Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?
Person1: Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!
Person2: Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!
Person1: You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!
Person2: I know, but --
Person1: You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!
Person2: Wait a minute -- wasn't it Stanley who discovered Livingstone?
Person1: Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!
Person2: I'd like to think.
Person1: Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.
Person2: I get it!
Person1: You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.
Person2: Let me get at that typewriter and I'll show you how a doll-faced mugg can write!
Person1: Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!
Person2: Whoa -- wait a minute. We can't leave Williams here. One of the other fellows'll --
Person1: We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?
Person2: That one -- how you gonna take him? They'll see him.

Person1: But, Leon, I am only here for a few days.
Person2: If you don't stay with me, I'll have to continue my fight. I'll travel wherever Russian commissions are. I'll turn them all into Buljanoffs, Iranoffs, and Kopalskis. The world will be crowded with Russian restaurants. I'll depopulate Russia. Once you saved your country by going back. This time you can save it by staying here.
Person1: Well, when it is a choice between my personal interest and the good of my country, how can I waver? No one shall say Ninotchka was a bad Russian.

Person1: Beth you're losing it.  C'mon.
Person2: C'mon -- what?
Person1: You're lying --
Person2: Am I lying?  Are you sure?  Are you absolutely sure I'm lying?  Then explain to me about the jellyfish.  Earlier.  Why did we see jellyfish?  Harry doesn't fear jellyfish.  You do.  They're your fear, aren't they?
Person1: But --
Person2: And the snakes?  You want to know about the snakes?  You saw one outside earlier, didn't you?  When you thought I had deserted you -- you were terrified.
Person1: That's when you went in the sphere.
Person2: One lonely, terrifying sea snake.
Person1: You manifested that, Beth.
Person2: Did I?  Or was that you?  When you were hiding in the bathroom -- all conspiratorially like you were -- you became frightened, didn't you?  Terrified.  Like you were with the snake earlier -- and suddenly you have snakes slithering all over the floor.  You did that, Norman.
Person1: You're insane.
Person2: Am I?  Or am I making so much sense that you're going insane?
Person1: I never went in that sphere.
Person2: You don't remember you did.  But I'm sure you remember running like some hero to get Harry, don't you?  You remember that.
Person1: Yes.
Person2: You remember before you picked him up -- when you looked up at the sphere, you remember that -- when the sphere opened?  That's right.  But you can't remember going inside, can you?  No, of course not.  Harry couldn't either, could he?  "Like everything's on the tip of my tongue", he said.
Person1: That's nonsense.
Person2: Is it?
Person1: Beth, the message said Harry.  "My name is Harry".  My name isn't Harry.
Person2: No, it isn't.  Your name is Norman. But your younger brother -- what was his name?  The one who was stung when you were younger.  The one that died. The one you couldn't save.  What was his name?  "Mommy, we're going out to the ocean -- to go swimming." "But I don't want to go swimming, Norman.  I'm scared." "C'mon, Harry, it'll be fine, it'll be fun."  You heartless fuck.  That's why you're so scared of the water, isn't it?
Person1: Stop it, Beth --
Person2: When you were in that sub -- and that squid was attacking you -- are you sure it was the squid that was attacking?  Do you know?  "I can't get Beth on the radio.  I'm in this tiny sub on the bottom of the ocean.  All alone.  Surrounded by all this water." Was it really the squid that was attacking you, Norman -- or was it something else -- one of your fears?  You never really saw what it was, did you?

Person1: Miss Beaufort has accepted our invitation.  By this we can only suppose that she wishes to come -- as we wish her to be here.
Person2: Your Majesty has had many women --
Person1: That is my desire, and my desire is what should concern you, not the sentiments of some commoner!
Person2: It is not Raoul's heart alone that concerns me.  It is yours.  I know you find women compliant -- especially the poorer ones like Michelle.  But do they love you?  Do you love them?  What about a queen to love?  A son of your own?
Person1: What quaint notions, d'Artagnan! But they contradict my father, who picked his queen when he was old, and only then to bear me.
Person2: There is more to love than he knew, or that you know.
Person1: You dare criticize my father?!  Or lecture me?!
Person2: Not criticize -- plead.  Love.  Love your people, and you will not bear to see them hungry.  Love women, and they will love you.  Love yourself, and --
Person1: That is enough!  You are a good servant, d'Artagnan, but you forget your place!
Person2: At least help Raoul.
Person1: Silence!  I order you!
Person2: Order Fromberge to keep him in safety!  It is the least you can do, to protect your own honor!
Person1: I will consider it.  Now leave me.
Person2: Thank you, your Majesty.

Person1: I'm very sorry about that. I apologize.
Person2: I accept. Now get out.

Person2: Didn't you hear what I said?
Person1: I don't care what you said, we had an agreement. You've slept with half of the borough so don't tell me you're being choosy.
Person2: Get out!
Person1: I'm giving you to the count of three to plop your ass down on the bed.
Person2: And if I don't?
Person1: Then I will consider it a declaration of war. One. Two... three.
Person2: I think you have your answer.
Person1: War it is.

Person2: Well, it's not really my job to please. Hope you learned something.

Person1: I will not stand for anything that's crooked or unfair; I'm strictly on the up and up, So everyone beware. If anyone's caught taking graft And I don't get my share, we'll stand 'em up against the wall - and pop goes the weasel!
Person2: So everyone beware Who's crooked or unfair; No one must take a bit of graft Unless he gets his share.
Person1: If any man should come between A husband and his bride, We find out which one she prefers By letting her decide.  If she prefers the other man, The husband steps outside; We stand him up against the wall And Pop goes the Weasel!
Person2: The husband steps outside; Relinquishes his bride; We stand him up against the wall And take him for a ride.
Person1: The population must increase With great rapidity.  We give a couple seven years To raise a family. If, by that time, there is no branch Upon the family tree, we stand 'em up against the wall - and Pop goes the Weasel.

Person1: Oh, I was going to discover the secret of the universe.  That's why I liked Nix.  He promised me all these explanations.
Person2: And he didn't have them?

Person2: Is that all?
Person1: No.  At the end... when we had him cornered, he got into my head. He showed me what we really look like, when the veneer's gone.  Jelly. Shit...
Person2: And you believed him?
Person1: I saw it with my own eyes! See, that's his best trick.  No illusions.  Just the truth.  Are you ready for that?

Person2: Week after I'm twenty-one.

Person2: Yeah, sit in a room and do long division for the next fifty years.
