Person2: Yeah, be a researcher.
Person1: It's a way outta here.
Person2: What do I want a way outta here for? I want to live here the rest of my life. I want to be your next door neighbor. I want to take out kids to little league together up Foley Field.
Person1: Look, you're my best friend, so don't take this the wrong way, but in 20 years, if you're living next door to me, coming over watching the Patriots' games and still working construction, I'll be really upset with you. And that's not a threat, that's a fact. I'll be really upset with you.
Person2: Chuckie, what are you talkin'...
Person1: Listen, you got somethin' that none of us have.
Person2: Why is it always this? I owe it to myself? What if I don't want to?
Person1: Forget you. You owe it to me. Tomorrow I'm gonna wake up and I'll be fifty and I'll still be doing this. And that's all right 'cause I'm gonna make a run at it. But you, you're sitting on a winning lottery ticket and you're too scared to cash it in. And that's nonsense 'cause I'd do anything to have what you got! And so would any of these guys. It'd be a real shame if you're still here in twenty years.
Person1: Let me tell you what I do know. Every day I come by to pick you up, and we go out drinkin' or whatever and we have a few laughs. But you know what the best part of my day is? The ten seconds before I knock on the door 'cause I let myself think I might get there, and you'd be gone. I'd knock on the door and you wouldn't be there. You just left.

Person2: I wish I could have made it, but I'm pretty sure it wasn't me.

Person2: Can you believe this?!

Person2: What?

Person1: Yes, you do. You always back down. You assume blame that isn't yours, you come in when called as opposed to enjoying your day off, you buckle like a belt.
Person2: You know what pisses me off the most?
Person1: The fact that I'm right about your buckling?
Person2: I'm going to miss the game.
Person1: Because you buckled.
Person2: Would you shut the hell up with that shit? It's not helping.
Person1: Don't yell at me, pal.
Person2: Sorry.
Person1: See? There you go again.
Person2: I can't believe I'm going to miss the game!
Person1: At least we're stuck here together.
Person2: You've got a customer.

Person1: Yeah, it is.
Person2: I never get my hair done.
Person1: No kidding.
Person2: In fact, I don't think I've ever been to a beauty parlor in my whole life.
Person1: No shit.
Person2: You think that's funny, don't you?
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: You live a phony cheap cop-out existence.
Person1: Yeah...
Person2: Beverly Hills hairdresser... what kind of a thing is that to do... you might as well be a faggot... think that's funny too?
Person1: No.
Person2: Then what do you think?
Person1: That you're just like your mother.
Person2: I am not like my mother!
Person1: You are.
Person2: I am not!
Person1: You are.

Person1: Will? Are you awake?
Person2: No.
Person1: Come with me to California.
Person2: What?
Person1: I want you to come with me.
Person2: How do you know that?
Person1: I know. I just do.
Person2: Yeah, but how do you know?
Person1: I don't know. I just feel it.
Person2: And you're sure about that?
Person1: Yeah, I'm sure.
Person2: 'Cause that's a serious thing you're sayin'. I mean, we might be in California next week and you could find out somethin' about me that you don't like. And you might feel like "hey this is a big mistake."  But you can't take it back, 'cause you know it's real serious and you can't take somethin' like that back. Now I'm in California, 'cause you asked me to come. But you don't really want me there. And I'm stuck in California with someone who really doesn't want me there and just wishes they had a take-back.
Person1: "Take-back?" What is that? I don't want a take-back. I want you to come to California with me.
Person2: I can't go out to California.
Person1: Why not?
Person2: One, because I have a job here and two because I live here--
Person1: Look, Will if you're not in love with me, you can say that.
Person2: I'm not sayin' I'm not in love with you.
Person1: Then what are you afraid of?
Person2: What do you mean "What am I afraid of?"
Person1: Why won't you come with me? What are you so scared of?
Person2: What am I scared of?
Person1: Well, what aren't you scared of? You live in your safe little world where nobody challenges you and you're scared shitless to do anything else--
Person2: --Don't tell me about my world. You're the one that's afraid. You just want to have your little fling with the guy from the other side of town and marry--
Person1: Is that what you think--
Person2: --some prick from Stanford that your parents will approve of. Then you'll sit around with the rest of the upper crust kids and talk about how you went slummin' too.
Person1: I inherited that money when I was thirteen, when my father died.
Person2: At least you have a mother.
Person1: Screw you! You think I want this? That money's a burden to me. Every day I wake up and I wish I could give that back. I'd give everything I have back to spend one more day with my father. But that's life. And I deal with it. So don't put that shit on me. You're the one that's afraid.
Person2: What am I afraid of?!
Person1: You're afraid of me. You're afraid that I won't love you back. And guess what? I'm afraid too. But at least I have the balls to it give it a shot. At least I'm honest with you.
Person2: I'm not honest?
Person1: What about your twelve brothers?
Person2: Oh, is that what this is about? You want to hear that I don't really have any brothers? That I'm a orphan? Is that what you want to hear?
Person1: Yes, Will. I didn't even know that?
Person2: No, you don't want to hear that.
Person1: Yes, I do, Will.
Person2: You don't want to hear that I got cigarettes put out on me when I was a little kid. That this isn't surgery

Person1: Nigel, get out of here. And don't come slithering back. Nigel shakes his head.
Person2: You need me, Selena. I'm the only one who can save you from a terrible fate.
Person1: I need you like an Eskimo needs a lawnmower. Now burn rubber.

Person1: Okay, I know what I want this time.
Person2: Anything you need.
Person1: Yo' cousin, Craig.  Hook us up.
Person2: That's it?
Person1: Just tell him to come over here and talk to me.
Person2: And I can go free?
Person1: Go, fo' I change my mind.

Person1: This is not a sexist thing. If you were a waiter I would still be here saying...
Person2: Are you totally gone? This is my private home...
Person1: I am trying to keep emotions out of this. Even though this is an important issue to me and I have strong feelings about the subject.
Person2: What subject? That I wasn't there to take crap from you and bring you eggs? Do you have any control over how creepy you allow yourself to get?
Person1: Yes, I do, as a matter of fact... and to prove it I have not gotten personal and you have. Why aren't you at work? You're not sick -- you don't look sick... just very tired and bitter.
Person2: My son is sick, okay?

Person1: Any particular reason?
Person2: Just a feeling.  Nothing personal.
Person1: You want to leave?
Person2: I don't know. Probably be best for everybody.
Person1: You may not care a lot about this place, Alice, but I mean to make it my whole life. It's been my whole life. Gimme a chance. Stay a week. Help get it ready. Next Friday, if you're not happy, I'll put you on the bus myself. I'll be grateful.

Person1: I have eighteen more minutes!
Person2: I don't want to hear any more today.
Person1: Why not?
Person2: Mr. Follett, do you trust me or don't you?
Person1: Well, I don't know... I only been seeing you --
Person2: Without trust, there's no point to any of this. You might as well not come.
Person1: Now hold on, I didn't say I didn't want to come --
Person2: Good, then go.

Person1: Drink up, Charley. We're ahead of you.
Person2: I'm not thirsty.
Person1: After what we been hearing about your brother, I thought your throat'd be kind of dry.
Person2: So they're walking along and smiling. That doesn't mean he's going to talk. There's no evidence until he gives public testimony.
Person1: Thanks for the legal advice, Charley. That's what we always kept you around for.  Now how do we keep him from giving this testimony? Isn't that the er as you put it main order of business?
Person2: He was always a good kid. You know that.

Person1: Where are you?
Person2: Closer than you think.
Person1: Alright I'm here. What do you want from me?
Person2: To see your reaction.
Person1: Reaction to what?

Person1: We have to prepare you for an audience with Sophie.
Person2: Who's Sophie?
Person1: Ah ... the Lady Sophie... The ravishing first cousin, once removed, from the Empress. We must convince Sophie that you are the Princess before we'll be granted a meeting with the Empress ... your grandmother, I mean.

Person1: What a thoughtful, ever-lovin' thing to do-
Person2: Bill? Have I gone crazy, Bill?
Person1: You're my girl, aren't you?
Person2: That I am...
Person1: Then you're crazy.
Person2: When - when are you coming back?
Person1: I leave in a week - the picture's all wrapped up, we previewed last night... those previews. Like opening out of town, but terrifying. There's nothing you can do, you're trapped, you're in a tin can-
Person2: - in a tin can, cellophane or wrapped in a Navajo blanket, I want you home...
Person1: You in a hurry?
Person2: A big hurry, be quick about it - so good night, darling, and sleep tight...
Person1: Wait a minute! You can't hang up, you haven't even said it-
Person2: Bill, you know how much I do - but over the phone, now really, that's kid stuff...
Person1: Kid stuff or not, it doesn't happen every day, I want to heat it - and if you won't say it, you can sing it...
Person2: Sing it?
Person1: Sure! Like the Western Union boys used to do...

Person1: Then say so.
Person2: Yes, Addison.
Person1: And you realize - you agree how completely you belong to me?
Person2: Yes, Addison.
Person1: Take your nap, now. And good luck for tonight.

Person1: Goddamn you, girl! You've made me make a fool out of myself, damn your hide, but let me tell you I am standing at the pass of Thermopylae and I won't budge! The very idea, my own home with children in the house, to say nothing of my wife -- oh-h, you had better believe I am standing at Thermopylae, you little nut, you had better believe it! What are you, crazy? A man is supposed to be a fool like this, but a woman is supposed to have some control and sense! Are you a nitwit? What's the matter with you?
Person2: Oh-h, I'm sorry. I'm sorry, Mr. Hillyer... I just... couldn't help myself. I'm sorry...

Person1: What are you doing here?
Person2: I don't think you locked your door.
Person1: What do you want?
Person2: See how easy it is? Perhaps Miss Mayfield left her door unlocked. Or if she didn't, there's a passkey on every floor in the linen room. The head porter has a passkey. The bell captain has a passkey. The hotel's full of passkeys.
Person1: Passkey?
Person2: Or--since one is a well-known and respected guest--one could go to the desk in the lobby and say "Miss Mayfield seems to have lost her room key--have you another"?  They always have another.
Person1: Don't be a fool. I loved him. He wasn't worth it, but I loved him.
Person2: And now that he's safe from all other women, you can go on loving him.
Person1: You nasty, sardonic--
Person2: Sardonic, if you will my dear. Bust nasty. You lied about the gun.

Person1: Well, as you know, most of my staff have weighed in against this "incursion."  They believe it will fail to achieve anything fundamental militarily, and will result in crushing criticism domestically ...
Person2: I didn't ask what your staff thinks, Henry.  What do you think?
Person1: What I think is ... they're cowards. Their opposition represents the cowardice of the Eastern Establishment.  They don't realize as you do, Mr. President, that the Communists only respect strength, and they will only negotiate in good faith if they fear the "madman," Richard Nixon.

Person1: Thank you for showing it to me first. I'll... I'll take care of it. Can I have the picture?

Person1: What?
Person2: When I asked Evan about his drawing, well, he didn't remember doing it.

Person1: I was wondering.
Person2: You're driving me crazy!  Do you know what it's like trying to jack-off in an armoire?

Person2: You're off, you know?  You're way, way off.
Person1: I thought I was helping you.
Person2: It would help me if I could kiss you.

Person2: What you think, you know, doesn't have much to do with reality.  I mean, I hope I'm not the first to say that about you.

Person2: Okay.  I guess.

Person1: Would it work?
Person2: Yes.  And I think we already know it will.
Person1: How's that?
Person2: Down below, Harry said we would all have to die.  Since there was no evidence on that spacecraft that anybody knew time travel through a black hole was possible -- and we all knew -- then we would all have to die before we could tell anyone. Death was the only logical explanation.  But sitting here, we still know.  So how is that possible?  Unless we make ourselves forget.

Person1: That was a mistake, Juno. Mark is a married stranger. You overstepped a boundary.
Person2: Listen, Bren-duhhh, I think you're the one overstepping boundaries. You're acting like you're the one who has to go through this and get huge and push a baby out of your vag for someone else. Besides, who cares if he's married? I can have friends who are married.
Person1: It doesn't work that way, kiddo. You don't know squat about the dynamics of marriage.
Person2: You don't know anything about me!
Person1: I know enough.

Person1: I thought we both wanted the same things.
Person2: I've changed my mind.

Person2: That's a lie!
Person1: Is it?  William says now you have requested a British Commission, why not colonial?  I'll clear it up for you, sir, because as a British officer you can lord over colonial yokels -- more than that, it will even get you into polite society! Your dream come true, George, the only dream that really matters to you.
Person2: Perhaps you've been counting my acres, Mrs. Fairfax, and discovered exactly how poor I really am.
Person1: Now that is a lie!  See how much you want to create a scandal in exchange for a glowing reputation and polite society laid at your feet!  When you break off your engagement to Martha Curtis, I'll divorce William!  Do you hear?  You get what you want from this world, then throw it all away on love!
Person2: I'd throw everything away for you.

Person1: Hey, 'Top.'  What's the op?

Person1: Get me out of here.
Person2: Where do you want to go?
Person1: Take me home.
Person2: Home?  This is your home. You're dead.
Person1: Dead? No. I just hurt my back. I'm not dead.
Person2: What are you then?
Person1: I'm alive.
Person2: Then what are you doing here?
Person1: I don't know. I don't know.  This isn't happening.
Person2: What isn't happening?
Person1: Let me out of here!
Person2: There is no out of here. You've been killed. Don't you remember?

Person1: Uh... hi. Uh... Enid's stepmother told me I'd find her here?
Person2: She's not at home?
Person1: No... they said she was here...
Person2: What the heck is she doing?! She was supposed to be here three hours ago!
Person1: Uh, do you mind if I wait? I really need to talk to her.
Person2: Are you sure she wasn't there?  Maybe she was just hiding from you.
Person1: Why would she be hiding from me?
Person2: I don't know... where is she, then?
Person1: Maybe she's with Josh?
Person2: Josh!? Why would she be with Josh?
Person1: I don't know.
Person2: Why? What did she tell you?
Person1: She just mentioned him a few times and said that they had been dating - I thought maybe she was...
Person2: What? Is she having some secret affair with Josh?
Person1: I have no idea - I just want to...
Person2: Why wouldn't she tell me? There's no way! She could never keep that to herself... you're crazy.
Person1: Really, I don't know enough about it to...
Person2: That person!
Person1: Why did you say she might be hiding from me? Did she say anything to you about me?
Person2: Yeah, she thinks you're a dork.
Person1: Did she say that?
Person2: Look, what do you expect?  Considering how we met you.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: On that pathetic fake blind date.
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: Didn't she ever tell you about that? God, she really is pathological...
Person1: What fake blind date? What are you talking about?

Person1: Go, Doctor.
Person2: What's your worst memory of childhood?  Quicker than that. I'm not interested in your worst invention.
Person1: The death of my father.
Person2: Tell me. Don't lie, or I'll know.

Person1: For God's sake, will you please go now?  We gave you every nickel we got.
Person2: You're goin' outside with me.  If there's no cops around, we just split.  Otherwise, you go with us.

Person1: Maybe I do.
Person2: Or maybe you just think you do. Just another small town. One guy chasing you. You go big town. Just gonna have four guys after you instead. Kiss kissy kiss. It gets down to one thing -- are you a human being or are you one of those hungry ghosts out there never satisfied with nothing? Cause you gotta remember you can run just as far as you can, but wherever you go, that's where you gonna be.
Person1: I think I've heard that before.
Person2: What do you want for free?
Person1: You sure got a lot of philosophy, old man.
Person2: Seems like I do but only cause end of the day we're all eyes in the same head. And everything is everything.
Person1: What?
Person2: ...And everything is nothing too.

Person1: I'm going to keep an eye on that Kringelein fellow. I'll find out where he gets the money to hang around the Grand Hotel.
Person2: Well -- you want me?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Well?
Person1: I must go to England -- at once.
Person2: Well?
Person1: You see, I'd like to take a secretary with me for my correspondence and -- humm -- humm -- for company on the trip -- I'm nervous -- I need somebody -- I don't know if you quite understand me. You said you have travelled with gentlemen -- and I mean --
Person2: I understand perfectly.
Person1: What do you think your salary would be -- for such a trip?
Person2: Wait -- I must figure it up.  First, I'll need -- clothes -- shoes -- it's cold in England in March, I'll need a suit... You'd want me to look nice?
Person1: Of course -- of course.
Person2: A thousand marks --
Person1: It's agreed -- I will get a room here for you.

Person1: You can.  You're full of ideas.  You just need to squeeze one out.
Person2: I can't...
Person1: You got till the count of three. Then you end up like him.

Person1: We had a court-martial in your absence. They wanted to put a bullet in your head. I pleaded for clemency. Said we should find out what happened first. So what did happen?
Person2: He ran. I couldn't shoot him in the back. I tried to catch him. He made it to the road and got hit by a Saracen.
Person1: So you did mess up.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: But you know what the thing is, Fergus?
Person2: No, what is the thing?
Person1: You vanished quite effectively. Became Mister Nobody. And you've no idea how useful that could be.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: We've got some plans here. And we'll need a Mister Nobody to execute them.
Person2: No way, Jude. I'm out.
Person1: You're never out, Fergus.

Person1: You guys are crazy.  What the hell you play that stupid game for?
Person2: What game, Cobb?...I'm on my way to Nirvana...
Person1: You're on your way somewhere all right...the looney bin.
Person2: I'm on the way to the looney bin?  Hey, man, I'm not the dude sun bathing in his clothes.

Person1: I said, 'Next time, phone ahead.'
Person2: Jesus Christ. Mr. Gordon, when I come all the way to serve somebody a summons, I don't call ahead for an appointment.
Person1: What the hell are you talking about?
Person2: I'm issuing you a ticket. Moving violation.
Person1: Moving violation! I just got out of bed and you're telling me you're giving me a goddamn speeding ticket? Now? Are you nuts? Is that it, Whitehouse? You're nuts?
Person2: Yesterday morning, you passed a stopped school bus, which was flashing its lights, then you--
Person1: Hold on!
Person2: Don't ever put your hands on me, Mr. Gordon.
Person1: You're talking about a goddamned ticket, from when I passed you at the school where you were deciding to hold up traffic while dreaming of becoming a traffic cop or something?
Person2: Don't give me a hard time, Mr. Gordon. I'm just --
Person1: Doing your job. I know. I watch television too.
Person2: Yes. Here's your ticket.
Person1: You get the hell out of my house now, asshole. And know this -- you are going to be a lucky asshole if I haven't got you fired before the day is out. I can do it with one phone call, and I'm pissed enough to do it now!

Person1: There's no point in helping some of them when there are so many others.
Person2: I know perfectly well how little I can do. What I want to do is give passing beggars a roof, some food, and a bit of human warmth.
Person1: Is that all you're going to devote your life to?
Person2: I'm not sure yet. I've had a shock recently, and I'm only beginning to get over it. Perhaps I'll go back to the convent one day.

Person1: You're really serious, aren't you?
Person2: Yes, I am.
Person1: But what about the past? Our past?
Person2: We never really shared one.
Person1: You're inhuman.
Person2: I'm...in touch with humanity. Evelyn, I'm sorry.  You're just not terribly important to me.

Person1: The thing about it is, threesomes so rarely work out.
Person2: You're out of your mind.
Person1: I've been a cop for a while, Kelly.  It's hard enough for one person to keep a secret, let alone three.  And then there's the love angle.  I mean do you and Sam really want that little pill-head around, now that you have the money?

Person1: Elaborate on 'they,' okay?
Person2: There are all kinds of groups, all kinds of initials.  But they're all part of two warring factions. One: families that have held wealth for centuries. They want one thing.  Stability. Group Two:  the boat rockers. Eisenhower's military industrial complex.  They want instability. It's a trillion dollar a year business.  When there isn't a hot war, they make a cold one.
Person1: Cold War's over, Jerry.
Person2: So now they feed us terrorists. To create fear.  How much do you think an airport security system goes for?  Then multiply it by every airport in the country.
Person1: And you think Group One is at war with Group Two.
Person2: Latest casualty?  Ernest Harriman. You heard of him?
Person1: Sure. One of the richest men in America until he died a few days ago.
Person2: His obituary was in every paper. But not one of them said he was murdered.
Person1: Murdered?
Person2: Right here in Manhattan.
Person1: It said in the paper he drowned in a swimming pool.  In Newport.
Person2: Nobody dies in Newport.  They couldn't even kill Sunny von Bulow there.  Harriman drowned, but it wasn't in Newport.
Person1: Where then?

Person1: Remember, you promised... no screwing around.
Person2: Did I promise that? I don't remember that...
Person1: You're really pissing me off.

Person1: Twenty-seven fifty-three... do you see it?  That must be it...
Person2: Great...
Person1: What?! It looks totally normal... what's wrong with it?
Person2: I said "great"...
Person1: Oh yeah, I can tell you really love it!
Person2: Well, what am I supposed to say? "I can't wait to live in some depressing shit-hole in the middle of nowhere"?!
Person1: There's something wrong with every single place we look at! Why don't you just come right out and tell me you don't want to move in with me?!
Person2: Because you'll freak out and act like a total psycho about it.

Person1: Someday you'll have a son just like you, Jeremiah. A boy who lies through his teeth, buys demonic records, and smokes the dope just like you.
Person2: If I'm anything like you, I'll deserve him.
Person1: What?!
Person2: I said, I'm sorry!
Person1: If you truly are sorry, son, then you better pray like you've never prayed before. God willed me to find those tickets because He wanted to hear from you.  He knows you need help and He wants you to ask Him for it.

Person1: I won't have another mate like ONA.  You rate very high in sanitation.  I've checked.  In fact, I am surprised that you were ever matched with LUH.  Her ratings are very erratic - you know what I mean.  We'll be happy.

Person1: The army needs you.

Person2: Christ, George, Joseph Reed's been writing letters back to Congress attacking you.  Your own aide!

Person1: Well, your condition's pretty serious.
Person2: So they say. What?
Person1: I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable?

Person1: My Westley will always come for me.

We'll run up the white flag and deliver your message. If Westley wants you, bless you both. If not ... please consider me as an alternative to suicide. Are we agreed?

Person1: We gotta face some facts here.
Person2: What facts are those?

Person1: Friends call me Otis - sometimes Tricky Otis.

Person1: I...Liz...all I ever wanted, was for you to be happy. I just wanted to give you the wedding, the life you always dreamed of...  ...I just love you so much...So much...

Person1: Money never sleeps pal. When I came in in '69, they traded six hours a day, now the clock don't stop, London's deregulated, the Orient is hungrier than us. Just let the money circle the world, sport, buying and selling, and if you're smart it comes back paying. I just made $800,000 in Hong Kong gold. It's been wired to you -- play with it. You done good, but you gotta keep doing good. I showed you how the game works, now school's out.
Person2: Mr. Gekko, I'm there for you 110%.
Person1: You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, sport, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it... My wife tells me you put a move on Darien. Here's some inside info for you. That Euroflash GQ guy she's going with's got big bucks but he's putting her feet to sleep. Exit visas are imminent. So don't lose your place in line.  Oh, jeez, I wish you could see this. The lights coming up over the water. I've never seen a painting that captures the beauty of the ocean at this moment.  ...an old Russian proverb - "a fisherman always sees another fisherman from afar." I like you sport, I ever tell you that... Gordon, call me Gordon from now on.
Person2: ...Gordon.
Person1: Yeah, I'm gonna make you rich, Bud Fox. I'm gonna make you rich enough you can afford a girl like Darien. Remember, power is the best aphrodisiac. This is your wake-up call. Go to work.

Person1: What do I have to do for it?
Person2: Nothing, Wade, I've been thinking. You don't get enough appreciation around here and it's time we changed things a little.
Person1: I saw Mel Gordon in here this morning.
Person2: So?

Person2: Wade, that wasn't smart. Going out right after the man's father-in-law shot himself. Let it go. Call it a favor to me.

Person2: What's the difference? Take my truck, take a rest -- stop worrying about Mel Gordon. Have you decided what to do with your old man's place -- he going to stay there?
Person1: Want to buy?
Person2: Don't light that in here. I'm allergic.
Person1: I won't. You interested?
Person2: Maybe.
Person1: You and Mel Gordon?
Person2: Could be.
Person1: Always count on old Wade for a good screwing. Why should I always pay more, sell cheap? Why should you guys make all the money. You and Mel and Jack. Right's right.

Person1: Are we going to get the ball rolling?
Person2: What are you talking about?  What do you think I'm doin'?  I'm gettin' the ball rollin'.  I'm keeping these people happy ... I'm keeping you happy ... I gotta keep the cops cooled out ... I gotta do everything ... I gotta pay for the pizza ... I'm workin' on it, do you know what I mean?  I'm workin' on it ... Jesus Christ!  I gotta do it all ... I got all the ideas ... you want me to give you the gun?  You want to take it over?

Person1: Getting anywhere with those?
Person2: There's some sort of pattern here. It'll take a minute.
Person1: Have you looked outside?  Jellyfish. Everywhere.  I hate jellyfish.  Harry, what happened in the cafeteria?
Person2: Don't do this.  Don't psychoanalyze me.  I hate squid.  Period.  Just like you hate jellyfish.
Person1: You said something to me, before -- about how we were all going to die.
Person2: Did I?
Person1: You don't remember that?
Person2: I don't remember much.  It's like my memory is on the tip of my tongue -- but I can't taste any of it.  Funny, my senses are much keener though. Purer.  Hearing, seeing, smelling. Like, I can smell your sheets, Norman.  You tried to wash it out earlier, But I can still smell the urine.  Don't worry, I'm not going to tell the others.  It's normal, really, isn't it?  In a crisis.  The stress. The panic.

Person1: Hello, Gabriel.
Person2: When you call me Gabriel, I know I've got trouble.
Person1: Where've you been?
Person2: Working...I'm trying to figure out where to start.
Person1: Maybe I can help. Let's see... if one night I got up and packed up all my things and drove away without leaving so much as a note, and stayed away for months, I think what I'd want to do is come up with a well thought-out reason.
Person2: After the funeral I just had to leave.
Person1: Had to leave?  Believe me, we all wanted to leave...but you know what?  We stayed.
Person2: A lot of things fell apart up there.
Person1: I know...
Person2: I don't think you do.
Person1: Why can't you believe that you did everything you could?
Person2: Did I?  I don't know.  Maybe I shouldn't have gone out on that line.  Maybe I panicked.
Person1: I was there, you were the only one who didn't panic.  So do everyone a favor, don't hog all the guilt.  You held on as long as you could.  Yes, everything did go wrong, starting with Hal. I mean, what was he doing up on the Tower with a girl who could barely climb?
Person2: I can't blame anything on Hal. It was me.  I play it back in my mind everyday.
Person1: Then turn it off, Gabe, because it doesn't get any better.
Person2: I don't expect you to understand.
Person1: I don't understand?
Person2: You couldn't.
Person1: You're saying, I don't understand?  I'm the only one who does understand.  I'm the one you lived with for two years, I'm the one you made promises to, I'm the one who spent too many nights looking up at these rocks and wondering if you were ever going to make it down in once piece or ever at all.  Believe me, there's been times I didn't know what I wanted to do more, love you or hate you.  But the one thing in our relationship that I did know and still do know is that I understand you.
Person2: Why are you yelling?
Person1: Excuse me?
Person2: Why are you yelling?
Person1: Did I miss something?
Person2: Y'know, yelling at this altitude can lead to hyperventilation and fainting--
Person1: I'm not going to faint, but if I want to faint, I'll faint, okay?
Person2: Okay, but if you do I'll have to perform resuscitation--
Person1: Resuscitation?
Person2: --mouth-to-mouth, which could maybe...
Person1: Which could maybe what?
Person2: Maybe lead to a flare up...
Person1: A flare up...
Person2: Flare up of old emotions...
Person1: Listen to you...  The old "mouth-to-mouth" resuscitation routine, huh?
Person2: From one professional to another, of course.
Person1: Course maybe you don't have to wait until I faint.
Person2: No, I think I will, it's safer. I have patience.

Person1: Take me down. Let me talk to Picard.
Person2: Talk... we should send down an assault team and take them by force.
Person1: That is not an acceptable option. If people get hurt, all the support we have in the Federation...
Person2: Federation support, Federation procedures, Federation rules... look in the mirror, Admiral... the Federation is old... in the last twenty four months, it's been challenged by every major power in the quadrant -- the Borg, the Cardassians, the Dominion... they all smell the scent of death on the Federation. That's why you've embraced our offer... because it will give your dear Federation new life. Well, how badly do you want it, Admiral? Because there are hard choices to be made now. If the Enterprise gets through with news about their brave Captain's valiant struggle on behalf of the defenseless Ba'ku, your Federation politicians will waver, your Federation opinion polls will open a public debate, your Federation allies will want their say... need I go on?

Person1: And?  Then?
Person2: I wonder no longer.  You were out of the country.
Person1: How could you know?
Person2: I sense...  The faintest whiff of a perfume, whose base, whose base, whose base is "Hamamelis" ... it is witch-hazel--such a clean scent.  No, not a European scent. I would say it is a scent of the New World.  I would say, you have been in America.  Have I struck home?
Person1: You know America?
Person2: ...you have brought this perfume... brought this perfume.  Back.  Back from America.  To your New Wife...  You have given it to her, and some of...  Some of 'her perfume' has found its way back onto you.  Lucky man.  Lucky man, indeed.

Person1: -- and when my husband died I felt helpless. They disobeyed me -- things went from bad to worse. All my husband's dreams of good health, good sanitation, good morals for these sweet and gentle people seemed to die with him.  Then, almost accidentally, I discovered the secret of how to deal with them. There was a girl with a baby -- again and again I begged her to boil the drinking water. She never would. Then I told her the god, Shango, would be pleased and kill the evil spirits in the water if she boiled it. She boiled the water from then on.
Person2: But you didn't have to come up here.
Person1: Perhaps not.  But I did come here and I found it was so simple to let the gods speak through me. Once started, it seemed such an easy way to do good.  I should have known there was no easy way to do good, Betsy.

The keys to my store, the codes to my locks, the life, the blood of my bussiness and return is smashing in seven-eleven, late, always late, loans -- I loaned you money for your kitchen that you never did --

Person2: Two years! Two years later and out of your paycheck, I never charge interest --
Person1: Solomon, please.  Please.  I am so messed here if you do this.  This is the worst timing. The worst timing I could ever imagine. I need to keep working.  I have so many debts, so many things, I have, I have, I have -- I have surgery -- I have my oral surgery coming --

In the middle of all this I start to think about something that does nothing but make me feel good and makes immediate sense and that's you ...And I'll stop here but, Jane, I'd give anything if you were two people so I could call up the one who's my friend and tell her about the one I'm in I...I don't think I should go any further.  Come on -- I'll walk you to the corner.

Has this cocksucker ever been...you ever sit down with a cust...

After that I figure she'll tell the Police that you broke in.  That you were crazed because we humiliated you in court?

Person1: You see, Karl, growing up, only knew that sex was wrong and that people who did it should be killed for it. He couldn't really read but, well, neither could his mother. But, his father made sure that his mother knew what the Bible said. And she made sure Karl knew. You know he slept in a hole in the ground under a toolshed, right?
Person2: I knew he slept in a toolshed.
Person1: His mother told him that he was their punishment. Hers and his father's; from God, for having sex--
Person2: Before they were married?
Person1: I don't think so. Just period, I think. She told him... God gave them the ugliest creation he could think of. Karl has an entire book -- a notebook. On every page it says "Franklin Chapter 1 Verse number 1." He wrote that a few years ago after he'd learned to write. His father's name was Franklin.
Person2: That's really strange. What does it mean?
Person1: One of his Daddy's Bible lessons I imagine. Y'all pull up a chair. I'll go out and talk to him.

Person1: You killed them.
Person2: It was only a matter of time before somebody killed somebody.  You saw it coming as well as I did. Dodge had his plans, starting with scuttling the boat. And Greer too, except he went nuts. Couldn't take it, I guess. Could've happened in the middle of downtown Anchorage. But did it make him any less dangerous? I don't think so.
Person1: So you killed them?
Person2: The way I figure it, it was them or me. I thought putting Dodge up on that pipe was a nice touch? Bought a little time. Made it look like whoever killed those Greeks was still around. But it's just us on this ship. Us and your... spirit friends.
Person1: And now you're gonna kill me, is that it?
Person2: I didn't want it to turn out this way.
Person1: Murphy, don't you see what's happening?
Person2: I think I see it pretty well.
Person1: It's the ship. The ship's making you think this way.
Person2: I know a little bit about human nature and what I've seen only confirms that.
Person1: It's a trap. There was no way we were gonna get away with that gold. Nobody ever does. It's just the bait. This ship sucks people in and it never lets them out.
Person2: I think maybe you been on this boat a little too long, with all that supernatural mumbo jumbo. There's nothing supernatural about greed. And that's what it comes down to, pure and simple.
Person1: I don't give a damn about the gold.
Person2: I wish I could believe that. Either way, you know what I've done. I've got no choice.

Person1: Captain, I've been observing the nurses on your shift. But naturally your own opinion is more informed than mine.

Person2: And his track record, that don't count? Look, honey, when you watch the two shifts try to notice which one does the most work with the least fuss.

Person1: That kind of familiarity is inconsistent with maximum efficiency in a military organization.
Person2: Okay, Major, honey.  I'm going to have a couple shots scotch and go to bed. I'd normally ask you to join me but obviously you're a female version of the routine Regular Army clown. And that turns me off, so just leave my outfit alone and we'll get along fine.  See you around the campus.
Person1: I wonder how a degenerated person like you could have reached a position of responsibility in the Army Medical Corps.
Person2: Sister, if I knew the answer to that I sure as hell wouldn't be here.

Person1: Why, Buddy, shut your mouth! What an awful thing to say, and where did you get any such idea as that, anyhow?

Person1: Now, let's free ourselves from emotionalism and try to solve the problem in a practical way. Our situation has changed considerably. Before I had only a claim to the jewels. Now I have the jewels.
Person2: In other words moral ideas have no weight with you... all right, then let's deal with legal facts. You know that France has recognized the Soviet.
Person1: Unfortunately.
Person2: Under Soviet law the jewels belong to the State. France is going to uphold that ownership.
Person1: My lawyer agrees with you. He says France will uphold it in every court, but I will drag you through every court, don't forget that. And when I say it will take two years I am, as always, conservative.
Person2: Won't those two years in court be expensive for you? I know that money was no object as long as you could squeeze it from the pockets of the people, but now...
Person1: I may run out of money, but you have already run out of bread. Two years is a long time for your comrades to wait.
Person2: I see. You have calculated in terms of hunger.
Person1: No, I just wanted to be absolutely impartial. Both of us are faced with two rather uncomfortable years. We can condense these two years to two minutes if you want to accept my proposition. Ninotchka now realizes what she is after.
Person2: Go on.
Person1: I am willing to hand over the jewels and sign the necessary papers if you take that five-forty plane to Moscow.
Person2: That's not the way to win him back... not Leon.
Person1: I think I know Leon quite as well as you... possibly a little better. Leave that worry to me. Five-forty leaves you time enough to close the deal with Monsieur Mercier, but naturally you'll be too busy for any farewells. I'll see to it that everything is done in the most expeditious manner and I will also see you to the airport. That's my proposition, Comrade Yakushova.

You be as cold as you want. A child would know it, he's right.  You're going to make something up, be sure it will help or keep your mouth closed.

And I, I decided to complicate my life. For a guy who likes sure things, I was about to bet the rest of my life on a real longshot.

What is love anyway?  It's a... it's a mutual respect. It's - it's a devotion. It's a... it's a caring from one person to another. And if we could set up some kind of foundation...  based on that mutual respect...  I feel that eventually you would care enough about me... that I could live with that.

Person1: You know what I love about all this?

Person1: You're strapped into an implant chair, and I'm monitoring you at a psycho-probe console.
Person2: Oh, I get it; I'm dreaming!  And this is all part of that delightful vacation your company sold me.
Person1: Not exactly.  What you're experiencing is a free-form delusion based on our memory tapes.  But you're inventing it yourself as you go along.
Person2: Well, if this is my delusion, who invited you?
Person1: I've been artificially implanted as an emergency measure.  I'm sorry to tell you this, Mr. Quaid, but you've suffered a schizoid embolism. We can't snap you out of your fantasy. I've been sent in to try to talk you down.
Person2: How much is Cohaagen paying you for this?
Person1: Think about it.  Your dream started in the middle of the implant procedure. Everything after that--the chases, the trip to Mars, your suite here at the Hilton--these are all elements of your Rekall Holiday.  And Ego Trip. You paid to be a secret agent.
Person2: Bullshit.  It's all coincidence.
Person1: What about the girl?  Brunette, athletic, sleazy and demure; just like you specified.  Is that a coincidence?
Person2: She's real.  I dreamed about her before I even went to Rekall.
Person1: Mr. Quaid, can you hear yourself? "She's real because you dreamed her?"
Person2: That's right.

Person1: Is this my fault? Do you think this is what I am?
Person2: What?
Person1: This is not me! I am a professional thief. I steal money. You try to stop me, god help you. But I don't kill people I don't have to, and I don't rape women. What you doin' ain't how it's done. Do you understand?
Person2: Seth, if you were me --
Person1: Just say yes! Nothing else, just say yes.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Yes, Seth, I understand.
Person2: Yes, Seth, I understand.

Person1: I'm not interested in what you think.

Person1: I tell you, I'm not interested in your opinion.
Person2: No?  Then maybe you'll understand, Mrs. Dickson. Oh, gee, he's crazy about you. Nobody knows it better than you. If he ever finds out, it'll kill him.

Person1: I'll tell you something, Annie -- I stood there looking at what was happening to that horse... And, I swear, it felt like the same thing was happening to me.
Person2: I don't understa-
Person1: And I have two choices. I can either fight the way things are, or accept them.  See, I always knew I loved you more. Didn't bother me. I always felt lucky... a little amazed... that such a vibrant, beautiful woman would want to be with a man like me... And I guess I thought as long as I did everything right -- if I was the best husband I could be, the best father... even being a good lawyer only mattered to me because of what it meant for us... if I could do all that, it wouldn't make any difference if we loved each other the same or not... I wasn't asking for more. I told myself I didn't need more.  But you don't know how you feel about me. You don't know... if you want a life with me anymore...  And I don't want you to come home until you do know...  ... one way or the other.

Person1: Without you, my dearest, I might have died without ever knowing love. Inexpressible love!  God of nature! Bitterness than which nothing is sweeter, sweetness than which nothing is more bitter.  Divine monster which can only be defined by paradoxes.
Person2: Let me give a thousand kisses to that heavenly mouth which has told me that I am happy.
Person1: As soon as I saw you loved me, I was pleased, and I gave you every opportunity to fall more in love with me, being certain that, for my part, I would never love you.  But after our first kiss, I found that I had no power over myself.  I did not know that one kiss could matter so much.

Person1: You called me twenty minutes ago and said you had it! Ready to make delivery, ya says! Come on down and get it!  And here ya are and you're wastin' my time and you're wastin' my wife's time and I'm payin' nineteen- five for this vehicle here!

They couldn't give a flyin' fuck if all the pimps in the whole wide world took two in the back of the head. If you don't get caught at the scene with the smokin' gun in your hand, you got away with it.

Person1: No. No. No. It's what my father said to me. He said it and he meant it... He said to me...He said, Adam, he said...He told me and I heard him... he said...  Hell he said so many Goddamn things I can't remember everything he said for Christsake.

And her hair smells sweet and she's your's. She's all your's. Do you see where I'm going here?

Person1: I'm sorry, Miss Arroway, not only is it too Speculative a subject for a doctoral dissertation, at this point in your career it'd be tantamount to suicide.
Person2: I'm willing to take that risk.
Person1: I'm not.  You're far too promising a scientist to waste your considerable gifts on this nonsense --
Person2: Dr. Drumlin, we are talking about what could potentially be the most important discovery in the history of humanity.  There are over four hundred billion stars out there --
Person1: And only two probabilities: One: there is intelligent life in the universe but they're so far away you'll never contact it in your lifetime --
Person2: You're --
Person1: Two: There's nothing out there but noble gasses and carbon compounds and you'd be wasting your time.
Person2: What if you're wrong?  No -- I'll grant you probabilities but as a scientist without all the evidence -- you can't deny the possibility -- and I believe even the remotest possibility of something this profoundly... profound is worth investigation -- and worth taking a few risks.
Person1: I disagree.
Person2: Then disagree but don't stand in my way!

Person1: It's going to be a long night.  It could take hours before we know something.  You should try to eat.

Person2: I want you to take care of Sailor, so he won't ever be able to bother my baby again.
Person1: Take care of him?
Person2: Yes.

Person2: What's with you? You know what take care of him means. I don't call Santos except for one big reason.

Person2: I want you to get rid of Sailor.
Person1: Get rid of him?
Person2: Yes... Get rid of him.
Person1: How would I do that? Send him on a trip - like maybe to Hawaii?
Person2: Santos, why in hell do you insist on playin' this stupid game?
Person1: Just tell me what you want.
Person2: I don't need to explain anymore'n I have... You know damn well.
Person1: You need to explain it.
Person2: All right... I want you... to... kill... Sailor... As simple as that.
Person1: Simple? Kill him? How?
Person2: That's your business... I don't care how.
Person1: Like an accident where maybe Lula might also get hurt?
Person2: NO... For God's sakes, Santos!
Person1: Well, like kill him with the atomic bomb?
Person2: Santos...
Person1: Explain it... I told you.
Person2: Shoot him.
Person1: Shoot him? Like with a gun?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Where? In the leg?
Person2: No.
Person1: Where?
Person2: In the head.
Person1: Shoot Sailor in the head with a gun... Now I'm beginning to get it... You want me to shoot Sailor in the head with a gun.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: But where in the head? Not the chin, I hope.
Person2: No... In the brains... What little I'm sure he has.
Person1: You want me to shoot Sailor in the brains with a gun.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Through the forehead?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Wrong! It's much better to blow a hole in the back of the head... right toward the bridge of the nose... Lots and lots of irreparable damage.
Person2: See! I knew you had it all under control.
Person1: Why didn't you send Johnnie Farragut?
Person2: Maybe I did... Try New Orleans first... Lula can't ever stop talkin' 'bout that town.
Person1: On one condition...

Person1: Between 50 and 400 million, definitely?
Person2: Uh-huh.
Person1: And if you had to guess ...
Person2: With nothing linking it to the corporate offices yet, I'd say we'll end up on the lower end of that.  Still a lot of money.

Person2: Because.  They know the evidence; they know they're gonna lose a jury trial.  Maybe they wouldn't lose 400 million bucks, but once you factor in all they'd spend on this case in the next ten years, it makes a lot of --
Person1: Wait, what do you mean, ten years?
Person2: Five years, maybe, for a trial.  Double that for the appeal.
Person1: I'm sorry, are you saying that if this thing goes to trial, it'll be ten years before these plaintiffs see their money?
Person2: Hey, that's not so bad.  Compare it to the Love Canal -- that was twenty years ago, and those people still haven't seen a dime.  So in legal terms, ten years is --
Person1: Forget legal terms.  We're talking about human beings here.  Sick people.  A whole bunch of them are gonna be dead in ten years.  They need their money now!  We gotta get 'em to agree to the arbitration, Ed.  We gotta get every damn one of those plaintiffs to --
Person2: I know.  We're having a meeting, it's all set up --
Person1: When?  Where?
Person2: Tuesday at seven, at the Hinkley firehouse.
Person1: Okay, good.  I think I should be the one to tell 'em, cause they trust me more than --
Person2: You're not gonna be there.
Person1: I absolutely will be there.  I don't care what the doctor says --
Person2: This isn't doctor's orders.  It's mine.  I'm saying you can't come.
Person1: Why not?
Person2: Because Kurt doesn't want to work with you. He thinks you're a loose cannon.
Person1: Forget Kurt.
Person2: Erin --
Person1: No, I'm serious.  You know what Kurt Potter is?  He's the kind of guy who never would have taken this case in the first place. He's the kind of guy who would have sold these plaintiffs down the river when PG&E offered 20 million.  He doesn't work like us, Ed.  There's no little voice in his head telling him to do the right thing.

Person1: How long have I been here?

You're like some kind of antidote that mixes the liquor and keeps me in balance, but that won't last forever. You'll get tired of it really quickly. Believe me.

Person1: You're full of ifs.

Person1: You know what? I've been here since I was fourteen and I remember like yesterday when Baby Suggs, holy, came here and sat right where you are. Whiteman name of Garner brought her. He and Mr. Bodwin were good friends. That's how she got that house you all live in. Other things too.
Person2: Yes ma'am.
Person1: I never went to those woodland services but she was always nice to me. Always. Never be another like her.
Person2: I miss her.
Person1: Bet you do. Everybody miss her. That was a good woman...Well, I don't know whether the Bodwins think it or not but they sure could use some extra help.
Person2: Ya think?
Person1: They getting older now and I can't take care of 'em like I used to. More and more they keep asking me to sleep over night. Now, I don't want to quit these people but they can't have all my days and nights too. I got my own family needs me. It'll take some convincing but maybe you could come after supper - take care of your mama during the day, then earn a little something at night, how's that?
Person2: Fine. But what would I do at night?
Person1: Be here. In case.
Person2: In case of what?
Person1: In case the house burn down or bad weather slops the roads so bad I can't get here on time or late guests needed cleaning up after. Anything.  Don't ask me what whitefolks need at night.

Person1: No, of course not... I never killed anyone...

Person2: You didn't see the expression you had on your face when you pulled the trigger. But I did.  You kind of liked it, didn't you? That thrill of going over the edge again. Of taking out an innocent bystander or two, as long as you got the target...

Person2: It was just like before, wasn't it? Wasn't it?  But you are making progress. Instead of killing seven people to get the one you're after, this time there was only one other person involved.

Person1: Barry, I'm completely broke! I know we used to mess with anyone who asked for anything we didn't like, but it's gotta stop.

Now all of a sudden I'm offending your golf buddy.  You're right, Rob.  I am so sorry. How are we ever going to make enough money to get you and Laura into the country club?

Person1: Good afternoon.

I really went on my own business, to see a man that I happen to be in love with... and I'm glad I did it, but I'm sorry about the policy and I'll be happy to make up the money the company didn't get... of course just now I don't have...  One million, four hundred and ten thousand dollars.  But if you were to dock my salary, say, twenty dollars a week, in a few hundred years we'd be even... and I think this is where you fire me?
Person1: You're right.  You're fired.

Person1: Because you were spoiled, don't try to spoil Sunny.

We would get up with the chickens. Every summer the fence had to be repaired. The barn needed a coat of paint. We had to pip all of Big Mama's hundred laying hens and go to church all day on Sunday. For Big Daddy, calluses and sweat were the mark of a man. Sunny will never have to bust his knuckles like we did.

Person1: They buried my ma & pa and my sisters. And Chingachgook - who found me with two French trappers - raised me up as his own.
Person2: I'm sorry.

Person1: My father sent Uncas & I to Reverend Wheelock's school when I was ten. So we would know both worlds... though we were told only bother learning readin' & arithmetic from yours.
Person2: And what were the consequentialities of European culture you didn't bother with?
Person1: The Bible. Monarchy. Many wrong ideas about the government of men. My father's people already know each man is his own nation. And only he can have dominion over himself. Not kings. No man is better than any other man.
Person2: In London those radical ideas could land you in Newgate prison.  Why were those people living in this defenseless place...?
Person1: 'Cos frontier land's the only land affordable to poor people. So after seven years indentured service in Virginia, they headed out here where they are beholden to none and not livin' by another's leave...  Their name was Cameron. John & Alexandria.

Person1: Tell me, Vincent.  Do you believe in Santa Claus?
Person2: Can't say that I do.
Person1: Neither do I.  But my children, they're still young.  Do you know who they like even more than jolly old Saint Nicholas?  His helper, Black Peter. An old Russian fairy tale tells of how Santa got so busy looking after all the good kids, he had to hire a helper to punish all the bad kids.  That was Black Peter's job.  He was given the list of all the bad children, and he would visit them in their homes late at night.  And if he caught them not saying their prayers, he would leave a bundle of wooden switches outside their door.  That was a warning.  If they continued to misbehave, he would swoop down and take the children away. And they would never be seen again.

Person1: Well, if my intentions are what you think they are -- if I do wish to step into your shoes, what then?  I have no other intentions than you had yourself.  Lady Cosgrove's wealth may be great, but am I not of a generous nature enough to use it worthily?  Her rank is lofty, but not so lofty as my ambition.  I will be sworn to muster just as much regard for my Lady Cosgrove as you ever showed her; and if I win her, and wear her when you are dead and gone, corbleu, knight, do you think that it will be the fear of your ghost will deter me?
Person2: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one; my wife so fond of me, that she is even now thinking of appointing a successor?  Isn't it a comfort to see her; like a prudent housewife, getting everything ready for her husband's departure?
Person1: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, knight?
Person2: Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps.  Why, man, I have been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.  Who knows how long I may keep you waiting.
Person1: Sir, let those laugh that win.
Person2: I am sorry for you Mr. James.  I'm grieved to keep you or any gentleman waiting.  Had you not better to arrange with my doctor or get the cook to flavor my omelette with arsenic?  What are the odds, gentlemen, that I don't live to see Mr. James hang yet?

I'm been hot on your trail you could say because I was hoping you'd consider coming to New York and taking a look at my daughter's horse and possibly --

When the time of the Gathering came the urge to go was so strong we tried to claw through rock with our bare hands.  What you thought was the end -- was not.  This is the end.  We are the last of our kind, Macleod.

But someday maybe you'll learn that being smart and always being on top and doing whatever you need to do to get ahead, and yes, stepping on people to get there, well, there's a lot more to life than that.  And in the end, you're only cheating yourself.

I think the lesson there is that, old and young, we ail make mistakes, and we have to learn that our actions, all of them, can carry serious consequences.  You're very young, Tracy underage, in fact -- but maybe one day you'll understand.

Especially when certain young, naive people's mothers are para-legal secretaries at the city's biggest law firm and have won many successful lawsuits. And if you want to keep questioning me like this, I won't continue without my attorney present.

Person1: What was the name of that kid at Anzio, the one who got his face burned off?
Person2: Vecchio.
Person1: Yeah, Vecchio, I couldn't remember his name, he was a good kid, remember how he used to walk on his hands and sing that song about the man on flying trapeze?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: You know why I'm such a good officer? Because of my mother.  Have I ever told you about her?
Person2: Bits and pieces.
Person1: She's the best poker player you ever saw.  My father used to go to these Saturday night games and lose his shirt.  Finally, my mother gave him an ultimatum, either she gets a regular seat at the table or she locks him in every Saturday night. He squawked and so did his buddies but after a while they gave in and from the first night she sat down, she never lost.  She could read those cocky bastards like they were playing open hands.  And he bluffs?  He had sixteen levels of bullshit.  Her eyes, the tone of her voice, her bets, her jokes, the way she sipped her coffee, she was a master.  She won more money on shit hands than anyone in the history of the game. Every Saturday night, my father would lose two, three hundred bucks and she'd win it all back and then some. And I'd stand there, glued to her shoulder, from the time I was five years old, watching every hand, every move, studying how she did it.  That's why I'm such a good officer, I can look at a man's face and tell you exactly what he's holding, and if it's a shit hand, I know just what cards to deal him.
Person2: And what about your own hand?
Person1: No problem.  A pair of deuces?  Less? So what?  I bluff.  It used to tear me apart when I'd get one of my men killed, but what was I supposed to do?  Break down in front of the ones who were standing there waiting for me to tell them what to do?  Of course not, so I bluffed, and after a while, I started to fall for my own bluff. It was great, it made everything so much easier.  Sarge Is that why your hand's been shaking?
Person1: It could be worse.  You know the first thing they teach you at O.C.S.? Lie to your men.
Person2: Oh, yeah?
Person1: Not in so many words, but they tell you you can have all the firepower in the world and if your men don't have good morale, it's not worth a damn.  So if you're scared or empty or half-a-step from a Section Eight, do you tell your men?  Of course not.  You bluff, you lie.
Person2: And how do you bluff yourself?
Person1: Simple, numbers.  Every time you kill one of your men, you tell yourself you just saved the lives of two, three, ten, a hundred others. We lost, what, thirty-one on the cliffs?  I'll bet we saved ten times that number by putting out those guns.  That's over three hundred men.  Maybe five hundred.  A thousand. Then thousand.  Any number you want. See?  It's simple.  It lets you always choose mission over men.
Person2: Except this time, the mission IS a man.
Person1: That's the rub.  I liked Wade.  Who's Ryan?  If they're both standing in front of me and I have to shoot one or the other, how do I choose?  Look at my hand, there it goes again.
Person2: John, I've got to tell you, I think you're about used up.
Person1: I think you're right, Keith.
Person2: You want me to take over?

I'm sorry.  I'm not supposed to... I shouldn't go on like this.

Person1: An old friend. I was rummaging through a closet and it was just sitting there. Like it was waiting for me.

I never meant it to become my life. And if I hadn't gotten rid of her now, I'd have ended up writing her forever.  For the first time in fifteen years, I think I'm really onto something here.
Person2: I'm glad to hear that, Paul, I really am. But you have to know--when your fans find out that you killed off their favorite heroine, they're not going to say, "Ooh, good, Paul Sheldon can finally write what we've always wanted. An esoteric, semi-autobiographical character study.

You think I'm dying to go back to shouting in the wilderness?  I'm doing this because I have to.  Now, I'm leaving for Colorado to try to finish this and I want your good thoughts--because if I can make it work ...  I might just have something that I want on my tombstone.

Person1: I know it's a cornball thing but love is passion, obsession, someone you can't live without.  If you don't start with that, what are you going to end up with?  I say fall head over heels.  Find someone you can love like crazy and who'll love you the same way back.  And how do you find him?  Forget your head and listen to your heart.  I'm not hearing any heart.  Run the risk, if you get hurt, you'll come back.  Because, the truth is there is no sense living your life without this.  To make the journey and not fall deeply in love -- well, you haven't lived a life at all. You have to try.  Because if you haven't tried, you haven't lived.

Person2: Again, I am the author of the definitive book on the Woodsboro murders.!  What about you?

Person1: The boys said no.  She wouldn't give her name. A month later, the station gets broken into, the file room ransacked.

Person1: No, actually I went to Craignewton but I was worried that you wouldn't have heard of it so I put the Royal Edinburgh College instead, because they're both schools, right, and we're all in this together, and I wanted to put across the general idea rather than the details, yeah? People get all hung up on details, but what's the point? Like which school? Does it matter? Why? When? Where? Or how many O grades did I get? Could be six, could be one, but that's not important. What's important is that I am, right? That I am.

Person1: What am I going to to do with this guy?  Pierce, I was just on the phone with Borough Command. Out of twelve shifts this month, you've been late for nine, sick four and that includes the shift where you came late and went home early.

Person2: I'm sorry Captain. Don't take it too hard.

Person2: You know they won't do it. It's up to you. You gotta be strong.
Person1: I feel for you, but we got an emergency here. It's a weekend of full moons.  Everyone's called in sick. Larry, Veeber, Stanley too. We need bodies out there. I had to put Marcus on Twelve Young. You know he's not supposed to work two nights in a row.
Person2: You swore you'd fire me if I came in late again.

Person1: No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You see, when I was little me mother let me make some treacle toffee one time in our back scullery. When I'd done she said to me, "Go and give some to the other kids." So, I said I would but I thought to meself, "She must think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating away there but I wanted somebody else to know how good it was so in the end I wound up giving it all away ... but I didn't mind, mind, 'cos I'd made the stuff in the first place. Well ... that's why you need other people... an audience ... to taste your treacle toffee, like. Eh ... does that sound as thickheaded to you as it does to me?
Person2: Not really but I'm probably not a toffee maker. How would you do those lines of mine?
Person1: Well, look at it this way, I mean, when you come right down to it, that girl, she's a bit of a scrubber, isn't she?
Person2: Is she?
Person1: Of course ... Look, if she was a Liverpool scrubber ...  Eh, fella, you want to try pulling the other one, it's got a full set of bells hanging off it ... Y'what? ... I know your sort, two cokes and a packet of cheese and onion crisps and suddenly it's love and we're stopping in an empty shop doorway. You're just after me body and y'can't have it ... so there!!
Person2: And you honestly think that's what she meant?
Person1: Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile, she's trying to get him to marry her but he doesn't want ... well ... I don't reckon any fella's ever wanted to get married. But girls are like that, clever and cunning. You've got to laugh.

Person1: No. It's your turn to tell me, Clarice. You don't have any more vacations to sell, on Anthrax Island. Why did you run away from that ranch?

Person1: He asked me why I thought I was in danger and I said.

Person1: Look, do you want the truth, or just what you want me to say?
Person2: I want the truth.
Person1: The truth is that I heard between four and six shots.  I'm not going to lie for you.
Person2: ...you heard echoes.
Person1: No.  I had guns all my life.  I used to go turtle shooting.
Person2: I realize you're under a great deal of stress .. it's clouded your judgement.
Person1: So off the record, he starts talking about my family, and even mentioned my marriage was in trouble like I didn't know it or something.  He got angrier and angrier and then
Person2: Look, we can put you in a mental institution.  We can make you look crazier'n Marguerite Oswald, and everybody knows how crazy she is.
Person1: I knew something was crooked as a dog's hind leg, 'cause no one who is just taking a deposition gets that involved and angry... sure enough, when I finally read my testimony as published by the Warren Commission, it was a fabrication from start to finish.

Person1: This had nothing to do with shoes that didn't fit or my relationship with my father who, as you know, made a fortune selling penny loafers in the fifties. These people died because of the criminal actions of my doctor.

Person1: Yes.  My psychiatrist didn't insist that I stay on my medication.

Person2: Permanently disrupted?  Aren't you selling paintings now for quite a lot of money?  Hasn't this 'incident' as you call it, jump started your career as an artist?
Person1: Look, I'm in here.  You call this a career move?
Person2: And isn't there a movie in the works about you?

Person2: But doesn't the Son of Sam Law prevent criminals from profiting from their crimes?

I would kill anyone so much as lays a finger on her or her beautiful daughter, but that pisher you socked in the mouth has the most expensive dentist in Beverly Hills and wants I should buy him an implant. Person1: Was it my fault? Did I know that coal mine was going to have another cave-in? I meant to be with you on our honeymoon, Hildy -- honest I did.
Person2: All I know is that instead of two weeks in Atlantic City with my bridegroom, I spent two weeks in a coal mine with John Kruptzky -- age sixty-three -- getting food and air out of a tube! You don't deny that. Do you?
Person1: Deny it! I'm proud of it! We beat the whole country on that story.
Person2: Well, suppose we did? That isn't what I got married for. What's the good of -- Look, Walter, I came up here to tell you that you'll have to stop phoning me a dozen times a day -- sending twenty telegrams -- all the rest of it, because I'm --
Person1: Let's not fight, Hildy. Tell you what. You come back to work on the paper and if we find we can't get along in a friendly way, we'll get married again.
Person2: What?!!
Person1: I haven't any hard feelings.
Person2: Walter, you're wonderful in a loathesome sort of way. Now, would you mind keeping quiet long enough for me to tell you what I came up here for?
Person1: Sure, come on. We'll have some lunch and you can tell me everything.
Person2: I have a lunch date. I just want --
Person1: You can break it, can't you?
Person2: No, I can't.
Person1: Sure you can. Come on.
Person2: Don't tell me what to do! We're divorced -- I'm a free woman. You're not my husband and you're not my boss! And what's more, you're not going to be my boss.
Person1: What do you mean by that?
Person2: Just what I said. That's what I --
Person1: You mean you're not coming back to work here?
Person2: That's the first time you've been right today. That's what I --
Person1: You've had a better offer, eh?
Person2: You bet I've got a better offer.
Person1: Well, go on and take it. Work for somebody else! That's the gratitude I get for --
Person2: I know, Walter, but I --
Person1: What were you when you came here five years ago? A little college girl from a School of Journalism! I took a little doll-faced mugg --
Person2: You wouldn't have taken me if I hadn't been doll-faced!
Person1: Why should I? I thought it would be a novelty to have a face around here a man could look at without shuddering.
Person2: Listen, Walter --
Person1: I made a great reporter out of you, Hildy, but you won't be half as good on any other paper, and you know it. You need me and I need you -- and the paper needs both of us.
Person2: Well, the paper'll have to learn to do without me. And so will you. It just didn't work out, Walter.
Person1: It would have worked if you'd been satisfied with just being editor and reporter. But no! You had to marry me and spoil everything.
Person2: I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I proposed to you!
Person1: Well, you practically did! Making goo-goo eyes at me for two years till I broke down. And I still claim I was tight the night I proposed. If you'd been a gentleman you'd have forgotten all about it. But not you!
Person2: You -- you --

And I've given my whole life for you.  If you kicked off tomorrow, where'd I be? Out in the gutter!  Sure I took those bonds.  Who has a better right -- ?

Person1: His real name is Benjamin Raspail. A former patient of mine, whose romantic attachments ran to, shall we say, the exotic...? I didn't kill him, merely tucked him away. Very much as I found him, in that ridiculous car, in his own garage, after he's missed three appointments. You'd have him under "Missing Person" - which, in poor Raspail's case, could hardly be more true.

Person2: That doesn't interest me, Doctor. And it's the sort of thing Miggs would ask.

Person2: I don't know. Is it?
Person1: Or doesn't this all begin to suggest to you a kind of... negotiation? There's something Crawford can give me, and I want to trade for it. I even wrote to him, offering my help. But he hates me, so he won't deal directly.
