Person1: No, we're here for information, to find out where a man named Ricky Tan is.  We must tread softly and keep our ears open.
Person2: Tread softly?  Who taught you how to roost a bar?
Person1: Carter, you don't understand.  These men are Fu-Cang-Long Triads.  Part of the most deadly gang in China.
Person2: Man, are you crazy?  You think that scares me?  I'm from  L.A.  We invented gangs.  We were having gang wars before anybody even thought about it.  We get royalties from other gangs.  Now gimme your badge and gun and I'll show you how it's done.
Person1: No.  You are a civilian.  In China, I am Michael Jackson, and you are Toto.
Person2: You mean Tito.  We had  Toto for dinner last night.

Person1: You're the only person in this place who can see right through me.
Person2: You've made us look pretty good in the past week.  And the way you handled the press --
Person1: Just following your example.
Person2: D.C.'s very high on giving you the promotion.  There's just one problem.
Person1: What's that?
Person2: Me.  I have doubts about your ability to stick with what is essentially a desk job.
Person1: I had doubts too.  I always looked at a desk as though it were a ball-and-chain. But something happened ...

Person1: Is that your answer, Old Man? You're a hardcase too, ain't you?
Person2: Luke, are you alright?... They got us, boy. They're out there thicker'n flies. Bosses and dogs and sheriffs and more guns than I ever seen in my life. We don't have a chance, Luke... They caught up with me right after we split up and they was aimin' to kill you, Luke. But I got 'em to promise if you give up peaceful, they wouldn't even whip you this time.
Person1: Do we even get our same bunks back?
Person2: Why sure, Luke. I mean I didn't talk to them about that. But why not? They're reasonable, Luke. Hell, we only been gone a coupla hours.
Person1: You don't understand a thing, do you, Drag?
Person2: Luke, you got to listen to me. All you got to do is just give up nice and quiet, just play it cool.
Person1: Like I always do?
Person2: Thass right. Just play it...

Person1: I noticed you seemed distant at the meeting. Is everything okay?
Person2: It's just some personal stuff.
Person1: Do you want to share? Maybe I can help.
Person2: It's not important. I'll handle it. Thanks for asking though.
Person1: Alright, but remember you can always talk to me.

Person1: You would leave me for Armand if he beckoned you.
Person2: Never.
Person1: He wants you as you want him. He's been waiting for you. He wants you for a companion. He bides his time that place. he finds them as dull and lifeless as we do.
Person2: That's not so.
Person1: Do you know what his soul said to me without saying a word? When he put me in that trance...
Person2: So you felt it too!
Person1: Let him go, he said. Let him go.

Person1: SAY IT!
Person2: I got that...sir.

Person1: If you meant it, you wouldn't show it to me, Betty.  Or am I supposed to deliver it to dear Inspector Killaine?
Person2: Wrote it in the waiting room of the Hudson Bay Store.  With somebody's Pekingese trying to climb into my lap.  Perhaps you're right.  Perhaps I didn't mean it. All I know is that I'm licked.
Person1: There's a lot of water between Vancouver and the U.S.A. This note is a suicide note.  After you're gone where would they look for you?  Why would they look for you? Darkness, and open water, and a fast cabin cruiser.  And I have a pocket full of money.  And if I helped you, I'd be committing a crime, or so they tell me.
Person2: That wasn't why I called you.  Why did I hope--when I hadn't any right to hope?
Person1: How bad is it?  Bad enough for--
Person2: Yes.  I've never been very far from it, for a long time.  Will you do something for me?

Person1: -- is that what this is all about?
Person2: Yes and you don't have to be sarcastic about it, that's a beautiful thing he's doing -- some people do more than go to the beauty parlor and shop at Saks --
Person1: Lester, you're a miserable man. You're not helping anybody. You're just twisting arms to raise money for a lot of silly son of a bitches that are out for themselves -- this is just business, don't kid yourself. And you know the worst thing about it, even if it does somebody some good somewhere which I can't possibly imagine, you'll never know the difference. You're just sweating and kidding yourself - and you're kidding yourself if you think your new business partner is going to keep his hands off that girl -- or that she'll keep her hands off him.
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: -- think what you have time to think, Lester.

Person1: I've got evidence of the shortcuts you've been taking in the production process.
Person2: That's a serious accusation, Tara.
Person1: It's not an accusation if it's the truth.
Person2: Watch your step; it would be unfortunate if things got ugly.
Person1: I'm only interested in ensuring the company's integrity. Do what you must.

Person1: It's some kind of trick... a preliminary airstrike in response to our troop movement.
Person2: They are in our airspace. We would be within our rights.
Person1: The world would not look on us kindly if we shot down a civilian airliner.

Person1: You mind telling me what that's supposed to mean?
Person2: Nothing.
Person1: If you got a problem with me taking care of your kids instead of getting some job, just say so.
Person2: I didn't say that.
Person1: Cause I can get a job.  I will.  And you can start leaving the kids with the chicken fat lady again.  Would that make you happy?
Person2: Keep your voice down.
Person1: I know what they can sleep through, Erin.  I probably know it better than you.

Person1: Wow, I guess I hit a nerve.
Person2: You make it sound like, you know, I have no needs or something.  You think I'm too self-sufficient?
Person1: Now, Hannah, that's not what I meant, you know.  Uh, yeah, everybody relies on you for so much. "You're so giving. It's not a criticism.  We love you. We're grateful."
Person2: You're grateful, but you resent me.
Person1: Oh, wow!  I don't want to have this conversation.  I didn't do anything wrong.

Person1: Now listen. Now that you're on your way, it would be stupid of you to stop. Think of Sebastian as a tutor. Let him instruct you.
Person2: I don't love him. I love Ronald.
Person1: So? Don't you want to make Ronald a happy pappy? Practice makes perfect, Cecile. My advice is to sleep with as many people as possible.
Person2: But that would make me a slut.  Wouldn't it?
Person1: Cecile, everybody does it. It's just that nobody talks about it.

Person1: So I was driving to work today, and some bozo in a Cadillac cut me off...
Person2: Oh, that's terrible, Reege...
Person1: So I followed him...
Person2: You followed him?
Person1: I followed him all the way downtown, and when he gets out of the car, I reach under my seat and pull out an aluminum bat.
Person2: You keep a bat under your seat?
Person1: Recently, yes! So I run up behind this guy, and start bashing his brains in with this bat, and it made me feel happy! Did you ever see THE UNTOUCHABLES?
Person2: Yes, great movie...
Person1: I was DeNiro!

Person1: According to my sources, the world will end on February 14, in the year 2016.
Person2: Valentine's Day.  That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine?
Person1: I received this information from an alien.  I was at the Paramus Holiday Inn, I was having a drink in the bar when he approached me and started talking.  Then he must have used some sort of ray or a mind control device because he made me follow him to his room and that's where he told me about the end of the world.
Person2: Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn?
Person1: It may have been a room on the spacecraft made up to look like a room in the Holiday Inn.  I can't be sure, Peter.
Person2: No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens; you just can't trust them. You may get some nice ones occasionally like Starman or E.T., but most of them turn out to be some kind of lizard.  Anyway, we're just about out of time.  Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets.  Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ...  ... Good night.

Person1: I've heard the kidnapping story, so save it.  I know you're mixed up in all this, Dude, and I don't care what you're trying to take off her husband.  That's your business.  All I'm saying is, I want mine.
Person2: Yeah, well, right man, there are many facets to this, uh, you know, many interested parties.  If I can find your money, man-- what's in it for the Dude?
Person1: Of course, there's that to discuss. Refill?
Person2: Does the Pope shit in the woods?
Person1: Let's say a 10% finder's fee?
Person2: Okay, Jackie, done.  I like the way you do business.  Your money is being held by a kid named Larry Sellers. He lives in North Hollywood, on Radford, near the In-and-Out Burger. A real brat, but I'm sure your goons'll be able to get it off him, mean he's only fifteen and he's flunking social studies.  So if you'll just write me a check for my ten per cent. . . of half a million. . . fifty grand.

Person1: Why are you pulling away from me? I've noticed you've been spending more time with your friends than with me.
Person2: It's not like that, Laura. I just need some space sometimes.
Person1: I always put you first, unlike others. Why can't you see that?
Person2: It's not a competition. I appreciate everything you do for me, but it's important to have a balance.
Person1: I just wish you'd recognize the effort I make for us, that's all.

Person1: You taught my child that I am some unsuccessful loser.  Who didn't care about her pain.
Person2: That's not wh...
Person1: You think I didn't have some harsh words for that little troublemaker? You think I couldn't figure out some sharp criticisms?
Person2: You weren't passing 'em out.
Person1: Well, maybe your version of growing up is 'Just win, baby'.

Person1: You know what I want to do?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: What do I want to do?
Person2: You want to fuck me. But you can't fuck me.
Person1: Why?
Person2: Because, you know why. You know.
Person1: Because your a virgin?
Person2: Because I'm a virgin and I don't want no baby.
Person1: You think I want a baby? When you're with me, you don't have to worry about that kinda stuff.
Person2: Why is that?
Person1: Because I like you. I think you're beautiful. I think if we were together, you would love it. You wouldn't even believe it.
Person2: I wouldn't believe it?
Person1: I don't know. I just think that you would love it.
Person2: But, I don't know. I'm just scared that things would change. Between us.
Person1: What things? I'm telling you, nothing's going to change.  I want to make you happy. That's all.

Person1: Fran -- remember that last weekend we had?
Person2: Do I. That leaky little boat you rented -- and me in a black negligee and a life preserver --
Person1: Remember what we talked about?
Person2: We talked about a lot of things.
Person1: I mean -- about my getting a divorce.
Person2: We didn't talk about it -- you did.
Person1: You didn't really believe me, did you?
Person2: They got it an a long playing record now - Music to String Her Along By. My wife doesn't understand me -- We haven't gotten along for years -- You're the best thing that ever happened to me --
Person1: That's enough, Fran.
Person2: Just trust me, baby -- we'll work it out somehow --
Person1: You're not being funny.
Person2: I wasn't trying.
Person1: If you'll just listen to me for a minute --
Person2: Okay. I'm sorry.
Person1: I saw my lawyer this morning -- I wanted his advice  -- about the best way to handle it --
Person2: Handle what?
Person1: What do you think?
Person2: Let's get something straight, Jeff -- I never asked you to leave your wife.
Person1: Of course not. You had nothing to do with it.
Person2: Are you sure that's what you want?
Person1: I'm sure. If you'll just tell me that you still love me --
Person2: You know I do.
Person1: Fran --

Person1: Now, are you sure you want to drive that horse back yourself? There are plenty of people 'round here who do that sort of thing.
Person2: I already know the way... and it's not like I have a job I have to rush home for.  Between you and me, I could use the time alone.

Person1: I don't?
Person2: Of course not. Not when you've got so much going for you.
Person1: I do?
Person2: Sure! But nobody knows it. Least of all you.  Look, would you mind if I gave you some constructive criticism?
Person1: Actually, yes.
Person2: Well, you shouldn't  Be more aggressive, Clark! Trust your instinct! When you see your opportunity, grab it! I do.

Person1: By the way, shouldn't you have had a period by now?
Person2: I'm a little late, that's all.
Person1: How late?
Person2: What difference does it make? If anything was to happen, which I'm sure it isn't, it would be my responsibility.
Person1: Exactly how late are you, Lynette?
Person2: What do you care? Suppose I was pregnant. Just suppose it. You don't think I'd try to make you do anything you don't want to, do you?
Person1: No. But that's not the only issue here, sweetheart. There's a lot more to it than that.

Person1: That's a terrible idea-
Person2: -is it, I'm sorry, but then, of course, you're the doctor, you should know.
Person1: Silliest thing I ever heard of- why in the world should we go through all that?
Person2: I suppose I could answer you. I suppose I could explain that the place is so inviting, what with the smell of blood and flesh, that they have to strike. It's even possible that I tell you I found some fresh paw marks around back which means they're already contemplating feasting here.  But I don't want to answer you because when you question me you are really saying that I don't have the least idea what I am doing, that I am nothing but an incompetent, that I am a fool.  Anyone who finds me a fool, please say so now.
Person1: I have been desperate for Patterson to let me move the hospital since the day he arrived.
Person2: Then we agree.

Person1: Is this Friedman?
Person2: Who are you? Who are you working for, huh?
Person1: Is this Friedman, Martin?  Come on, scumbag. Youve reached your sell- by date. Tell me if this is Friedman, where he is in Los Angeles and what name hes using?
Person2: Youre making a mistake, tough guy. Whoever he is, your guys not one of Friedmans...
Person1: You seem very sure about that.
Person2: I told you... The rabble, its me...  Huh... Its sad.
Person1: What is?
Person2: Dying without ever reaching the top...

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: I, I don't know.
Person1: What do you want?

Person1: Mmm, I don't know if you remember me, but we had the worst night of my life together.
Person2: I remember you.
Person1: Yes, you do recall, right?
Person2: I recall you.
Person1: I was walking past and I saw you in here...
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: ...and I thought I'd come in and...and we could replay, uh, the whole, uh...
Person2: We didn't hit it off.
Person1: Oh, that's putting it mildly.  We did everything but exchange gunshots.
Person2: How are you?
Person1: Good.  How are you?
Person2: I'm fine.
Person1: You look wonderful.
Person2: Oh, no.
Person1: Yeah, really.  You do.  You do.
Person2: Yeah?
Person1: It was a terrible evening.
Person2: Yeah, it was.
Person1: Remember slamming the cab door in my face and..  you know, it came very dangerously close to emasculating my nose in a...

Person1: Rose.
Person2: Kitty...
Person1: Rose, we have a crisis.  I am sure that you are aware of the horrible allegations against Jim Cunningham.
Person2: Yes, I saw the news. Something about a kiddie-porn dungeon.
Person1: Please! Don't say those words.  Well... as you can see... many of us are devastated by this news. This is obviously some kind of conspiracy meant to destroy an innocent man. And I have taken it upon myself to spearhead the Jim Cunningham defence campaign. But unfortunately my civic duties have created a conflict of interest... which involves you.
Person2: Beg pardon?
Person1: Rose... I have to appear at his arraignment tomorrow morning. And as you know, the girls also leave for Los Angeles tomorrow morning. Now, as their coach... I was the obvious choice to chaperone them on the trip.
Person2: But now you can't go.
Person1: Yes. And believe me, of all the other mothers I would never dream of asking you, given the predicament with your son. But none of the other mothers are able to go.
Person2: Oh, Kitty, I don't know. This is so last-minute... Eddie is in New York...
Person1: Rose... I don't know if you realise how great an opportunity this is for our daughters. This has been a dream of ours for a long time.  Sometimes I doubt your commitment to Sparkle Motion.

Person1: This is the newest technology approved for general implementation. It's called a locater implant. Every parolee gets one.  We're going to know where you are every second for the rest of your life.
Person2: If you try to run, I'll hunt you down and kill you myself.
Person1: Yes or no, Mr. Barnes?

Person1: How could she have done this to me? How could anyone do this to anyone?
Person2: You didn't say anything about my hair.

Person1: Hello?
Person2: Where are you?  You're driving me crazy, waiting like this.  I want you in me now!

Person1: Okay. I think everything's set.  You've got the number for Cape Cod, right? Just in case something goes wrong.
Person2: No problem, Vinnie. Everything's under control.  I could run this store in my sleep.
Person1: How long you been working for me, Auggie?
Person2: I don't know. Thirteen, fourteen years. Something like that.
Person1: It's pretty crazy, don't you think? I mean, a smart guy like you. What do you want to hang on to a dead-end job like this for?
Person2: I don't know.  Maybe because I love you so much, boss.
Person1: Gosh. You should have been married to someone by now. You know, settled down somewhere with a kid or two, a nice steady job.
Person2: I almost got married once.
Person1: Yeah, I know. To that girl who moved to Pittsburgh.
Person2: Ruby McNutt. My one true love.
Person1: Sounds like another one of your stories to me.
Person2: She upped and married some other cat after I joined the navy. By the time I got my discharge, though, she was divorced. Her husband poked out her eye in a domestic quarrel.
Person1: Lovely.
Person2: She made a play for me after I got back, but her glass eye kept interfering with my concentration. Every time we got into a clinch, I'd start thinking about that hole in her head, that empty socket with the glass eye in it. An eye that couldn't see, an eye that couldn't shed any tears. The minute I started thinking about it, Mr. Johnson would get all soft and small. And I can't see getting married if Mr. Johnson isn't going to be in tiptop shape.
Person1: You don't take anything seriously, do you?
Person2: I try not to, anyway. It's better for your health. I mean, look at you, Vincent. You're the guy with the wife and three kids and the ranch house on Long Island. You're the guy with the white shoes and the white Caddy and the white shag carpet. But you've had two heart attacks, and I'm still waiting for my first.
Person1: I should stop smoking these damn things is what I should do. They are going to kill me one day.
Person2: Enjoy it while you can, Vin. Pretty soon, they're going to legislate us out of business anyway.
Person1: They catch you smoking tobacco, they'll stand you up against a wall and shoot you.
Person2: Tobacco today, sex tomorrow. In three or four years, it'll probably be against the law to smile at strangers.
Person1: Speaking of which, are you still going ahead with that deal on the Montecristos?
Person2: It's all set. My guy in Miami said he'd have them within the next few weeks.  Are you sure you don't want to go in with me? Five thousand dollars outlay, a guaranteed ten-thousand-dollar return. A consortium of Court Street lawyers and judges. They're just drooling to get their lips around some genuine Cuban cigars.
Person1: No thanks. I don't care what you do, but just make sure you don't get caught, okay? The last I heard, it was still illegal to sell Cuban cigars in this country.
Person2: It's the law that's buying. That's what's so beautiful about it. I mean, when was the last time you heard of a judge sending himself to jail?
Person1: Suit yourself. But don't keep the boxes around here long.
Person2: They come in, they go out. I've got it planned to the last detail.
Person1: I've got to get moving. Terry will bust my chops if I'm late. See you in September, Auggie.
Person2: Okay, my man. Love to the wife and kids, et cetera, et cetera. Drop me a postcard if you can remember the address.

Person1: Antha...your grandmother...her life ended there, on the stones. Head split open like a melon.
Person2: Why are you doing this...?  Handing out these horrors! Why...?!!
Person1: You have the Mayfair eyes.   Tell me, Rowan --- what have those eyes seen that the mind can't fathom...?

Person1: I ain't never used no hatchet that I remember.
Person2: You're just crazy in a retarded kind of way then.  It wouldn't matter to me if you did do violence on somebody 'cause I ain't afraid of shit. You think I'm afraid for you to stay here. You're just a bit odd it looks like to me. Not really, I'm just jokin' with you. Welcome to our humble home, buddy. Frank needs all the friends he can get. Frank's a real weak little kid. His daddy taught him how to be a timid person.

Person1: Nobody's trading with anybody! Look, this ain't a goddamn city counsel meeting! Listen up Mr. Pink. We got two ways here, my way or the highway. And you can go down either of 'em. So what's it gonna be, Mr. Pink?
Person2: Goodness, Joe. Forget it. This is beneath me. I'm Mr. Pink, let's move on.

Person1: Baxter, we're a little disappointed in you -- gratitude-wise.
Person2: Oh, I'm very grateful.

Person1: I think I'm stupid.....All you do is use me and expect me to wait for you.
Person2: No.
Person1: I thought you loved me Doug but all you want from me is sex.

Person1: What are you crazy?
Person2: Do you know how easy it would be for you to just disappear. Shit, you wouldn't even wash up for weeks. Do you understand? I want you to get off your backside. I want a bunch of Panthers served up on a plate. I want you to set 'em up... armed robbery!!
Person1: I can't... they don't work that way...
Person2: Forget how they work. Just do it. Like your man says, "By any means necessary."

Person1: Santos... What's happenin' here?
Person2: Hey... Stop the nervous cry-baby routine... You're my girl now... Santos is gonna wipe away those tears and make you happy... Come on, let's get outta here.
Person1: Where we goin'?
Person2: Got word the kids are moving through Texas... I think an ending is being arranged there... Come on, lemme see a smile.
Person1: Please Santos... Where's Johnnie?

Person1: Because I lost a filling in my back tooth. I gotta go to the dentist tomorrow.
Person2: Dentist?  We been out of work for four months - and you want to blow your first week's pay on your teeth?
Person1: It's just a little inlay - it doesn't even have to be gold -
Person2: How can you be so selfish?  We owe back rent - we're in four eighty-nine bucks to Moe's Delicatessen - we're being sued by three Chinese lawyers because our check bounced at the laundry - we've borrowed money from every girl in the line -
Person1: You're right, Joe.
Person2: Of course I am.
Person1: First thing tomorrow we're going to pay everybody a little something on account.
Person2: No we're not.
Person1: We're not?
Person2: First thing tomorrow we're going out to the dog track and put the whole bundle on Greased Lightning.
Person1: You're going to bet my money on a dog?
Person2: He's a shoo-in.  I got the word from Max the waiter - his brother-in-law is the electrician who wires the rabbit -
Person1: What are you giving me with the rabbit?
Person2: Look at those odds - ten to one. If he wins, we can pay everybody.
Person1: But suppose he loses?
Person2: What are you worried about?  This job is going to last a long time.
Person1: But suppose it doesn't?
Person2: Jerry-boy - why do you have to paint everything so black? Suppose you get hit by a truck? Suppose the stock market crashes?

Person1: Who do you think you are? Where do you think you are? Why do you think I shouldn't just put you in a dumpster?
Person2: I have money --
Person1: I got money.
Person2: I'll pay you a thousand dollars.  I have it in my wallet.
Person1: I want your money, I'll take your money.
Person2: Just tell me where she is.

Person1: He is a very close friend.  Do you have some explanation of what happened in my apartment?
Person2: Yes, but I have to tell you in private at a fine restaurant.
Person1: Can't you tell me now?
Person2: I'll cancel the reservation,  I found the name "Zuul" in ...  The Roylance Guide to Secret Societies and Sects.  I don't suppose you've  read it.
Person1: You must have gotten the last copy.
Person2: Well, the name Zuul refers to a demi-god worshipped around 6000 B.C. by the ... What's that say?
Person1: Hittites,  the Mesopotamians and the Sumerians.  "Zuul was the Minion of Gozer."
Person2: "Gozer" -- he was very big in the Sumerian religion.  One of their gods.
Person1: What's he doing in my refrigerator.
Person2: I'm checking on that.  I think we should meet Thursday night at nine to talk about it.
Person1: I don't think so.  I'm busy Thursday night.
Person2: You think I enjoy giving up my evenings to spend time with clients?  I'm making an exception because I respect you as an artist and as a dresser.
Person1: All right.  Since you put it that way.
Person2: I'll pick you up at your place.  I'll bring along the Roylance Guide -- we can read after we eat.
Person1: I've got to go now.

Person1: Baby, please don't... I love you.
Person2: I don't want to be a fool!... I want to look them in the eye and say, I know!
Person1: Baby, don't do this --
Person2: -- it'll help me if you'll tell me.
Person1: -- please, baby --
Person2: -- no, it'll help me, really --
Person1: How?
Person2: I'll know you've lied to me... all along. I'll know you're incapable of... love... that'll help me... not now, but eventually.

Person1: What happened?
Person2: You remember the '99 Chrysler LeBaron? It's the exact height of the front fender.  Looked right instead of left.
Person1: So you're not so smart after all.  I want you to know--if it ever came to it-- I'd be willing to get an ovum from the Egg Bank.  In fact, I'd rather use a donor egg--  --if it came to it.
Person2: But "if it came to it" then it couldn't have your--  --nose.  How perfect does your child have to be?
Person1: You hypocrite.  Do you think for one moment you'd be doing what you're doing if it wasn't for who you are--what you are?  Don't you get any satisfaction knowing that your children will be able to live to a ripe old age unless they do something foolish?
Person2: That's precisely what scares me--that they won't do anything foolish or courageous or anything--worth a Goddamn.

Person1: Don't you remember? We were at the office party together --
Person2: Oh, yes -- office party -- Miss Olsen --
Person1: That's right.  I told you we had a fight -- that's what it was about -- Miss Olsen -- you know that other girl you saw --
Person2: I don't understand --
Person1: It's not important, Fran -- the main thing is that I got here in time -- and you're going to be all right --  -- isn't she, Doc?
Person2: I'm so tired -- DR. DREYFUSS Here -- drink this.

Person1: I thought I'd show you one of my favourite places.
Person2: It's paradise . We could be very happy here.
Person1: But I have to go back. I brought you here so you'd be safe. From her.
Person2: You can't just abandon me.  Alone.

Person1: Oh, hello, perhaps you could help me.  I'm looking for an aerosol love potion I could spray on a certain Penthouse Pet that would make her unconditionally submit to an unusual personal request.
Person2: Oh, hiya, Pete.
Person1: So, no goat hooves, huh?
Person2: I knew that voice sounded familiar.  What's up?  How's it going?
Person1: Nowhere -- fast.  Why don't you lock up and buy me a sub?

Person2: I didnt know my husband and Friedman knew each other. I just...  Do you think we spoke about it? Ive known for five years. Hes known Ive known for five years... But not once have we spoken about it. There are things one just doesnt speak about...
